full_text: #dnd tip: Build some background into your magic items. Where did that sword come from? How did it get to the dragons hoard?
#dnd tip: You don't always have to use wet erase mats or dwarven forge or dungeon tiles separately. Mix them together. Be a kid again!
#dnd tip: Gnoll minis can make decent Rakshasa minis when you don't want to spend a mint on the Rakshasa minis. Cat warriors too.
#dnd tip: A black cloth tablecloth works well to hold dungeon tiles in place and doesn't distract from the map. Nice for bottomless chasms.
#dnd tip: A few short skill challenges can show the players progress through a long journey. "Remember that time back at the Lake of Fire?"
#dnd tip: Don't underestimate a good ad-hoc skill challenge. What's the situation? What's the goal? What happens on success or failure?
#dnd tip: Don't burn paper, soak it, and then microwave it. It will catch fire again and burn your house down. Learned the hard way. #dnd
#dnd tip: A cut up black t-shirt can make a great fog of war for your dwarven forge layout.
#dnd tip: reskin one of your big bad evil guys with stats from a Monster Manual 2 beast to see how it plays out.
#dnd tip: Want to get your warped D&D miniatures straightened? Put them in boiling water, straighten them, and put them in bowl of ice water
#dnd tip: Game going long? Distribute loot and exp in email between games. Add some good background or flavor text too.
#dnd tip: Make skill challenge failure interesting and an opportunity for something new.
#dnd tip: Sudoku puzzles with runes or sigils instead of numbers can make for fun arcanic puzzles provided you have a player good at sudoku.
#dnd tip: It's hard to keep a villain reoccurring. Don't overuse one way. Have them become an ally, resurrect, flee,  or fight from shadows
#dnd tip: try having minions at paragon and above deal their level in damage.
#dnd tip: Keep a card for each of your players with their playstyle, goals, and your plans to keep them engaged.
#dnd tip: Be creative and run a battle or two without maps or minis for a random encounter or two.
#dnd tip: Combat is a poor failure condition for a skill challenge. It can add an extra hour to your normal game. Take surges instead.
#dnd tip: bring out minions in waves of four to reduce the effectiveness of blasts. The cleric's Solar Wrath is devastating to minions.
#dnd tip: Keep Dungeon Tiles separated by set to make it easy to find the pieces you need.
#dnd tip: want a movie with a great D&D-style storyline? Try Carpenter's "Prince of Darkness". The scariest villains are often unseen.
#dnd tip: Playing a high-level one-shot? Consider eliminating paragon paths and epic destinies to streamline and balance the character.
#dnd tip: Always try to run your party through four or five combats before they get a full rest or they'll power through things too often.
#dnd tip: use sticky notes to post elite templates or modified hp / damage house rules right next to the stat block in your MM or adventure.
#dnd tip: consider offering to update the character sheets of your players using the Character Builder. Gives you am idea of their powers.
#dnd tip: Don't forget that monsters can take minor actions instead of move actions. Solos and Elites may make up to three attacks a round.
#dnd tip: The Players Handbook 2 character backgrounds are a great way for non-roleplayers to get into their characters past.
#dnd tip: use roleplaying and theatrics to lighten up dull moments in battles.
#dnd tip: from @chattyDM; run eight session "Seasonal Campaigns" to let your players try out new classes and races.
#dnd tip: from reader Luke; maximize player and monster damage to speed up combat quite a bit with fewer rounds and fewer rolls.
#dnd tip: Don't be a slave to a creature's published hit points. If a battle is dragging, give the party a critical kill.
#dnd tip: Keep careful track of your monsters' immediate abilities, especially death-based instants. Write a note where you track their HPs.
#dnd tip: don't be shy to talk in voices. Have fun with it. There us no ego in D&D (except those dwarves).
#dnd tip: Use house rules you can enforce on the DM side of the screen so players aren't jerked around by your new strange rules.
#dnd tip: Mix your dungeon tiles and dwarven forge together. Place the flat tiles within dwarven forge rooms for added detail.
#dnd tip: Good tips for challenging your powergamer / tactical players:
#dnd tip: Read up on future modules and Introduce major npcs from those modules early in your campaign.
#dnd tip: tweak your boss monster to challenge your party by replacing powers or adding alternate abilities. Check Open Grave, page 220.
#dnd tip: Need some quick PCs for a one shot or dungeon delve? Use the DMG rules for NPC creation for limited PCs.
#dnd tip: The PHB2 and Forgotten Realms "backgrounds" work well for NPCs and bad guys as well as PCs. Use them for a quick NPC seed.
#dnd tip: soak notes in coffee to give them an aged look.
#dnd tip: Remember that monsters can use multiple minor powers in a round - even the same power - if it isn't a "once per round" ability.
#dnd tip: watch your players to get a feel for their excitement and boredom. Figure out what they like and hate.
#dnd tip: set up your battles and try a few rounds out solo to get a feel for the battlefield before the big game.
#dnd tip: have your players tell you one "secret" that their PCs are keeping from the rest. Sometimes you need to add a little drama.
#dnd tip: Dwarven Forge's strength is in 3D environments. Use platforms and multi-levels. Build upwards!
#dnd tip: Screen grab and paste monster statblocks from the compendium into a horizontal Word document to build your own encounter sheet.
#dnd tip: Bax the Dragonborn in the Thunderspire adventure can make for a great redemption story arc. Use him but not for combat.
#dnd tip: sometimes you might tell a NPC's backstory even after their dead. Maybe thinking with a shield bash was a hasty choice.
#dnd tip: *trollhaunt spoiler* Let players plan their defense of Moonstair. Make it their Helm's Deep.
#dnd tip: use the backgrounds in the Eberron PHB as story seeds for your campaign or backgrounds for your npcs.
#dnd tip: Want to speed up a game or miss the 3.5 swing? Add a "double damage on critical" house rule.
#dnd tip: watch your players to get a feel for their excitement and boredom. Figure out what they like and hate.
#dnd tip: Use house rules you can enforce on the DM side of the screen so players aren't jerked around by your new strange rules.
#dnd tip: Want more roleplaying in your combat-focused 4e game? Add it TO the combat! Banter between combatants, skill challenges, etc.
#dnd tip: Give physical props to your players as a larping gateway drug.
#dnd tip: You can scale Dungeon Delves up to 4 levels above or below your party's level. That's nine adventures for nearly any level.
#dnd tip: Players spending too much time twittering or texting at the table? Ask yourself what you can do to draw them back into the game.
#dnd tip: catagorize and store minis based on the numbers you have. Mix orcs and gnolls if they aren't that numerous.
#dnd tip: set up your battles and try a few rounds out solo to get a feel for the battlefield before the big game.
#dnd tip: Have a rules lawyer at the table? Make his or position official as a rules moderator. Make sure they are objective, though.
#dnd tip: Remember that power gamers are a legitimate player type. Make the game exciting for them with detaled and interesting encounters.
#dnd tip: Draw your power gamer in with an intelligent item that grants nice bonuses with the right roleplaying.
#dnd tip: Write your own flavor text. Keep it short and make it heroic or epic.
#dnd tip: turn your character into a deck by using hard card sleeves with the character and power cards from the Builder.
#dnd tip: add some normal skirmishers two or three rounds into your big solo battle.
#dnd tip: tape or paste the errata update to difficulty check scores per level to your DM screen. It's a valuable aid.
#dnd tip: try running random encounters without a battle map. Just use descriptions. Mix them with skill challenges.
#dnd tip: little cut out circles of red construction paper make great pools of blood to decorate the battlefield during an encounter.
#dnd tip: Dungeoncraft essays by Ray Winninger recommended by Mike Mearls:
#dnd tip: send email to specific players to give them info only their character knows. Be careful not to drive a wedge between them, though.
#dnd tip: awesome tip of using a double dog dish as a dice roller from @unclebear :
#dnd tip: Run some encounters as flashbacks or dream sequences to show instead of tell the background of the story. Don't overdo it.
#dnd tip: Run some encounters as flashbacks or dream sequences to show instead of tell the background of the story. Don't overdo it.
#dnd tip: Run some encounters as flashbacks or dream sequences to show instead of tell the background of the story. Don't overdo it.
#dnd tip: Run some encounters as flashbacks or dream sequences to show instead of tell the background of the story. Don't overdo it.
#dnd tip: for a powerful party, use terrain effects that don't affect monsters. It's an experience-budget-free way to increase challenge.
#dnd tip: Everyone in Eberron has been affected by the Last War. Everyone knows someone who died. How will that play into your PCs and NPCs?
#dnd tip: Why do your bad guys think they are right? What makes them heroes in their own eyes?
#dnd tip: Take a minute to review the monsters in your next encounter just before running it. Any auras or immediates to remember?
#dnd tip: Precision dice may sound cool and the Col sure is a great salesman, but the ink runs and round-edged dice play just fine.
#dnd tip: Use changing environments to really spice up a battle. Did that fire elemental open a pool of molten rock? Will the walls burn?
#dnd tip: Watch Indiana Jones or Maltise Falcon to get in your Eberron mind-set. Think high adventure!
#dnd tip: Bosses dying too fast? What if they are immortal except if their orbs of power are broken?
#dnd tip: The gargantuan blue dragon mini works well as a Tarrasque.
#dnd tip: Stunning a paladin is a good way to break off his or her divine challenge. This can be critical for solo creatures.
#dnd tip: Reuse old battle maps from published adventures by changing the monsters and the environmental effects.
#dnd tip: The straight dracolich in MM1 is probably too stun-heavy for a good time. Consider the dracolich alts in Open Grave instead.
#dnd tip: War devil minis can stand in for many other demon and devil minis. They're a good universal winged red nasty.
#dnd tip: Write out your treasure parcels on sticky notes you can paste right into your adventure books.
#dnd tip: If you're too shy or embarrassed to "use the voices", try roleplaying in the third person. It's not quite as odd.
#dnd tip: think early about where each character's epic destiny may lie. Where is their path taking them?
#dnd tip: Who will be the Belloq (of Raiders of the Lost Ark fame) in your Eberron campaign. Nothing builds a good story like a good rival.
#dnd tip: always consider what environmental effect you can add to an encounter room.
#dnd tip: not everything needs to be a skill challenge. Sometimes all you need is a series of skill checks.
#dnd tip: Everything in Eberron is fantastic. Towers so vast they have weather within them. Bridges that span drops beyond sight. Fantastic.
#dnd tip: What motivations guide the drive of a thousand year old lich? What would such a creature want? Consider age with motive.
#dnd tip: Use Asmor's treasure parcel generator to build out a level's worth of treasure ahead of time:
#dnd tip: Not every battle has to be in wide open rooms. Consider a series of cramped hallways as a single encounter.
#dnd tip: Build encounters based on your favorite action scenes. Think "House of Blue Leaves" from Kill Bill.
#dnd tip: Always ask your players if they're having a good time but also watch their body language during the game.
#dnd tip: Think of ways to run your game like a three-ring circus. Give them more to see than they can handle and they'll stay engaged.
#dnd tip: Good list of retired heroes called back to action - great background ideas for NPC heroes or villains:
#dnd tip: Add statues, gargoyles, columns, mirrors, and other objects that don't actually do anything just to throw off your players.
#dnd tip: The key to keeping a beholder dangerous is keeping everyone within 5 for the aura. Have him float four squares above the party.
#dnd tip: found a great zombie tile graphic to use for zombie hordes like those found in Demon Queen's Enclave:
#dnd tip: For storing Dwarven Forge pieces, try the Sterlite 7 Drawer craft cart for $30. Holds 6 sets per cart.
#dnd tip: The gargantuan ancient black dragon miniature works well as the main boss Nightwyrm Fortress.
#dnd tip: Print monsters on 5x8 cards using the Monster Builder. They look far better than the scaled images. It's like a monster deck!
#dnd tip: What interesting plot motives do each of Demogorgon's heads have? Surely they conflict. He's a one-character plot twist!
#dnd tip: Mix slaughter wights and bodaks for a devastating weaken to death gaze attack combination. Take that, powergamers!
#dnd tip: Use magic items and treasure as keys or other plot hooks into the rest of your story. Who will hunt the party down for that loot?
#dnd tip: You only get one chance to do a particular scene right. Blow it and you can never try it again. Prepare, prepare, prepare!
#dnd tip: Be wary of high level soldiers. Missing all the time steals the fun away from players. High level brutes are more rewarding.
#dnd tip: Boneclaws work best when they're using their substantial OA effects on ranged and  casters. Against defenders, they're not useful.
#dnd tip: Even for your two or three encounter nightly game, think about the story hook for that game. Think of it as a TV episode.
#dnd tip: Here's my current favorite initiative and condition tracking system. It's almost free!
#dnd tip: Hazardous zones are only useful to your monsters if they can push and pull. PCs have lots of ways to move enemies. Monsters don't.
#dnd tip: Players not paying attention at the game? Find ways to draw them back in without being pushy or confrontational. It's all for fun.
#dnd tip: Tie back to a character's background at least once every five games. Ask yourself how you can tie to the player's creative work.
#dnd tip: from @chattydm. Stop being self consious and just go for it. Apparently alcohol can help.
#dnd tip: Choose and suggest movies for your players to watch to get into the mood of your campaign. Is yours Harry Potter or The Fountain?
#dnd tip: Rolling attacks and damage isn't always faster. Sometimes it's easier and faster for a player to take a step at a time.
#dnd tip: Have trouble beginning your game? Write down a short, strong, and powerful introductory sentence: "Your friend, Hodar, is dead"
#dnd tip: Create a Diablo-style loot pinata by crying out loud and throwing 3x5 treasure item cards into the air when your boss dies.
#dnd tip: Always be on the lookout for a good prop. Antique shops, party stores, and dollar stores have great selections of crazy things.
#dnd tip: Skim through the DMG every month or so to refresh your ideas and get you thinking about how to improve your game.
#dnd tip: modify the traps on page 87-93 of the DMG by changing targets, elements, or effects.
#dnd tip: Consider your villain's dialog carefully. A misplaced word can mean the difference between being sinister and being silly.
#dnd tip: Running an encounter on a ship or airship? Have the rocking of the boat push and pull the combatants as an environmental effect.
#dnd tip: Use a good word processing program to make good-looking quest cards with pictures and clear quest motivations.
#dnd tip: Clear quest goals help tie your players to the story. Don't put too many twists into them. Players want to feel in control.
#dnd tip: What is your adventure's soundtrack? Listen to your old tunes while dreaming your adventure like Tarrantino:
#dnd tip: When using +1 tokens as motivators for fast rounds, let them trade them to another player when needed.
#dnd tip: Three battles taking too much time? Drop it to two battles with some leisure time for skill challenges and roleplaying.
#dnd tip: Order food and have it ready before the game begins. Interrupting a game for food can take up valuable time.
#dnd tip: Customize your skill challenges to make them personal for the characters. Use them to aid in background creation and char plots.
#dnd tip: Give bosses a way to control environments. Fire elementals may leave trails of molten rock or giants may crush walls.
#dnd tip: Be careful of making the black dragon's dark cloud too cheesy. Think of it as an offensive tool, not a defensive one.
#dnd tip: Use elemental miniatures as flame effects for your battle maps. They look great.
#dnd tip: For a buck, the cultist miniature in Legendary Evils is a great generic spellcaster.
#dnd tip: Let your players play dominated characters. Just ensure they act as their master wishes. Some players really love this chance.
#dnd tip: Add two monsters for every character you have in an encounter above five. One monster isn't enough to push the battle difficulty.
#dnd tip: On a Mac, Shift Control Command 4 lets you screengrab the monster stat block from the monster builder or the D&D compendium.
#dnd tip: Use twine to tie scroll props. It makes them look authentic.
#dnd tip: Use authentic images from the internet for handouts. Aztec sacrifical artwork makes for great creepy findings in an ancient tomb.
#dnd tip: Travel lite to your game. You probably only need your character sheet and a PHB. Don't bother grabbing all those books.
#dnd tip: A subscription to D&D Insider can save you a lot of money if you don't buy all the books. Who really needs every "power" book?
#dnd tip: Ensure your players are paying attention during the character's turn right before them. Let them preroll their attack and damage.
#dnd tip: Buy cheap $2 whiteboards for your players. Have them write attack and damage for the DM on the board and hold it up.
#dnd tip: Always keep 3x5 cards handy to give secret notes to players.
#dnd tip: Secretly let a player know they're dominated. Hand out multiple notes to make it impossible to tell who.
#dnd tip: Work on your dynamic voice projection. Nothing can steal a game's energy than a mumbling DM.
#dnd tip: Take a few minutes at the beginning of some sessions to talk about the player group and what bonds them together.
#dnd tip: Be like @wilw. Come up with your own Oath of Enmity whether it be authentic elven or a cutting dwarven insult.
#dnd tip: think about the forked decisions you'll offer in upcoming games. Forks are the middle ground between sandboxes and rails.
#dnd tip: Roll for skill checks often, even if you have a story element you plan on just  telling to the party. Don't just give it to them.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid in the epic tier to make big changes or as quoted from the high level talk "Go ahead and blow up Vulcan."
#dnd tip: Use a few 3x5 cards, one for each scene, with talking points and decision trees for your night's adventure.
#dnd tip: Don't always put all your monsters out at once. Put them out in waves. Don't hesitate to attack from behind or ambush a campfire.
#dnd tip: Firegiant miniatures work very well for enlarged Duergar.
#dnd tip: it's a good time to find props for your game at the local party store with Halloween coming. Prices are best after Oct 31 however.
#dnd tip: Try to maintain a relaxed and neutral DM style. Save your emotion for your NPCs.
#dnd tip: Remind players that immediate actions of their PCs require their attention off of their turn. Don't remind them if they miss it.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to call a battle early, but do so in game terms. Turn them into minions or have them flee or escape.
#dnd tip: Don't tell players  if you make something easier or harder on the fly. Don't tell them you did it even afterwards.
#dnd tip: give your party a nice tricky riddle-based puzzle when you have to go pee.
#dnd tip: Get your game table fully prepped before your players show up to save time.
#dnd tip: Let people take a quick break before your third encounter. We call it the "second encounter stretch". yaaawwwnnn.
#dnd tip: You don't need a million dice at your table. Four or five of each type is enough. Mix the colors for multiple attacks.
#dnd tip: Outline minor quests for each of your players to keep them engaged in the story.
#dnd tip: Make sure to have significant choices for your players every two or three games. Make them big ones without clear outcomes.
#dnd tip: Consider the game "Mass Effect" for meaningful NPC dialog. It's rare to see a game with such a widespread plotline.
#dnd tip: When running a Demilich, remember the Soul Drain is the primary attack. Damage almost doesn't matter. Keep Soul Draining! #dnd
#dnd tip: Mix open map and dungeon encounters to give your players a variety of battlefields.
#dnd tip: Use minions for your battles without battle maps. They're easier to run without seeing it on the table.
#dnd tip: Have you reviewed your player goal chart today?
#dnd tip: Watch "Fifth Element" to get yourself into the mood and steal some details for Sharn, the City of Towers in Eberron.
#dnd tip: Avoid zone effects that immobilize or stun. They're very sticky and players will often remain stuck for a long time.
#dnd tip: Stagger your action and storytelling in your game. Like "Walker, Texas Ranger", always have a fist fight every 12 minutes.
#dnd tip: Stand up to keep yourself and your players full of energy. Move around and be dynamic at the table.
#dnd tip: Write 3x5 "situational motivator" cards for your players ala "Syndoche, New York". "Your intelligent sword speaks of your death".
#dnd tip: Update your minions with increased damage from the DMG2.
#dnd tip: Let some ongoing damage stack to break through PC resistances. Use sparingly.
#dnd tip: Mix in monsters with varying elemental damage types to avoid complete negation due to resistances.
#dnd tip: When running an epic-level one-shot game, plan for 2 hour battles. It's fun, but the battles are looong.
#dnd tip: Give players a +1 roleplaying bonus for creative insults against your monsters.
#dnd tip: Let PCs and NPCs wrest control of a huge construct or elemental monster with in-combat skill challenges.
#dnd tip: Write out your treasure parcels on a 3x5 card and check them off as you run your adventures.
#dnd tip: Use the "Greater Good" motivation for a PC decision tree. Will they commit a clearly evil act for a greater good?
#dnd tip: Use the "Needs of the Many" decision tree: Will your players save the city or the one NPC they've grown to love?
#dnd tip: Need to make your players cry? Try puppies, deer, penguins, and unicorns. Disney's been exploiting this for 50 years.
#dnd tip: Use the "self sacrifice" decision tree. Will your PCs sacrifice something they love to prevent a great evil?
#dnd tip: On your game table, use a black tablecloth and stick boxes underneath to create a non-level playing area.
#dnd tip: Now is your last chance this season to load up on halloween props and models for your game.
#dnd tip: Ask for your players Epic Destiny choices in the middle of the paragon tier so you can build your story around their choices.
#dnd tip: use these wedding decor lights to light up your Dwarven Forge. From Michael's.
#dnd tip: Have other players choose a PC's surname or nickname. Try to steer away from out-of-character silliness.
#dnd tip: Every adventuring party needs a good party name. Let the group play a few adventures before choosing.
#dnd tip: Always consider what possible terrain powers your encounter might provide. Use the powers on p. 63 of DMG2 as examples.
#dnd tip: For a change, have a monster that can switch between statues of itself placed throughout an encounter area.
#dnd tip: Consider adding a terrain effect when a solo creature becomes bloodied. For example, a red dragon creates lava pits when bloodied.
#dnd tip: Remember that daze, blind, stun, and knocked prone grants combat advantage. Optimize creature mixes to take advantage of this.
#dnd tip: Remember, a good DM is a facilitator for group storytelling. Don't laugh maniacally when a PC turns to stone.
#dnd tip: Use Legos as an alternative to tiles and figures for #DnD.   (via @4E_DnD_DM)
#dnd tip: Set up a buddy system to pair up ADD players with players who pay attention so they can work as a team.
#dnd tip: Promote the adoption of pets but ensure the pet doesn't take up a turn. How about a squirrel familiar that grants +1 perception?
#dnd tip: Ask your players for their character's theme song. A theme song can go a long way to define a character.
#dnd tip: A Shadar-kai bard would definitely look like Iggy Pop. "Search and Destroy" is a good theme song for this character.
#dnd tip: Michael's, the hobby store, has some good miniature accessories during halloween. Look for spider webs and small piles of skulls.
#dnd tip: A level+8 single non-elite makes for an interesting and fast solo battle.
#dnd tip: Buy some spare costume jewelry to act as a lich's phylactery or other magical items. Props are always good.
#dnd tip: Use the "Now or Future?" decision tree: Will your players take an advantage now or take it later?
#dnd tip: Build out a detailed room but don't stage a battle in it. Use it for clues or a skill challenge to make your players paranoid.
#dnd tip: Build your encounter design checklist: monsters, setting, terrain, environmental effects, flavor text, etc.
#dnd tip: Don't push your game beyond your planned time if you finish early. Leave your group hungry for more.
#dnd tip: Finish in the middle of an exciting battle or right at the beginning. Leave your players excited to return.
#dnd tip: If you're going to run a D&D one-shot adventure, seriously consider running it in the heroic tier. Ideally level 3 to 6.
#dnd tip: Give your players a battle or two with lower-level creatures so they can feel truly powerful.
#dnd tip: Ask yourself if you've given each player character a chance to shine recently. Add in encounters focused on each PC.
#dnd tip: Establish and post clear table rules for your D&D game like the rules they have for Craps in Vegas.
#dnd tip: Encourage your players to take camera-phone pics of your game and post them to the net. It helps all of us get better.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to mess with the math a bit in your game. Just try it out behind the screen first.
#dnd tip: Pay special attention to monster auras, immediates, and bloodied reactions. They're very easy to forget.
#dnd tip: Use a black poster board and blue sticky tack for your poster maps so you can just lay them down when needed.
#dnd tip: Buy some tea-lights and wedding chime LED lights at Michael's to light up your Dwarven Forge. They work well with fake cobwebs.
#dnd tip: Use the PCs reputation in their primary city or town as a motivator. Will they hurt their reputation for some quick gains?
#dnd tip: Read a few modules ahead so you can drop seeds in for future plot-lines.
#dnd tip: Give your players a battle where they get to coordinate a defense or attack of a stronghold.
#dnd tip: Encourage the use of a dice-rolling box to prevent d20s from flying all over the room and getting eaten by dogs.
#dnd tip: Jot down a dozen or so NPC names from a baby name book to keep on hand. You don't need a huge list all the time.
#dnd tip: Don't forget about diseases. They're good to keep your players on their toes outside of combat and for failed skill challenges.
#dnd tip: Page 42 DMG limited high damage can make for a suitable end to a failed skill challenge. It's less hated than taking surges.
#dnd tip: Try using a single initiative roll and order for an entire night's worth of encounters.
#dnd tip: not every battle has to be against a perfectly sized group of monsters. Throw out a single elite or pack of roaming minions.
#dnd tip: Use 5x8 cards to print from the Monster Builder and print your room descriptions. They're handy at the table.
#dnd tip: Pick out a theme, even a minor one, for every night's worth of adventure. What is their immediate goal?
#dnd tip: Catch up on your Hitchcock before running an Eberron game: "Man Who Knew too Much" and "North by Northwest" are classics.
#dnd tip: Switch a dracolich's stuns to dazes for most of its attacks except the roar. Players hate stuns. Give him a bloodied nec aura.
#dnd tip: Stop reading so many forums, blogs, and tweets. Go work on making your adventure more fun for your players.
#dnd tip: For fast and furious battles, average out monster damage instead of rolling dice for normal monsters.
#dnd tip: Don't get too caught up in your own storyline - remember this is your players' story, not yours!
#dnd tip: Don't fall to deus-ex machina when your group is captured and held prisoner. Work with the players to find an escape they control.
#dnd tip: Don't plan your campaign further out than the next two adventures. Let the story grow organically from the actions of the PCs.
#dnd tip: Don't bore your friends with tales of your D&D adventure. It's like talking about your child's poopie diapers. No one cares.
#dnd tip: Don't run a solo creature by itself above level 10. At paragon and above, a single solo creature will get destroyed quickly.
#dnd tip: Avoid running skill challenges at the end of your nightly game. Most players want a big battle and quick conclusion.
#dnd tip: Come up with your campaign's "elevator pitch" - a single sentence that describes your story. If you can't it's too complicated.
#dnd tip: Losing the attention of one of your players? Come up with an on-the-spot character hook to reel them back in. Why do THEY care?
#dnd tip: Having trouble bringing your players into your world? Find pop culture references that get them excited or entertain them.
#dnd tip: Find out what fiction your players enjoy reading or watching. Find ways to bring that into the story you're running.
#dnd tip: Describe the components of a trap and let your player talk about how they're going to screw with it.
#dnd tip: Starting your PCs out as agents of an Eberron noble house is a great break from the "you all meet in a bar" PC origin.
#dnd tip: Always check your monsters' aura powers. For some, like Draconic Wraiths, they are the bulk of the monster's cool factor.
#dnd tip: A great character naming resource (via @unclebear)
#dnd tip: Always be careful with betrayal in your game. Some might think its cool, but some may really hate it. Especially PC betrayal.
#dnd tip: DMG2 p 202-203 has a great list of Sigil's notable NPCs with many built in hooks. Use it for character driven Sigil adventures.
#dnd tip: Keep the number of new NPCs you introduce to five or less. Too many and your players will never remember them. Three is preferred.
#dnd tip: Print out Quest and NPC cheat-sheets for your players to make it easy for them to remember who is who and what they need to do.
#dnd tip: Use Mega-Mini's "Dungeon Decor" to spice up your Dwarven Forge setups. Good dungeons are in the details.
#dnd tip: Use household items as physical props in your dungeon. A flower vase with some lights in it quickly becomes a soul-well.
#dnd tip: Focus on developing NPCs rather than stories. Let the story build out from the collisions of your PCs and NPCs.
#dnd tip: Use a PC skill-matrix spreadsheet to keep track of your PCs and their skills and develop challenges based on their choices.
#dnd tip: Consider Stephen King's favorite 10 villains as models for your nastiest NPCs:
#dnd tip: Learn to love page 42 in the DMG and on your DM screen. Use it for ad-hoc challenges or random damage done to or by the PCs.
#dnd tip: Put a dot in your rulebooks next to rules changed with the  WOTC errata. A red dot can tell you which rules are out of date.
#dnd tip: Come up with a theme song for your arch-villains. Get your players used to it so they recognize it before the villain shows up.
#dnd tip: Consider the physical mechanics of traps. How would an ancient spike-trap still work after 10,000 years of neglect?
#dnd tip: Keep track of diseases. They are one of the few mechanics that last after extended rests. Don't forget about them!
#dnd tip: Print monsters from the Monster builder on 5x8 index cards. They print perfectly.
#dnd tip: Treat your artifacts and intelligent items like NPCs. Give them goals, backgrounds, and character arcs.
#dnd tip: Consider all of the character choices in Dragon Age and how they still manage to fit into a linear story. Mimic this in your game.
#dnd tip: Not all game music needs to be instrumental. Don't be afraid to have a bar scene with Lady Gaga's "Poker Face".
#dnd tip: give your players a familiar home base they can return to. It should be comfortable and relaxing like an old pair of shoes.
#dnd tip: James Bond shootouts show great ways to shake up an battle's environment. Consider the sinking building shootout in Casino Royale.
#dnd tip: trading card wallet pages for ring binders can store up to 54 small (1x1, to 4x1) dungeon tiles per page! (via @prax3des)
#dnd tip: Give powerful dragons and other memorable solos the "heroslayer" trait from the Heroslaying Hydra: +2 att, +5 dam vs markers.
#dnd tip: Give dragons a ranged breath weapon that shares their breath refresh. Make it burst 2 within 10. Scare your ranged attackers.
#dnd tip: Get over the idea that you're game is Shakespeare. Think Roadhouse, not Gone with the Wind.
#dnd tip: When putting together adventures or one-shots, farm the encounters in Open grave, Draconomicon 1 & 2, and Dungeon Delve for ideas.
#dnd tip: Give your PCs a home base and return to it often. It gives them a familiar place to put up their feet after their adventures.
#dnd tip: Try to give your players at least one meaningful choice in an adventure with no pre-determined conclusion.
#dnd tip: Too many choices can make the game less enjoyable. Don't overburden your PCs with too many decisions to make.
#dnd tip: Try to get a hold of the D&D Game Day character cards. They're absolutely fabulous for one-shot games.
#dnd tip: Always try to keep beholders within 5 squares of the main force of the PCs. Beholders in small rooms make for formidable allies.
#dnd tip: Storming an evil bar and then defending that bar from an attack can be a good change of pace from dungeon delving.
#dnd tip: Save pictures of fantasy art you really like so you can use it as a handout in future games. Keep a D&D scrap book.
#dnd tip: A good silver or iron dragon miniature can stand-in for many of the metallic dragons. Likewise with bronze dragon minis.
#dnd tip: There are too many powers for any DM to verify. Institute an "audit thy neighbor" policy to ensure people aren't overstepping.
#dnd tip: Skeleton, ghoul, and vampire spawn minis make for great foes from level 1 to 30. Buy a bunch of them.
#dnd tip: Take some time every so often to  consider what the evil masterminds in your campaign are doing right now.
#dnd tip: The excellent Fantastic Terrain in The Planes Below can work well anywhere. It also scales at the heroic, paragon, and epic tiers.
#dnd tip: Always gauge your players' interest in a skill challenge. If they get bored - end it!
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to email descriptions of what else is going on in your campaign world. It doesn't all need to be first person.
#dnd tip: round glass candle holders make for great props for crystal balls and other strange artifacts.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to add 20 levels onto a heroic creature you really enjoyed. The monster builder makes it easy to scale monsters.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to run a single battle on your gaming night. It doesn't always need to be two or three. Leave some time to relax.
#dnd tip: Read or plan ahead and think of some ways to foreshadow the coming of a great evil or a new campaign setting. Foreshadow Dark Sun!
#dnd tip: Design a protective shield around your big elite boss NPC broken only with a skill challenge to slow down his or her death.
#dnd tip: Look for fun moments of cooperative storytelling at all times. If a player blurts out a shift in story, consider working with it.
#dnd tip: Reskin fantastic terrain from the DMG and Planes Below to fit the theme of your encounter.
#dnd tip: Give your epic-level players their own airship or floating island in the Elemental Chaos as a base of operations. Think fantastic!
#dnd tip: Have your players come up with names and backgrounds for their own new weapons.
#dnd tip: Use a mix of player-selected items, story-focused items, random items, and item tokens for loot in your campaign.
#dnd tip: Does a PC have a big moment coming? Try using a music playlist based on that PC selected by that player.
#dnd tip: Give your players a lot of different quests, each with a well-designed quest card so they can keep track of them.
#dnd tip: When using published adventures, don't be afraid to replace NPCs with those already known and loved (or hated) by your PCs.
#dnd tip: Try out a Stephen King style and foretell coming events: "That was the last time you saw your home town before it burned."
#dnd tip: Cross-train your RPG reading with King's "On Writing", Tharps "Creative Habit", and Edwards' "Drawing on the Right Side o/t Brain"
#dnd tip: Take time to customize encounters from published adventures around your players and their strengths.
#dnd tip: Make it easy for players to flank opponents when not using a battle map so they don't feel cheated and want the grid back.
#dnd tip: Be careful of monsters with stun effects. Players hate to miss an entire round of combat. Consider bonus damage, weaken, or daze.
#dnd tip: Have a spymaster NPC on your PC's side that delivers them dossiers on key villains. Helps your players keep track.
#dnd tip: Have you checked and updated your Robin Laws player motivation spreadsheet this month?
#dnd tip: Try to make every battle important. Don't have a battle that's just filler especially if time is limited.
#dnd tip: Make it easy for absent players to come back or they won't come back at all. Give them some exp while they were away.
#dnd tip: Game cancelled because of snow? Email your players for short RP stories on their character's activities.
#dnd tip: When running in a set gameworld, make sure that world's key differentiators are often seen.
#dnd tip: Encourage the use of ad-hoc terrain powers by using DMG p. 42 high-limited damage and only requiring a minor action to use.
#dnd tip: Hitchcock movies make great seeds for adventures. Check out The Birds, Notorious, Man Who Knew Too Much, and Rear Window.
#dnd tip: Keep your narration short. Mix it up with skill checks and combat whenever possible to keep people involved.
#dnd tip: Google Image Search, Elfwood, and Deviantart are all great places to dig up fantasy artwork for your campaign and characters.
#dnd tip: Give solos an extra standard action each turn to make them even more threatening.
#dnd tip: Check out @newbieDM's awesome video for building 3d terrain with dungeon tiles:
#dnd tip: For a great campaign idea ask yourself, "What if Galadriel had taken the ring of power?"
#dnd tip: Use the Nycademon's grab and fly power to drag tasty soft-armored wizards and strikers high up into the air - and them drop them!
#dnd tip: The battle at Balin's Tomb in Lord of the Rings makes a great two-battle encounter: dozens of minions and then a solo cave troll.
#dnd tip: Let your players build out their own fortress of solitude. Change it or upgrade it each tier.
#dnd tip: In RPGs, Rule of Cool trumps all rules. If a player wants to do something awesome, make the rules work (via @chattydm)
#dnd tip: Give quests to your villains. It makes them come to life in your story when they have motion and motivation.
#dnd tip: Remain open minded when running skill challenges. Default to letting your players DO things rather than limiting them.
#dnd tip: Want a brutal battle? Set up an encounter under the effect of the Weeping Lady (Underdark pg. 64) +1/2 level damage, 1/2 healing.
#dnd tip: Ask yourself if you're being biased at all towards one of your players or another. Try to remain even headed at all times.
#dnd tip: Give surprise rounds as rewards for successful skill challenges. Give them to monsters on failures.
#dnd tip: Be specific when roleplaying. Write down key notes for any NPC you're going to step into. Goals and attitudes are key.
#dnd tip: The soundtracks to Battlestar Galactica make for some great heart-racing D&D music. Check it out on iTunes.
#dnd tip: Give players plenty of opportunities to use the character features they like the best. Don't eliminate them very often.
#dnd tip: The perception of choice is often as fun as a real choice itself. Just don't tip your hand.
#dnd tip: Let your players fill out their fortress of solitude with cool "Wonderous Lair" items from the Adventurer's Vault 2.
#dnd tip: Ask yourself if the environment you set up for an encounter is fun for the players. It shouldn't just be a detriment to them.
#dnd tip: Let your players decide their PC's fate at the end of a campaign. You might even promote play-by-email continuations.
#dnd tip: Spend some time making sure your bosses will work the way you want. Don't just grab them from the Monster Manual without tuning.
#dnd tip: Want a nasty undead beast like the old level-drainers? Give them a disease on hit that stacks -2s to attack each failure.
#dnd tip: Use email as a method to run quests for individual PCs.
#dnd tip: If you can find them, Deathcap and Arcane Ballista miniatures can make for some great environmentals / terrain power pieces.
#dnd tip: Don't try to force your game to be a certain way. If you're group is out for a laughing good time, make it so.
#dnd tip: You don't have to use D&D minis. Wacraft minis and McFarlane Toys can work just fine in many circumstances.
#dnd tip: Every magic weapon should have a cool name and at least a sentence or two of background. Where did it come from?
#dnd tip: Powerful Solos should have some interesting effect when they become bloodied. Earthquakes, avalanches, or tidal waves of fire!
#dnd tip: Making an enounter more WoW-like isn't always a bad thing. A lot of designers spent time on those battles.
#dnd tip: Think about conversation trees in your roleplaying ala Mass Effect 2. How can conversations fork your storyline?
#dnd tip: Don't force skill challenges and roleplaying. Sometimes your group just wants to fight!
#dnd tip: Stay on your feet to keep your game energetic. It will keep you awake and keep your roleplaying interesting.
#dnd tip: Spread status effect attacks across your players. Don't "immobilize" the same player over and over even if it makes sense.
#dnd tip: Always add something exciting to your terrain that your players will WANT to mess with. Don't make it all bad for them.
#dnd tip: Try using Living Forgotten Realms cards in your home campaign as extra rewards.
#dnd tip: Did your monsters hear the PCs coming? Give them a round of readied actions!
#dnd tip: Use room positioning as a reward for a skill challenge. Give your PCs the high ground if they succeed or at a disadvantage if not.
#dnd tip: Give your beholder a swiss-cheese room where they can travel through tunnels in any direction. Got this from @davethegame.
#dnd tip: Give battles alternative objectives to simple killing. Assassinations, number of rounds before exploding, rescues, etc.
#dnd tip: For some wacky fun, make combats more like skill challenges and skill challenges more like combat.
#dnd tip: Sometimes it helps to write your own unseen background stories. What actually happened 500,000 years ago in that tomb? #dnd
#dnd tip: Introduce your campaign villain at level one. Have Orcus show up in a town and wreak havoc! Revenge is a great motivator.
#dnd tip: Give certain monsters a penetration ability to burrow through resistances once they've seen it in action. Reverse "variable" res.
#dnd tip: Give solos a lot of environmental effects they can manipulate.
#dnd tip: Try an encounter with invulnerable minions until a challenge has been passed.
#dnd tip: Give a monster a grab-and-toss ability to make use of interesting environmental effects.
#dnd tip: Try giving a +3 bonus when four PCs have a single creature flanked. It makes them fight hard for positioning.
#dnd tip: Pay attention to choke points in your battle space. They can be challenging or totally boring if mis-used.
#dnd tip: Don't forget - D&D isn't about fun, this is about killing PCs. If you haven't killed at least three PCs last month, you failed.
#dnd tip: Promote ad-hoc environmental powers using page 42. Make env powers trigger with minor actions so players will use them.
#dnd tip: Have fun with surprise burrowing creatures popping up in the middle of a party, sending them scrambling.
#dnd tip: Ranged minions can be far more dangerous than melee minions.
#dnd tip: If a player comes up with a plot twist, try to jump on it and make it part of the story. Let the story grow organically.
#dnd tip: Change minion elemental damage with normal damage or it will often be fully resisted.
#dnd tip: Use the Death Dealer critical hit tables (or make your own) as an environmental effect similar to Blood Rock.
#dnd tip: Want a quick skirmish battle that goes fast? Use fewer monsters but up their damage by +5 per tier.
#dnd tip: Want a quick skirmish battle that goes fast? Use fewer monsters but up their damage by +5 per tier.
#dnd tip: Think about how your monsters got into the environment. Can a pack of kobolds live sealed in a dungeon for 1000 years? How?
#dnd tip: Inverse of yesterday's tip, ignore how monsters got into a place and have fun with a true Gygaxian dungeon experience!
#dnd tip: Think about how the mechanics of your trap skill challenges work. Sit down and design it, don't just hand-wave it.
#dnd tip: Defeat doesn't always mean death. Have defeated monsters turn into conversational NPCs.
#dnd tip: Set up some achievements for your gaming group. Who did the most total damage? Most single-target damage? Who took the most?
#dnd tip: For a really challenging battle, don't allow a short rest between two fights. Put your PCs against the wall!
#dnd tip: Focus your creative time on making your next session really cool. Don't spend too much on the long range plan of your campaign.
#dnd tip: Start your adventures with a bit of action. Too much storytelling and skill challenging up front might put people to sleep.
#dnd tip: Come up with an environmental power to do high damage to solos at a cost if you want to speed up a solo battle.
#dnd tip: Get your NPC character models from everywhere. Sons of Anarchy, Deadwood, Breaking Bad, Dexter, they can all work!
#dnd tip: The chase can make for a great fun skill challenge. Just ensure you make the details clear.
#dnd tip: Have each player pick a theme song. When  that song comes up on your playlist, they get a free standard action on their next turn.
#dnd tip: Have a cool movie clip that sets the stage or atmosphere for your campaign or adventure? Show it but keep it short.
#dnd tip: For an extra challenge, put unholy relics in a room that prevent the use of healing surges until defeated with a skill challenge.
#dnd tip: If you're playing an old module or adventure, double-check those DCs to ensure they're in line with recent errata.
#dnd tip: Use @newbiedm's list of @wizards_dnd #dndenc effects in your own game with a random roll:
#dnd tip: Don't forget about lightning effects. Make darkness an effect that matters!
#dnd tip: Write up and email some short flash fiction to show what happened to minor NPCs the party encountered.
#dnd tip: use plastic sheet protectors for your one-shot char sheets so you can use them again.
#dnd tip: keep a dungeon delve, tiles, pregens, and minis ready in case you have a spontaneous game.
#dnd tip: keep your one-shots below level ten to keep the game a little simpler.
#dnd tip: run a one-shot game with PHB3 classes so your players can try out the new classes -
#dnd tip: Watch out for solos more than 2 levels higher than the party. They're going to be a slogfest unless you prepare for it.
#dnd tip: The huge Chain Golem makes a great mini for Codricuhn, the Blood Storm:
#dnd tip: Keep your D&D Dungeon Tiles (in separate ziploc bags so you can pull from each set independently.
#dnd tip: Start your adventures with a bit of action. Too much storytelling and skill challenging up front might put people to sleep.
#dnd tip: Today's errata didn't nerf a minion's ability to aid an attack. Stack four minions on someone to give a boss +8 to attack!
#dnd tip: take a red marker and mark anything in your books that's been errata'd in the updates.
#dnd tip: Want to beef up your powerful solo? Turn all of its actions into minor actions to give them more powerful attacks per round.
#dnd tip: If you're having trouble getting people excited about skill challenges, try using them during combat to change the encounter.
#dnd tip: Small poker chips can work as monster tokens in a pinch. Get three colors and write on them with a marker.
#dnd tip: Use random #dndenc encounter alterations in your own home game.
#dnd tip: Try using the detective-show crime investigative trope as a campaign path.
#dnd tip: Playing Eberron? Give your PCs a choice of being mercenaries, investigators, or artifact hunters.
#dnd tip: Here's an awesome story title generator, great for adventure ideas:
#dnd tip: Defending an area can make for a fun multi-battle encounter. Give the PCs a chance to build up their defenses.
#dnd tip: Have a ballroom battle? Use a crashing chandelier as an encounter power: level+3 vs reflex; medium limited damage and knock prone.
#dnd tip: Have players roll skill checks off of their turn to discover bits of information during a battle and keep them involved.
#dnd tip: For a more dangerous beholder, don't count the eyestalk aura as an attack when determining mark penalties.
#dnd tip: Get the required components for your next game done early so you have time for your creative juices to flow into it.
#dnd tip: avoid the "destiny" plot motivator. It's no fun to think you have no control over the outcome.
#dnd tip: avoid deus ex machina when introducing gods into your game. The players should still be the center of the story.
#dnd tip: Save the ink and use a computer or tablet to display DDI adventures. The ink cost alone  makes an adventure about $10.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to modify a monster to fit your party's experience level. Avoid making epic beasts too easy though.
#dnd tip: Dig into your Lovecraft to pick up strange and interesting ways to describe the Far Realm:
#dnd tip: things going slow during your RP \ skill challenge? Keep things moving by throwing out items of interest.
#dnd tip: Use psionic powers from PHB3 as monster abilities to recreate the psionic abilities of old-school D&D monsters.
#dnd tip: Give some off-camera background stories in email to give your players a wider view of their story.
#dnd tip: Write and keep a checklist of the things you need to put together a night's game. Check it two days before your game.
#dnd tip: When making an NPC or villain, sit back, close your eyes, and imagine what he or she is seeing and feeling.
#dnd tip: Scale environmental effect damage by 5 damage per tier. An epic pool of lava should do 15 damage when someone steps in it.
#dnd tip: Write short stories in email showing your players the unseen worldly and NPC reactions of their actions.
#dnd tip: What makes your villain think they're actually a good guy? What good do they believe they are doing?
#dnd tip: Model your fantasy towns and cities after the economics of real medieval castles and cities.
#dnd tip: Start your Eberron campaign off right by making your PCs choose one of three houses to ally with.
#dnd tip: Fire giant minis work well for death giants, animated statues, and enlarged Duergar in a pinch.
#dnd tip: McFarlane toys and WoW minis work well for monstrous D&D miniatures:
#dnd tip: Don't forget to have loot and experience ready to hand out at the end of your game. It's sadly easy to forget.
#dnd tip: Forget experience points. Level PCs on the adventures met, the quests completed, and the encounters defeated.
#dnd tip: Instead of random one-shots, build one-shots that fill out a piece of the main campaign story as yet untold.
#dnd tip: Treat Demogorgon as two different and often competing NPCs instead of as a single entity.
#dnd tip: War devils can be used as Pit Fiends if you don't want to pay the high price:
#dnd tip: Designate your table's rules lawyer as the official rules arbiter, but only if he or she is fair as well as annoying.
#dnd tip: Damaging auras are a great way to power up weaksause Solos. Try 5 dam per tier scaling  to 10 per tier when bloodied.
#dnd tip: Philip Seymour Hoffman's character in Mission Impossible 3 makes for a great sinister villain archetype.
#dnd tip: Consider James Bond-style introductions - prefaces full of action that might only be superfluously related to the story.
#dnd tip: Always give the players a chance for success even if a villainous NPC succeeds in a plot. Players hate losing and wasting time.
#dnd tip: Even if you dont use the card-over-the-screen trick, 3x5 cards folded in half work well for a fully-visible initiative order.
#dnd tip: Watch the show Breaking Bad for ideas in character development, organic plotlines, and off-stage storytelling.
#dnd tip: Remember that skill challenges fall between using regular skill checks and full-roleplaying sessions. Don't overuse them.
#dnd tip: Take a specific approach when building skill challenges. Disarming an doomsday trap is more specific than exploring caverns.
#dnd tip: When characters fall off of high places, consider different repercussions than falling to their death. Catch footing after 5d10?
#dnd tip: Remember not to run a monster more than 4 levels higher than your PCs. They might still win but it will take hours.
#dnd tip: When customizing monsters, think about what makes that monster unique. Example; vampires have dominate, enervate, transformations.
#dnd tip: Watch out for too many dazes and weakens - they generally just slow down a battle.
#dnd tip: If a player looks bored, ask them to roll a skill check to learn something interesting.
#dnd tip: Even if monster identification skills take an action, have the players roll them off-turn while someone else is up. Saves time.
#dnd tip: Stuck trying to make a map? Use one of the delve maps from Dungeon Delve, Planes Below, or Planes Above with different monsters.
#dnd tip: Pipe cleaners and Alea Tools magnets don't play nice together. Stick to bottle rings for marks and conditions.
#dnd tip: Githyanki are all about the psionics. Find lots of ways to show how this type of power is different from arcane magic.
#dnd tip: The purple worm mini can work well for the Hundred-Hands abhorrant from Plane Above ( )
#dnd tip: Copy and hand out the last two pages of the #dnd Players Strategy Guide entitled "Don't Be A Jerk" to all of your players.
#dnd tip: If you want a status effect penalty that won't slow the game down, give PCs -4 to defenses instead of -4 to attacks.
#dnd tip: cut-up dark pillow cases work well to cover up your 3D battle maps before the battle.
#dnd tip: Resking Forsaken from the Monster Manual 3 ( ) into high-level vampires.
#dnd tip: The time to worry about how long your game is running is during the first battle, not the last battle.
#dnd tip: The Thunderblast Cyclone miniature can be useful for environmental effects too:
#dnd tip: The white gargantuan dragon works well for a wraith dragon or a dracolich.
#dnd tip: Let two of your players roll their attacks at the same time to speed things along.
#dnd tip: Use statistics from equally leveled Monster Manual 3 creatures to recalculate stats for older monsters.
#dnd tip: Have players write action types and triggers with a big marker at the top of their power cards so they don't forget.
#dnd tip: Use unhallowed ground as Fantastic Terrain that removes undead radiant vulnerability until it is blessed with religion checks.
#dnd tip: Give players a status effect choice: Shake off stuns but take 20 damage? Break immobilize but take ongoing 15? Hard choices!
#dnd tip: Want a minion with some survivability? Try making minion swarms immune to everything but bursts or blasts.
#dnd tip: Opposite from yesterday: Try making an armored minion that can ONLY be hit by direct attacks.
#dnd tip: use MM3 solos as a model for older ones. What do they do differently when they're bloodied?
#dnd tip: 5 damage per tier is a good basic building block for damaging terrain effects. Keep it with your page 42 charts.
#dnd tip: Need a fictional character archetype for your crazy drunken dwarf? Try Calamity Jane from Deadwood.
#dnd tip: Consider the comic book or movie Planet Hulk as a mini campaign idea for Dark Sun:
#dnd tip: Want a monster tougher than the PCs can handle? Double damage output on creatures 5 levels above to show they hit too hard.
#dnd tip: Don't run the standard Dracolich as written. Too much necrotic to resist and too many stuns. Modify or run a later variant.
#dnd tip: Not sure how to end your campaign? You could do far worse than a montage like Six Feet Under:
#dnd tip: If a player looks bored, ask them to roll a skill check to learn something interesting.
#dnd tip: Oreos make great action points but your players will end up using them pretty quick.
#dnd tip: Be careful at level 1. Level 1 characters are very fragile. Don't attempt to challenge them too much too early.
#dnd tip: challenge is inversely proportional to level. Go easy below level 10 and get tough above level 10 to keep the pace right.
#dnd tip: Come up with creative ways to build 3D terrain. You don't HAVE to have dwarven forge. Put tiles up on blocks.
#dnd tip: Always watch your players' reactions to the battle. Are they angry and stressed for the right reasons or the wrong ones?
#dnd tip: Keep a list of your favorite fantastic terrain from the various sourcebooks. The right terrain makes a battle unique.
#dnd tip: The Watchmen soundtrack makes for some great #dnd music. Spice it up with some Dylan if you dare.
#dnd tip: Put one big decision in front of your group each session. Make it matter and don't favor one answer over the other.
#dnd tip: Oldie but goodie: Use sticky tack and black poster boards to build dungeon tile rooms ahead of time.
#dnd tip: Have players roll the recharges on monster powers so the others will blame someone other than you when Orcus kills them.
#dnd tip: Push your players to say when they're "done" at the end of their turn to keep things moving along.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid for a powerful monster to cast bursts or blasts on his own guys in order to hit a lot of players.
#dnd tip: Don't put TOO many environmental effects, fantastic terrain, or environmental powers into one encounter. Three is about the max.
#dnd tip: Watch out for wraiths. Players can really hate them. Use them sparingly.
#dnd tip: The Heroslayer mechanic from the Heroslayer Hydra works well for other monsters. Great way to deal with marks.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to write in the new errata damage amounts into your books and modules. Small-point Sharpies work well.
#dnd tip: Never run a solo alone in a Paragon or Epic game. It will just get ganged up on and destroyed.
#dnd tip: Have your minions explode in a poisonous, acidic, necrotic, blinding gas. Now your players don't really WANT to kill them!
#dnd tip: Above paragon, start asking whether your player is going to interrupt monster actions rather than having to retrofit them in.
#dnd tip: Channel your inner 14 year old when building out your adventures. What sort of stuff did you like back then?
#dnd tip: Give out quests to your group to defeat major villains. Write these up like wanted posters.
#dnd tip: Add fewer bigger dice to make an attack more swingy and lots of little dice to make the cut more accurate.
#dnd tip: With the new monster damage charts, worry less about temp hit points, free healing, or player resists trivializing your monsters.
#dnd tip: Just because all of your monsters are statistically the same doesn't mean your players need to know that. Pretend one's a boss.
#dnd tip: find ways to make the mechanics of your traps clear. Describe how the massive pump draws a torrent of blood into the room.
#dnd tip: Speed up combat with an angry gas. Any creature within it grants combat advantage and vulnerable 5 but gains +1d6 dam per tier.
#dnd tip: Need to challenge your epic-tier party? Send three waves of encounters with no short rests. Change the environment to keep it fun.
#dnd tip: People arguing about the rules of your monsters or environments? Bring them back with in-game flavorful descriptions.
#dnd tip: Don't just call a battle over when it gets long. Have a plan to finish a battle early that makes sense in the story.
#dnd tip: The power of an extra PC above five grows stronger every level. An extra level 26 PC is much more powerful than an extra level 6.
#dnd tip: When running skill challenges, stay loose and relaxed. Gauge the table and modify as needed to keep them fun. Make them yours.
#dnd tip: We all make mistakes when running a D&D game. Relax and move on - we'll all get better every game we run.
#dnd tip: Keep an online "hook journal" for your group so they can keep track of what possible directions they can go as a group.
#dnd tip: Give your players meaningful choices: they can kill the big bad guy or save the maiden but not both. (from @chattydm)
#dnd tip: Don't worry about defining hooks as hooks for your group. Sometimes people want a clearer idea where they can go.
#dnd tip: Let the story guide your skill challenge, not some X / 3 mechanic. Story leads mechanics, not the other way (from @chrisssims)
#dnd tip: Build a dungeon room like Legend of Zelda. Don't be afraid to steal a room DIRECTLY from Zelda. (from @davethegame)
#dnd tip: You could do worse than building your villain or NPC off of the character Godric from True Blood. 2000 year-old vampire loses self
#dnd tip: Add degrees of success and failure on your DC check rolls. You can use the low / med / high chart as degrees of success.
#dnd tip: Adventure seed: PCs investigate a derelict Chaos Ship that has been buried under a town for 100,000 years. Think Tommyknockers.
#dnd tip: Use brothers or twins or a coven of three witches instead of a single boss to avoid a single boss getting ganged up on in combat.
#dnd tip: Halloween stores are beginning to show up. Load up on cheap props and fake spider webbing.
#dnd tip: Be nice to your PCs in Heroic, be even handed with them at Paragon, be a bastard to them in Epic.
#dnd tip: One thing my article on solo monsters forgot: Every solo monster should change somehow when bloodied.
#dnd tip: Inanimate objects that radiate death make great powerful bosses. You can't stun a pillar!
#dnd tip: Build in mechanics and monster powers to scale your encounter difficulty up or down as a battle progresses.
#dnd tip: Want an alternate skill challenge system? Take a look at the Obsidian system:
#dnd tip: If you give your elite or solo a way to shake conditions, make sure it's a "no action" action. This works with stunned and uncon.
#dnd tip: Have dragons use the Chamber of Vulnerability ritual to create vulnerable environmental sections:
#dnd tip: At higher levels, award experience based on effort, not the encounter budget.
#dnd tip: Try to have at least one meaningful choice in every game you run.
#dnd tip: As @davethegame proved, even getting screwed by your HOA can make for a good adventure seed.
#dnd tip: Consider limiting character generation to specific published sources that fit your campaign theme to avoid game-breaking combos.
#dnd tip: Always keep your DM cheat sheet handy at your game:
#dnd tip: All solos above level 11 should have a no-action way to remove status effects or they'll be paralyzed for an entire fight.
#dnd tip: Consider limiting a high-level one-shot game to D&D Essentials only.
#dnd tip: For a break, have your players run a group of your NPCs as they have an adventure related to your main story.
#dnd tip: The Orcus mini also makes for an awesome cultist statue:
#dnd tip: Don't worry too much about tracking status effects on monsters. Players keep very good track of them on their own.
#dnd tip: Design environments that match your heroes's status. Level 15 PCs shouldn't still be hunting down lost farm maids.
#dnd tip: Consider limiting sources for character building in one-shot high level games. Essentials only for example.
#dnd tip: Think about the mechanics of a trap. How does it work and how does it reset itself? How does it still work after 10,000 years?
#dnd tip: Use superhero comic storylines as seeds for epic-tier games. PCs are more like the Justice Leage than the Fellowship now.
#dnd tip: Every monster above level 11 published before the MM3 needs its damage updated using the July update:
#dnd tip: Try having both puzzle and skill-challenge ways to get around a trap. Let players choose the way they get around the trap.
#dnd tip: Surge stealing can get old. Try custom diseases or other penalties to mimic life-draining. 1/2 healing, vulnerable 5, -2 to defs.
#dnd tip: In-battle skill challenges that require PCs be adjacent can help bring them into a room they might be apprehensive of.
#dnd tip: Remember, most of my desires to drop the hammer on PCs comes at paragon and above. Heroic PCs are much more easily killed.
#dnd tip: Give older solos some sort of effect when bloodied. Doubling aura damage is an easy way if not too creative.
#dnd tip: Strimko puzzles with symbols replacing numbers  can make for fun in-game puzzles:
#dnd tip: Keep a notebook on you and jot down ideas for NPCs, encounter areas, story seeds, etc. Good ideas come from everywhere.
#dnd tip: To scare your powergamers, hit them with fearsome status effects: 1/2 healing,  vulnerability 20, scaling ongoing damage
#dnd tip: With Halloween over, it's time to go pick up your fake spider webbing and other props at your local party store!
#dnd tip: When restrained and teleported, the restrain goes away if it was physical but stays on you if it was mental. Rules Comp p 214
#dnd tip: Consider using Essentials-only characters for higher level one-shot adventures.
#dnd tip: Re-skin environmental effects from the Dark Sun Creature Catalog for use in any campaign.
#dnd tip: Steal stories, encounters, and puzzles liberally from your favorite games including Final Fantasy or Dragon Age.
#dnd tip: Let players roll for their treasure using the new treasure rewards in the Rule Compendium.
#dnd tip: Use the old-school feel of Essentials characters to convince your group to try an Essentials-only mini-campaign.
#dnd tip: The Stone Giant miniature in Lords of Madness (an inexpensive uncommon mini) makes a great statue or stone golem as well.
#dnd tip: Do you have your adventure builder checklist in hand before you start building adventures?
#dnd tip: The heroslayer hydra mini might stand in well for a Tiamat aspect.
#dnd tip: Running a high-level one-shot adventure? Try sticking to just #dnd Essentials characters to keep it balanced.
#dnd tip: Customizing a monster? Make sure to add in some choice mechanics. Take 30 damage to remove stun as a free action for example.
#dnd tip: Get your NPC ideas from everywhere. Don't overuse fantasy characters, steal from Mad Men or Sons of Anarchy if you want.
#dnd tip: Don't try to do too much at once in a game. Run fewer awesome encounters instead of many mediocre ones.
#dnd tip: Keep a companion char or two ready at your PC's level in your game just in case @matt_james_rpg doesn't show.
#dnd tip: When designing ancient mechanical traps, remember that big components would last longer than small components.
#dnd tip: Three things to consider with traps: For whom was it originally intended? How did it last all this time? How does it reset?
#dnd tip: Give your magic item vendors a couple of random uncommon items to spice things up.
#dnd tip: Have players group powers by standards, minors, moves, and immediates. Fewer choices = faster turns.
#dnd tip: You can still combine multiple treasure hoards together when using the random treasure tables in the Rules Compendium or DMK.
#dnd tip: Monsters don't scale up too well against level 1 characters. Go easy on them and use monsters no higher than level 2.
#dnd tip: Auras are the best friend of epic-tier solos. Auras ignore status effects completely and rarely require a hit.
#dnd tip: Houserule the beholder's triggered eye attack so that it doesn't trigger defender marks.
#dnd tip: Running E3, Prince of Undeath? Dig up a copy of Throne of Bloodstone and consider thematics from that Orcus focused adventure.
#dnd tip: Try running #gammaworld as a ten session one-level-per-session mini campaign.
#dnd tip: The Ravenloft board game has lots of cool minis to use in your campaign. The wraiths make awesome ice liches.
#dnd tip: Always seek opportunites to add theatric descriptions to fun random events. Describe returns from near death or wild combo attacks
#dnd tip: Pick up the Monster Manual 3 and the Demonomicon for epic-level updated monsters to go along with your Monster Vault.
#dnd tip: The Demonomicon is probably the best book for planning out your epic-tier campaign. It's full of all sorts of nasty stuff.
#dnd tip: When your whole group is doing a bunch of damage at once, assign a player the job of tallying it together and giving the total.
#dnd tip: Add choices to your nastier status effects: Stunned or take ongoing 10 psychic per tier. Immobilized or 2d8+12 dam to rip free.
#dnd tip: Flame snakes and fiendish snakes make for a variety of great monsters. Pick up four of each.
#dnd tip: Need a powerful level 33 Dracolich ? Use the "Dragon of Tyr" stats from the Dark Sun Creature Catalog.
#dnd tip: Can't explain the layers of the Abyss? Watch the multiple-dream layers of Inception for an idea:
#dnd tip: Never fall in love with your monsters and always accept that their destiny is to die.
#dnd tip: Always have a lifeline prepared in case of a TPK. Make failure as interesting as success and you will not fear their deaths.
#dnd tip: Get creative with weapons. "short sword" can be as abstract as the Gamma World "one hand melee" weapon type.
#dnd tip: At level 15+ there's no such thing as a tough boss monster. Protect them with minions and skill challenges.
#dnd tip: After 100 sessions the two biggest speed boosts I found are fully-visible initiative cards and visible monster defenses.
#dnd tip: Planning for two runs against your big boss lets you feel out his or her stats in one battle so you can prep for the other.
#dnd tip: In Gamma World, you can steal NPC types from anywhere. Just roll up their origins to see how weird they might be.
#dnd tip: Always try to give every PC a chance to really shine every couple of adventures or so.
#dnd tip: Of all my adventures, the one people remember the most was the city defense where they got to set up the defenses. Try it.
#dnd tip: If your minis are looking a little warped or weapons are a little bent, use hot and cold water to soften and re-harden them right.
#dnd tip: Think of your game and encounters as a way for players to show off their PCs instead of a way to thwart them. 4e is about the PCs.
#dnd tip: Use published adventures as a loose theme. You don't have to run them rigidly, make them your own and use what works for you.
#dnd tip: Reskin Monster Vault creatures by changing the flavor of their attacks rather than redesigning MM1 and 2 creatures from scratch.
#dnd tip: In case you missed it, use @saveversusdeath's Dungeon Trick Generator to add spice to your encounters:
#dnd tip: Use a sheet of 20x by 30x acrylic from Home Depot to place over your poster maps. It makes a huge difference.
#dnd tip: Tiny amounts of fake spider web you bought last Halloween can also dress up your undead miniatures to make them ghostly.
#dnd tip: Break up large battles into phases that change environmental effects, monster powers, or adds waves of minions.
#dnd tip: Every solo above level 11 should have a way to get past daze and stun effects. Check out the dragons in the Monster Vault.
#dnd tip: Stuck in a boring meeting? Use the time by imagining and jotting down notes for some story seeds or NPC backgrounds.
#dnd tip: Use small in-battle skill challenges to get folks moving and protect your elite or solo bosses from getting killed too quickly.
#dnd tip: Spend some time before your players arrive to arrange all the materials you need to get right down to playing when they arrive.
#dnd tip: Always pick up the cheaper more generic miniatures to fill out your collection. A handfull of orcs goes a long way.
#dnd tip: Want to be a great DM? Be born in 1973 like @chattydm, @newbiedm, and I!
#dnd tip: Print out and prepare quest cards so you can keep your group focused on the directions they want to go.
#dnd tip: Spend less time worrying about @wizards_dnd's business and more time making your own game awesome.
#dnd tip: Pick up some $1 or less Star Wars minis to fill out your Gamma World PC races.
#dnd tip: When running a Gamma World game, assign one of the players the duty of Alpha Mutation and Omega Tech distribution.
#dnd tip: A good paper cutter makes it much easier and neater to cut initiative cards, monster knowledge cards, power cards, and quest cards
#dnd tip: Scale monsters up or down easily by adding +1 per level to all rolls and increasing hitpoints by 10 per level.
#dnd tip: Belloc from Raiders of the Lost Arc is an excellent NPC archetype. He has clear motivation and he's smart! Use him.
#dnd tip: Learn from internet sage @davethegame and re-skin Monster Vault creatures for your Gamma World game.
#dnd tip: Write down the musings of your players and turn those musings into formal quests with quest cards.
#dnd tip: Use Google Maps to get a map of your local area, print it, and write in your own fantastic Gamma World locations for your game.
#dnd tip: Looking for a couple of good inspirational movies? Check out Brotherhood of the Wolf and Name of the Rose.
#dnd tip: Try running an encounter on the back of a great beast. Perhaps a battle on the backs of two dueling dragons!
#dnd tip: Consider giving your pre-Monster Vault solos a free action attack that can instead remove stuns, dazes, or dominates.
#dnd tip: The knocked prone status effect is one of the better ones. It isn't too debilitating but it still makes life more difficult.
#dnd tip: Don't try to make something totally unique every time. Sometimes people just want to fight a room full of orcs.
#dnd tip: Ogremoch from MM3 makes for a great final doomsday sort of boss. Reskin him into whatever world-ending big bad you have in mind.
#dnd tip: You can't go wrong digging into Michael's craft store for all sorts of interesting terrain and props.
#dnd tip: Try giving your solo a terrain-altering effect when it becomes bloodied. Pour out minions or add lava pits or both!
#dnd tip: Add conspiracy groups to your campaign to keep things interesting. Good become evil, evil become good, and PCs in the middle.
#dnd tip: Gnolls and Eladrin from the Monster Vault make for great mid-level Gamma World humanoid monster templates.
#dnd tip: Hand out a list of classes, races, and allowed sourcebooks at the beginning of your campaign to limit complexity. #toomanypowers
#dnd tip: Keep a mobile DM kit in a small ziploc bag like you're a bank robber and this is your emergency geeky walk-away bag.
#dnd tip: A few hours before running a game, go through the whole game in your head step by step to see if anything's missing.
#dnd tip: Always keep your group rolling. If people start to look bored, do some group history or insight checks to reveal story bits.
#dnd tip: Don't take over control of dominated PCs. Let players run the PC in the best interests of the dominator.
#dnd tip: The Tron Legacy soundtrack works well for a Gamma World high-tech soundtrack:
#dnd tip: If you don't have a lot of time to prep an adventure, jot down the important details on 3x5 cards so you remember them.
#dnd tip: Dark Sun is the perfect campaign setting to give characters difficult choices with clear consequences either way.
#dnd tip: Need some powerful Epic-tier dragons? Check out the excellent Prismatic Dragon by @rjschwalb:
#dnd tip: The Beholder Gauth in the Monster Vault can be reskinned into an awesome alien or robotic probe in Gamma World.
#dnd tip: Every good Dark Sun game should begin with blood spraying in the arena.
#dnd tip: Professor Moriarty of Sherlock Holmes might be a perfect villain. Model yours after him:
#dnd tip: The instance bosses from World of Warcraft can be scraped for some pretty fun D&D encounters.
#dnd tip: Powerful villains should have some protection mechanism that can be disabled with skill challenges. Think healing fonts.
#dnd tip: A bit heuristic but go take a 30 minute walk without headphones and just ponder your next great adventure.
#dnd tip: Interesting villains might turn sides and become powerful allies. Leave open the possibility.
#dnd tip: When running a sandbox game, prepare and force decisions at the end of the adventure so you can well prepare the next one.
#dnd tip: There's a gamma world adventure lurking in this Luxury Bomb Shelter infographic:
#dnd tip: A MacGuffin is a great way to get your group focused around an object that, by itself, doesn't really matter.
#dnd tip: Space Hulk would make for a great Gamma World campaign. Explorers break into ancient derelict alien space ships.
#dnd tip: Assign a note-taker to your game and have them offer a summary at the beginning of each game. See what they think is important.
#dnd tip: If a battle doesn't go exactly like you planned, look for the interesting opportunity to let the story move in a new direction.
#dnd tip: From @gregbilsland, pay particular attention to the points of  tension in a battle.
#dnd tip: Highlight or underline the names of NPCs in your notes so you can refer to them easily.
#dnd tip: Assigning monster hit point tracking to a player helps remove the adversarial relationship between players and DMs.
#dnd tip: Be like @gregbilsland and hide die rolls to give you the ability to change the pace and tension of an encounter.
#dnd tip: Be like Chris Perkins and never fudge a die roll. Let the dice guide the story in an unknown direction.
#dnd tip: Wise words from @rjschwalb: "Never tell the players they are in a skill challenge."
#dnd tip: I find the best skill challenges often have the least amount of prep. Don't over-engineer challenges; let them grow naturally.
#dnd tip: Michael Mann's "The Keep" may not be a great movie, but it's a great story for a D&D or Gamma World game!
#dnd tip: try fitting your night's adventure onto a single page of paper. It forces you to stay simple and helps keep your game on track.
#dnd tip: Spend an hour sitting at your table visualizing the game you are about to run. Imagine the game running to see what's missing.
#dnd tip: Standard kobold miniatures and tokens can work well for Dark Sun Gith creatures. Your players will likely be too drunk to tell.
#dnd tip: Have you built some monster knowledge cards for your next game? Add it to your prep checklist:
#dnd tip: Check out the fantastic terrain in the back of the Dark Sun Creature Catalog. It's useful for any game and very well designed.
#dnd tip: Consider inflicting direct damage instead of taking healing surges away in skill challenges. Taking damage isn't as annoying.
#dnd tip: A player recording monster damage frees you up to worry about table management and monster tactics. Makes life much easier.
