#dnd tip: Paperclip your status-effect fold overs to a big card so you can easily pull out the right one.
#dnd tip: The sorcerer kings in the back of the Dark Sun Creature Catalog work very well for paragon and epic bosses. Reskin!
#dnd tip: Whether to kill, capture, or release a defeated foe is always an easy and interesting choice to give players.
#dnd tip: Gang warfare is always an interesting story choice for a Dark Sun campaign set in Tyr. Which gangs are rivals and which allies?
#dnd tip: Sell off your old monster books and stick to the MM3, Monster Vault, Demonomicon, and Dark Sun Creature Catalog.
#dnd tip: When rebuilding monsters, start with the traits that define the monster and build mechanics around those traits.
#dnd tip: The new DM screen's experience reward table makes it very easy to reward effort-based experience.
#dnd tip: in Dark Sun, don't have a generic "cross the desert" challenge. Make it specific like lizard hordes or crossing silt challenges.
#dnd tip: Keep your DM screen handy when prepping adventures for the skill and damage table.
#dnd tip: Reveal the DCs in a skill challenge so players will be more willing to try untrained skills to do things.
#dnd tip: Get yourself in the right mindset for Dark Sun by watching 300 and then picking up the soundtrack for your game.
#dnd tip: Keep your secondary battles fast by using only one monster type and a simple yet powerful environmental effect.
#dnd tip: Add an "out" to every encounter you design. How can the party finish the encounter besides just wiping out all the bad guys?
#dnd tip: Make heavy use of the DCs and Damage Per Level charts in the updated DM Screen. They're extremely valuable tools.
#dnd tip: Give your players choices for their next adventure at the end of your current session. Make them choose before they leave.
#dnd tip: Spend a couple of minutes summarizing the current story at the beginning of your adventure. Use it to turn on "game mode".
#dnd tip: don't reveal your "out" too early. Give your players a chance to discover how a battle works before revealing the victory states.
#dnd tip: A mix of Watchmen, Tron Legacy, 300, and the Social Network soundtracks makes for a great instrumental gaming playlist.
#dnd tip: Follow @rjschwalb's ruling guideline: if it smells like poop, it is probably poop:
#dnd tip: Be like Perkins: Think of a campaign as a TV season, create an episode guide, write one-line future episode summaries.
#dnd tip: Consider spelling out a few potential options for skill challenges to give players ideas of what they can do.
#dnd tip: Don't forget to assign a rules lawyer to the best potential candidate at your table. Knowledgeable and fair are required.
#dnd tip: For fast Gamma World con games, consider writing up some pregen characters. Just do the basics, leave the details to the players.
#dnd tip: Try combining skill checks, combat, roleplaying, puzzles, and physical props into one uber-encounter.
#dnd tip: Instead of just figuring out what your battle environment is, think about what it USED to be to add another layer.
#dnd tip: Add big nasty environmental effects to a single high level elite monster for a nice fast battle.
#dnd tip: In case you missed it, my Monster Makeover: Shademaw the 26th lvl black dragon, is on the #dnd website:
#dnd tip: Sometimes your group just wants to beat the crap out of a bunch of stupid guys. Give them those opportunities.
#dnd tip: A few small focused skill challenges will run better than a big vague one.
#dnd tip: Inherent Bonuses instead of magic items work well for one-shot characters. Give them one awesome item instead of a big pile.
#dnd tip: Think about ways to build your battle map in three dimensions instead of just two.
#dnd tip: In case you missed it, my Monster Makeover: Shademaw the 26th lvl black dragon, is on the #dnd website:
#dnd tip: Pay attention to and mix up which players get hit with which status effects. Being dazed three rounds in a row is no fun.
#dnd tip: Your villains shouldn't be sitting around waiting for your PC's to show up. What evil quests are they working on right now?
#dnd tip: Playing hardcore or #fourthcore? Have players bring spare sheets and sub-in new PCs when old ones die.
#dnd tip: Try designing puzzle encounters that have set goals in set time limits such as "bloody all foes in 30 minutes".
#dnd tip: Try telling your players what the DCs are for skill checks and challenges so they're more willing to use untrained skills.
#dnd tip: Some written flavor text for your nightly adventure intro summary can work nicely for a summary stored in Obsidian Portal.
#dnd tip: Lord Vizier from the Dark Sun Creature Catalog makes for an excellent 26th level Lich.
#dnd tip: When running a Dark Sun game, begin your night's adventure showing their place on the big poster map.
#dnd tip: Go back to the fundamentals. Read "Building Adventures" on page 169 of the Dungeon Master's Book.
#dnd tip: Give a +2 bonus to skill checks and attack rolls for good roleplaying or storytelling. Reinforce good behaviors.
#dnd tip: Take the time to draw a good color map on 1" grid sheets of paper like gaming paper:
#dnd tip: Good humanoid miniatures are always useful in your game. Pick them up before they're all gone!
#dnd tip: Don't stack up a lot of denial effects in a single battle like slows, difficult terrain, dazes, or obscurement. It's frustrating.
#dnd tip: Don't house rule every small broken combo. Instead, find the root cause and house rule those.
#dnd tip: Don't forget to try to keep your house rules over on the DM's side of things so you can tweak without changing PC rules.
#dnd tip: Skill challenges, puzzles, and riddles within an encounter helps keep the attention of your players on the game.
#dnd tip: Did the PCs get routed or forced to run after fighting a foe? Give them a chance for revenge!
#dnd tip: Perhaps its heresy but you might include bronze and iron in the base Dark Sun materials. I can't believe in a stone longsword.
#dnd tip: Mix up outdoor encounters with underground ones. Don't stick them in a dungeon for six months.
#dnd tip: Find out your players' birthdays so you can run a special adventure tuned around them that week.
#dnd tip: Refresh your adventure music playlist every couple of months to keep things fresh. Keep it about 8 hours long for a good mix.
#dnd tip: If you really want to play a monster from the MM1 or MM2, just make sure you increase its damage using the new Damage charts.
#dnd tip: Michael Clayton plot seed: What valuable piece of information do the PCs possess that everyone would kill them to quiet?
#dnd tip: Most solo bosses can be reskinned versions of Monster Vault dragons. Only the free action attack gives them away.
#dnd tip: Hand select appropriate classes and races for the campaign world you want to run based on the flavor of the campaign.
#dnd tip: Sometimes players just want a room full of orcs. Not every encounter has to be fully developed with environmentals, puzzles, etc.
#dnd tip: Go easy on big battles and lots of terrain effects at low levels. Big rooms full of goblins is just fine at level 1.
#dnd tip: In your dark sun campaign, use that awesome color map and show them their place in Tyr or Athas at the beginning of your game.
#dnd tip: Be careful with brute swarms if your group lacks burst and blast attacks. They can be deadly.
#dnd tip: Mix wide open encounter areas with smaller complicated claustrophobic areas.
#dnd tip: Keep your terrain effects simple. It's hard enough remembering what your monsters are supposed to do.
#dnd tip: Write up three solid directions your players can choose from at the end of an adventure. Have them ready on game night.
#dnd tip: The Hannibal Lecter villain seed: Give your villain a piece of information critical to the party to prevent instant killings.
#dnd tip: Plan no more than three battles for a four hour game or two battles for a three hour game.
#dnd tip: Avoid using more than one "permission" room in an adventure, rooms that severely limit player mobility or actions.
#dnd tip: Try to give players a non-predetermined choice at the end of each adventure or even each battle. Kill or not to kill is easy.
#dnd tip: Reskinning and re-leveling monsters are great tricks to learn to speed up your game prep.
#dnd tip: A good hand-held white erase board and a dry-erase marker can work better than scraps of paper. Better for the earth too.
#dnd tip: Mix up dungeon, wilderness, and city encounters to give your group a variety of locations.
#dnd tip: Imposing a house rule that limits PCs to one interrupt power per character can avoid chains of interrupts in your game.
#dnd tip: Don't send your DM a tweet with a picture of your junk, even if it's covered in tighty whities. It won't get you any new gear.
#dnd tip: Build evil NPC parties from the humanoids in the Dark Sun Creature Catalog and Monster Vault.
#dnd tip: Don't worry if your battle map isn't perfectly aligned with the encounter map in a published adventure. Mod it to suit your group.
#dnd tip: Named bad guys can be more real and more interesting than generic brutes. Try to come up with details for sub-bosses.
#dnd tip: Reskin monsters around the miniatures you have rather than the old " this human pig farmer is actually a wyrmling".
#dnd tip: Cheap plastic shoe boxes work really well in storing miniatures.
#dnd tip: Mix up your dungeon tiles, dry-erase maps, and 3d terrain to make things interesting.
#dnd tip: Scale monster damage by starting at level + 8 and increasing or decreasing based on the number of targets or rarity of the attack.
#dnd tip: Keep your stories simple. You might love all the plot twists in your game but your players might have a hard time keeping track.
#dnd tip: Use between two and four different monsters in combat to keep things interesting without getting too complicated.
#dnd tip: To build some easy monster sheets, take screen grabs from the compendium and paste them into a word or pages document.
#dnd tip: When designing monsters, keep standard monsters simple - one or two thematic powers will do.
#dnd tip: Hand out disease cards to those afflicted to keep track of it across games.
#dnd tip: Use damaging terrain effects to scale encounters up without making your battle take longer.
#dnd tip: Sometimes your group just wants to fight hordes of minions. Give them that chance.
#dnd tip: Set up an assault or a defense of a small keep, noble house, or inn as a sandbox game with a purpose.
#dnd tip: Need a quick minion? AC = level + 15; Def = level + 13; attack = level + 5; damage = 4 + 1/2 level; init = 1/2 level.
#dnd tip: Running an adventure in a location from a campaign guide? Try googling the name to see what else others have done with it.
#dnd tip: Stephen King's The Stand (available on Netflix Streaming) is a great seed for a Gamma World campaign.
#dnd tip: Have two groups of PCs? Consider splitting up simultaneous events, telling half of a single story one night and half the next.
#dnd tip: Write down your last week's summary and post it to your Obsidian Portal adventure log to save yourself some time and energy.
#dnd tip: Too many NPCs filling up your campaign? Do what Stephen King did in The Stand and blow a few of them up to keep things focused.
#dnd tip: Let your players choose which NPCs have a big part in your campaign. Don't force the ones you like.
#dnd tip: For a good #gammaworld story about a derelict Martian space ship, check out Broken Angels:
#dnd tip: Need inspiration for a great Dark Sun big brawl scene? Check out the beginning of "Gangs of New York":
#dnd tip: A good mastermind villain always has a good side-kick who is in the face of the PCs a lot. Think Grace Jones from View to a Kill.
#dnd tip: Steal good scenes for your game from everywhere. Consider a mini-adventure based on the gang movie The Warriors.
#dnd tip: Denzel Washington in Training Day makes for a great ally turned villain. Don't surprise your party, have them watch him turn slow.
#dnd tip: Make Revenge of the Giants and Tomb of Horrors useful again by updating monster damage with a sharpie.
#dnd tip: The good cop gone too far is a great villain archetype. Consider Alonzo Harris from Training Day.
#dnd tip: It's easy to turn a normal encounter into a Dark Sun encounter. Grass turns to sand and water turns brackish.
#dnd tip: Hill giants with a Beast Giant leader makes for a great desert oasis encounter for paragon-tier Dark Sun PCs.
#dnd tip: Here's a good Dark Sun high-res map:
#dnd tip: Don't have two NPCs with the same first letter of their name. No Zanthar and Zulamen and Zytheria. Old tip from Stephen King.
#dnd tip: Monsters that burst when hit bring a great challenge to your paragon and epic PCs. See the Monster Vault Black Dragon.
#dnd tip: Quiz your players to figure out how many NPCs and plot twists they can actually keep track of.
#dnd tip: Want to run faster combats? Try using average damage for PCs and monsters instead of rolling damage dice.
#dnd tip: A burning building about to collapse makes for a great encounter "out". Give the PCs five rounds before it collapses around them.
#dnd tip: Make your "who's coming this week?" email exciting with some quick lore and sneak previews. Make them REALLY want to come.
#dnd tip: Spend some time surfing the #dnd hashtag to meet new folks as into our hobby as we are.
#dnd tip: Make brutes the staple monster in your battles. They do tons of damage and are easy to hit. DMs and players both love them.
#dnd tip: It's a lot easier to just play out of the Monster Vault book or the Dark Sun Creature Catalog. Don't think you have to tweak.
#dnd tip: Misplaced your monster? Give him a ranged attack that matches his basic melee. No one will know the difference.
#dnd tip: Always give your monster stat blocks a full read-through before a game. It's easy to forget about auras or interrupts.
#dnd tip: Have lots of monsters planned? Average out the damage of non-elites to make your battle a little faster.
#dnd tip: Have an elite boss you don't want to get stuck in a corner? Give him teleports and a way to shake off any status effect.
#dnd tip: You don't always have to completely retire your campaign. Take a year off and come back later in the PC's story.
#dnd tip: If you run a single monster type in an encounter, give them both a melee and ranged attack.
#dnd tip: In your Dark Sun game, always remember that the environment itself is an enemy.
#dnd tip: Steal some of the more detailed tiles from older Dungeon Tiles sets and throw them in your Master sets. Runes, sigils, etc.
#dnd tip: Always give solos a way to shake off stuns, unconscious, and dominates. Give epic solos a way to shake any status effect.
#dnd tip: The recent Zhent Soldier miniature from Lords of Madness makes for a great generic bad guy miniature.
#dnd tip: Hard-hitting elemental effects are a great way to increase threat in an encounter without making it slower.
#dnd tip: Running an epic one-shot adventure? Stick to Essentials source material.
#dnd tip: Mix up easier and harder fights to give your PCs a chance to stretch all their cool abilities before you drop the hammer.
#dnd tip: Be careful with too much slowing and difficult terrain. It can get annoying quick.
#dnd tip: Be like @chrisSSims and build your encounters beginning with the story you want to tell.
#dnd tip: Character sheets can be printed two to a page and still be legible. Saves ink and makes it easier to see all options at once.
#dnd tip: think of creative ways to build 3D sets out of Dungeon Tiles:
#dnd tip: Keep traps, terrain effects, and hazards simple. You have enough to worry about.
#dnd tip: Give your players a chance to shine with a lower difficulty encounter. Run only three monsters instead of five or six.
#dnd tip: You don't need dwarven forge to have a 3d map. Use thread spools or toilet paper rolls to boost up dungeon tiles.
#dnd tip: Give bored players a chance to roll a skill check to learn something interesting about an environment or monster.
#dnd tip: The newer the monster book, the better the monster design. When selecting monsters, pick from newer books first.
#dnd tip: If you don't have it, invest in a good set of hero miniatures. While you can get away with monster tokens, PCs need minis.
#dnd tip: From the immortal Chris Perkins, model your notable NPC after a movie character to help with the voices:
#dnd tip: Good heroes make choices. Give your players plenty of opportunities to make the hard calls.
#dnd tip: Add excitement to your game by running it during a 5.9 earthquake...
#dnd tip: How is your villain changing his plans as your PCs move forward in their story?
#dnd tip: Hand select appropriate classes and races for the campaign world you want to run based on the flavor of the campaign.
#dnd tip: Take screen shots of monster blocks from the compendium, paste them together in Paint, and send as Photos to your iPad.
#dnd tip: From the @wizards_dnd podcast: the order of effects at the beginning of the turn is decided upon by the creature's player.
#dnd tip: Acrylic sheets from Home Depot work very well over flat dungeon tile arrangements as well as poster maps.
#dnd tip: To speed things up and still keep up the threat of a battle, change "-2 to attacks" auras on enemies to "-2 to defenses".
#dnd tip: With the Monster Vault, MV: Nentir Vale, MM3, and Dark Sun Creature Catalog, there's no reason to use outdated monster books.
#dnd tip: Don't assume your group just loves combat. Try a single battle and some roleplaying before and after.
#dnd tip: Try Fiasco-style character interactions to get your PCs together in some way other than all showing up at a bar.
#dnd tip: Sometimes acting like a Boggle (like an idiot) is all it takes to impress people like @katokatonian or @angrydm.
#dnd tip: Never ever "just end the fight here". Always come up with an in-game reason for a battle to end early.
#dnd tip: Tell your group the highest defense across all monsters as your "magic number" so they don't have to ask if they hit above it.
#dnd tip: Use acrylic sheets from Home Depot to stack multiple maps on top of one another and peel back as your group goes through maps.
#dnd tip: Acrylic sheets work very well above dungeon tiles. You don't even need to use poster putty.
#dnd tip: Take Chris Perkins's advice and "under-prepare and improvise":
#dnd tip: If you find yourself designing monsters, you can do a lot worse than picking up a copy of the 1st edition Fiend Folio.
#dnd tip: Keep a folio of poster maps and large tiles handy for those unplanned encounter areas that come up during your adventure.
#dnd tip: Auto-hit environmental effects are a lot easier to manage at the table than effects with attack rolls.
#dnd tip: Keep control of the magic items you give out in your campaign. Some of them can be quite a challenge to deal with later.
#dnd tip: Missing some good hero miniatures? Check out the Reaper pre-painted miniature line:
#dnd tip: What theme song does your campaign have? Play it often and use it to bring them into the mindset of your world.
#dnd tip: Running a one-shot? Try to stick to level 1 PCs. It makes for a much faster game with lots of potential encounters.
#dnd tip: Try out Mastermind as an interesting skill challenge puzzle for door traps or arcane locks:
#dnd tip: When running one-shot D&D or Gamma World games, start them at level 1 to keep things simple and fast.
#dnd tip: Tell your group what the highest AND lowest defenses are for all monsters so they know instantly if they hit or missed.
#dnd tip: Work with your group to come up with a party name. Don't simply pick it for them or leave it totally in their hands.
#dnd tip: Head out to your local drug stores or party stores to pick up some awesome halloween props for your game.
#dnd tip: Have more than five players? Have traps and hazards auto-hit instead of rolling attacks. Faster game and more damage output.
#dnd tip: Go over your poster map collection regularly so you can whip one out whenever the situation calls for it at your game.
#dnd tip: Easy way to figure out damage dice: Level + 8 damage - (1 + max dice roll) for 2 dice. 15th lvl = 23 dam - 9 = 2d8+14.
#dnd tip: Pick up the Fantastic Locations map packs. For the money, you get four great poster maps:
#dnd tip: Focus most of your preparation time time on the interactions of NPCs in your game world.
#dnd tip: A level + 5 elite can make for a great boss instead of a level +1 or +2 solo.
#dnd tip: Combine two poster maps for a nice large encounter area worthy of two or three battles.
#dnd tip: When designing monsters (and this should be rare - reskin instead), go back to original 1e sources for inspiration.
#dnd tip: Scunci girl hair bands make great mini markers and only cost $3 at CVS.
#dnd tip: In Gloomwrought, no one is pure and everyone has a hidden agenda.
#dnd tip: Have your characters build their backgrounds and relationships before you build your campaign's threads .
#dnd tip: Remember, bad villains always think they're the good guys.
#dnd tip: Try to build up a set of generic miniatures that work well at all tiers and in many battles.
#dnd tip: Reuse poster maps by flipping them 180 degrees, starting the party at different spots, and changing the environmental effects.
#dnd tip: Keep traps and environmentals simple. To make it really easy, have them auto-hit if a character ends its turn within the aura.
#dnd tip: Auras are an easy staple for solo monsters and epic-tier battles. They are easily over-used though.
#dnd tip: Keep monster theme powers in your head that tie monsters together into a clear group.
#dnd tip: Build a list of 20 potential relationships between PCs based on the factions in your campaign world when starting a campaign.
#dnd tip: Keep a big ziploc bag of all the table accessories you regularly need. Remove stuff you don't really use.
#dnd tip: Time to go look for that bargain-bin halloween props for your game!
#dnd tip: Try running your game without a DM screen to keep things more open and give you a better view of the table.
#dnd tip: Speed up combat and keep things lethal: At beginning of turn, monsters gain vulnerability 5 per tier and +5 per tier in damage.
#dnd tip: Every encounter should teach the PCs more about the story of the adventure. What will they learn from your next one?
#dnd tip: Before you prep your game, go over your collection of poster maps to get ideas for cool encounter areas.
#dnd tip: Think real hard about your game and then forget about it for a day. Let good ideas grow subconsiously.
#dnd tip: When running one-shot D&D or Gamma World games, start them at level 1 to keep things simple and fast.
#dnd tip: If you do nothing else, use updated damage expressions for monsters published before the Monster Manual 3.
#dnd tip: Set aside all the minis or tokens you might need for the general area your PCs explore. It opens up potential encounters.
#dnd tip: Try building a whole encounter that's nothing but traps and hazards. Think the idol temple in Raiders of the Lost Ark.
#dnd tip: Fleeing as a "combat out" rarely works well. Players are determined to stop them from running. Let them get away in an instant.
#dnd tip: For detriments, reduce defenses and add vulnerabilities rather than steal actions and reducing attack scores or damage.
#dnd tip: The Gloomwrought Despair deck can work well for any dismal adventure. Use it at the edge of (or within) the Far Realm.
#dnd tip: Heavy and nasty environmental effects can help a solo stay a solo in an encounter.
#dnd tip: Stick to gear rewards from the Dungeon Master Kit and Mordenkainen's Emporium. They have a good sense of what makes a rare item.
#dnd tip: Designing a big solo? Make sure they have a way to break away from movement impairment zones and chained effects.
#dnd tip: To give your dungeon some extra flavor and challenge, add a dungeon-wide effect like +5 to necrotic attacks or vul 5 to cold.
#dnd tip: Use vulnerability and "- X defenses" instead of action-stealing or "-X attack" status effects. Keeps up threat without boredom.
#dnd tip: Replace complicated status effects with "knocking prone". It's easy to keep track of and doesn't bone the PC too much.
#dnd tip: If you write up anything, write up a read-aloud summary of your last game to get your players in the right mindset.
#dnd tip: A good villain thinks he's right. A great villain IS right.
#dnd tip: A static damage number for traps and hazards makes them run a lot faster at the table.
#dnd tip: Use your Gloomwrought, Dark Sun, or Neverwinter maps to show your party where they ended the last session.
#dnd tip: A single high-level elite and a series of traps can make for a great non-standard encounter.
#dnd tip: "Restrain until the beginning of your next turn" works well for restraining hazards without making them too painful
#dnd tip: Hang a white-board near your table to write monster defenses and common DCs during a game.
#dnd tip: Don't worry too much about monster size. Sometimes players with low level PCs should fight a huge or gargantuan dragon.
#dnd tip: Sometimes auto damage is the only way you'll actually threaten high-level PCs. Don't use it all the time but a dash will do ya!
#dnd tip: Go over your whole encounter setup to ensure it threatens the whole party. Enough artillery? Enough brutes?
#dnd tip: In high level encounters, ensure at least one monster can hit each defense type.
#dnd tip: Instead of statting out full traps, just keep the theme in mind and use the DM Cheat Sheet for damage:
#dnd tip: You might be tempted to run a high-level elite instead of a lower-level solo. Level + 5 is about as far as you'll want to go.
#dnd tip: Random loot can be fun, but verify that your PCs have enough gold every so often by checking their ideal gold per level.
#dnd tip: Lazy DMing can help you focus on story and NPC interactions, but don't skimp on designing some good pre-planned encounters.
#dnd tip: Environmental effects that strictly do damage can be boring, but they're a lot easier to design and implement. Ware complexity.
#dnd tip: Stick to rewarding magic items from the DM Kit and Mordenkainen's. You get a good wide variety and better balanced items.
#dnd tip: When running for 4 PCs, keep in mind that much synergy is lost. Go easy on them or you'll wipe them out accidentally.
#dnd tip: With four "Heroes" books in publication, consider limiting short-run games to PC classes and races from only those books.
#dnd tip: Not every room in a dungeon needs monsters. Give them some interesting rooms to explore filled with story hooks.
#dnd tip: Give challenging bosses environmental terrain that penetrates damage resistance, boosts damage, or boosts damage shields.
#dnd tip: Make sure your players have enough options to keep them interesting from level to level.
#dnd tip: Ask your players what they enjoy the most and the least in your games. Always seek to tweak and improve your game.
#dnd tip: A small number of monsters at a higher level can be easier to manage and makes for a faster yet still challenging encounter.
#dnd tip: Keep some maps and tiles of generic rooms, inns, streets, and wilderness encounters for on-the-spot encounters.
#dnd tip: Want some extra threat and a way to deal with so many multiple attacks? Give your monster a fire shield that hits back!
#dnd tip: When building monsters, keep them to only the most important powers. Keep them lean and simple at the table.
#dnd tip: Not every boss needs to be a solo. Elites, and even normal monsters, can work well as humanoid bosses.
#dnd tip: Turn a normal creature into an elite easily with twice the hit points and an extra standard action each round.
#dnd tip: Poster maps and a 24" by 36" polycarbonate sheet are the best encounter props you can get.
#dnd tip: Mix and match your mini collection and the D&D Adventure Board Game minis to make the most of both.
#dnd tip: For an easy Combat Out, tie brutes or skirmishers to artillery or controllers. If either group dies, the others break down.
#dnd tip: Granting combat advantage is a nice clean nasty status effect to give to a monster's attack or aura.
#dnd tip: Don't force a story. Think what the main NPCs in your campaign are doing right now as they react to the PCs' actions.
#dnd tip: Pull out some fun old adventures for inspiration into your current 4e game.
#dnd tip: For your more open-ended games, having about three possible paths the party might go and don't fall in love with any one of them.
#dnd tip: Keep a list of favorite supporting characters in movies you liked for ad-hoc NPC roleplaying.
#dnd tip: Build out your story, then refine it to the most cool piece of it.
#dnd tip: While you can get away with tokens for monsters, invest in a good set of PC miniatures.
#dnd tip: It's easy to wipe people out in Gamma World. Plan accordingly.
#dnd tip: Stick to two to three different kinds of monsters in an encounter. More than that gets too complicated to run easily.
#dnd tip: Remember that being a DM is being a showman. Work on your dynamic voice and performance to keep the pace of the game right.
#dnd tip: For a good personality template, think of a movie character and watch a film of theirs on Netflix to get the personality right.
#dnd tip: Follow the advice of @theiddm and always keep an eye on the body-language of your players and yourself. Get into "the arena"!
#dnd tip: Boss rooms should often contain some sort of damage resistance penetration so your boss's elemental damage isn't nullified.
#dnd tip: Think through the eyes of your NPCs instead of plotting out your story.
#dnd tip: Use simple puzzles as potential mini-games instead of just rolling skill checks.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to talk about your hobby with your coworkers. You never know who used to play and dreams of playing again.
#dnd tip: Always ask for honest feedback on your game after it's done. Force them to come up with one thing you can make better.
#dnd tip: Feedback from your players can tell you a lot about your game. Body language can tell you a lot more. Watch them both.
#dnd tip: Romance in a game can be weird or fun. Keep it light hearted and funny most of time time and powerful once or twice.
#dnd tip: Just because things got more complicated doesn't mean they have to. A single skill check or single-use trap is a fine way to go.
#dnd tip: Consider running 6 to 8 session mini-campaigns focused on a particular theme and source material.
#dnd tip: When limiting source material, have players build their characters using the physical books and then put it in the CB after.
#dnd tip: Pay special attention to environmental effects in your encounters. They are often the thing that makes encounters unique.
#dnd tip: Players spending a lot of time on cellphones? What can you do to draw their interest back to the game?
#dnd tip: Don't assume your players care as much for the story as you do. Your high nterest is probably why you're the DM.
#dnd tip: Delegate things like initiative and monster damage tracking to other players when you get overwhelmed.
#dnd tip: Up and down-level monsters by adding a -X level sticky note in your monster book to remind you to do the math.
#dnd tip: Keep solos and elites simple and powerful by letting them ignore daze, stuns, and dominates during their turns.
#dnd tip: Keep elites and solos simple and powerful by letting them ignore daze, stuns, and dominates during their turn.
#dnd tip: Want an old-school feel with your existing 4e game? Try playing low level games with just Heroes of the Fallen Lands.
#dnd tip: Want the feeling of a simple old-school #dnd game? Try running low level adventures with just Heroes of the Fallen Lands.
#dnd tip: Keep your game ultra simple by only using the DM Cheat Sheet and coming up with everything on the fly:
#dnd tip: Keep NPC portraits handy on your laptop or iPad and save yourself the cost of all that ink.
#dnd tip: Use a single mini like the rat swarm or kobold to represent a pack of minions on your battle map.
#dnd tip: Use numbered tent cards in front of the player to run initiative at con-games or one-shots. Got this from @alphastream.
#dnd tip: Consider layered traps. Maybe the pit trap has a falling pot of pitch trap right on the other side.
#dnd tip: Use minis like the kobold or rat swarm to represent a number of small or tiny minions on your battle map.
#dnd tip: Use a handful of D6s to determine which player hordes of monsters might attack.
#dnd tip: Write up a seating chart on a note card in front of you to remember character names associated with each player oriented by seat.
#dnd tip: A quick and easy way to add flavor to an NPC is to associate them with a character in a movie or TV show you like.
#dnd tip: don't fight the knowledge your players bring to the game. Incorporate their knowledge into their PCs.
#dnd tip: Always keep your game moving. If players can't decide what to do, call a vote on two or three options.
#dnd tip: Don't save up that good idea for later, use it as soon as you're able. From Perkins:
#dnd tip: Keep an idea journal around for those adventure or story ideas you aren't quite able to use yet:
#dnd tip: When developing your story, consider the wise words of Kurt Vonnegut and start close to the end:
#dnd tip: Go crazy at the dollar store for some gaming props and terrain: from @markmeredith
#dnd tip: Mark and remember the map drawing tips of Chris Perkins.
#dnd tip: Use flashbacks, maybe even a flashback encounter, to share a richer and deeper story.
#dnd tip: When building or running a monster, ensure your players get the true feeling of what makes that monster different.
#dnd tip: The Cathedral of Chaos tile set includes a sheet of tokens for conjurations, walls, and other useful things.
#dnd tip: For your heavy tactical gamer players, incorporate roleplaying as a part of combat.
#dnd tip: Learn to be comfortable with changes in your story based on the decisions of your players, the actions of the PCs, and the dice.
#dnd tip: Really ask yourself if you need to do all that monster tweaking. Just play from the Monster Vault and have fun.
#dnd tip: When things slow down at the table, fall into character of the villains and bring things back to life with some flavor.
#dnd tip: Spend your time planning for a dynamic world instead of a static story.
#dnd tip: Reinforce the aspects of your game world that tie closely to its theme. Buildings should hate the PCs in Gloomwrought.
#dnd tip: A good piece of 250 to 500 word flash fiction in an email can keep your game tied together between games.
#dnd tip: Be wary of complicated dungeon crawls. Stacked on long combats, they can be a big slog.
#dnd tip: Keep a white-board on your wall to write up important all-visible notes like monster defenses.
#dnd tip: Write large 5x8 cards with monster defenses on them to post on your game-room white board when the time comes.
#dnd tip: Remember to be patient and build a game session that won't make you or your players feel rushed.
#dnd tip: Be like Perkins (and Stephen King) and use "What If" as your motivator for adventures instead of long plots:
#dnd tip: Use the Gloom deck from the Shadowfell boxed set as failure conditions to skill challenges or traps:
#dnd tip: Think about where you spend your time prepping your game. Is that where you SHOULD be?
#dnd tip: writing good flavor text helps you stick to just the descriptions crucial to trigger the inner eyes of your players.
#dnd tip: Use a small notebook to capture unexpected changes in the story during your game.
#dnd tip: Build adventures around the personal quests of the PCs.
#dnd tip: Reward meaningful personal quests with wish-list items.
#dnd tip: Don't over think a short rest. Sometimes it is just a reinvigoration between the parts of a two-part battle.
#dnd tip: your players will always assume traveling NPCs will betray them. Surprise them.
#dnd tip: add seasons and holidays in your game world.
#dnd tip: Mark the wise words of Steve Townshend. What are your "three things" for your next game?
#dnd tip: Spend your valuable time considering the personalities and motivations of your NPCs instead of building monster stat blocks.
#dnd tip: Use the acrylic sheet over your hand-drawn poster maps so your ink doesn't smear.
#dnd tip: Think about what each of your players hopes for when they come to your game. How will you give it to them?
#dnd tip: What big decisions will your players have to choose in your next adventure? Don't fall in love with any choice - they can tell.
#dnd tip: "removed from play until beginning of next turn" is a great nasty epic status effect that doesn't screw PCs too badly.
#dnd tip: Large areas of movement hindering terrain can be a royal pain in the ass. Use sparingly.
#dnd tip: Write quests down, especially unplanned quests, on 3x5 cards and keep them handy for your players.
#dnd tip: follow Perkins's wise words. Don't build a battle to capture or kill players but prepare for that outcome:
#dnd tip: Set a good example and run a fast turn when the monsters go.
#dnd tip: Not all random encounters need to be battles against monsters: Thanks @StvWinter!
#dnd tip: Consider using initiative to balance player table time in non-combat encounters and scenes with a split party:...
#dnd tip: All good DMs need to sit on the other side of the table. Find a way to regularly play in a game instead of just DMing all the...
#dnd tip: Always keep a blank flip mat available during your game for ad-hoc encounters:
#dnd tip: get out to some conventions like PAX, Gencon, of SynDCon. It's always useful to watch other DMs run games.
#dnd tip: Bit of a hard movie to grok but there are some great story seeds and NPC archetypes in "Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy".
#dnd tip: Avoid using piles of monsters with the same status effect powers. Too many creatures that grab can be a drag instead of fun.
#dnd tip: Wind power, running waterways, or harnessed heat are great forces to potentially reset mechanical traps over centuries.
#dnd tip: A good forest flip mat can help a lot for off-the-cuff forest encounters.
#dnd tip: The movie 13 Assassins is full of great character, encounter, and story ideas for your game.
#dnd tip: Like good NPCs, you can build the personality of intelligent artifacts around characters in books, movies, or TV that you adore.
#dnd tip: Sometimes the best and easiest dungeon map to use is the plain-old Gamemastery Flip Mat:
#dnd tip: Leave plenty of time to run your big climactic battles. Change things half-way through and make it memorable.
#dnd tip: Don't pressure or cut your group off too short when they're spending a good deal of time discussing a potential decision.
#dnd tip: Want to add a ready-made town to your #dndnext Caves of Chaos playtest? Add the Keep on the Chaos Scar:
#dnd tip: It's worth the time to do a quick review of a pre-published encounter before you're about to run it.
#dnd tip: Keep some random names around to name powerful memorable monsters in your battles.
#dnd tip: Keep a random loot list around to save yourself preparation time and embrace the lifestyle of the lazy DM:
#dnd tip: Always remember that published adventures are intended to be modified. Rework them to suit your style and your group's desires.
#dnd tip: Introduce key villains in your campaign at least two or three sessions before your group faces them.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid of adding ad-hoc powers to your big monsters on the fly. Use the DM Cheat Sheet as a guide:
#dnd tip: Keep your players engaged in your campaign on off-weeks with weekly emailed flash-fiction.
#dnd tip: Don't plan out your campaign too far. Pick a general goal and let the story move naturally.
#dnd tip: Group having trouble coming to a decision? Lay out the options and call for a vote. Go with the majority.
#dnd tip: Need a good villain? Look no further than Raven from the book "Snow Crash". Great background and awesome sinister motivations.
#dnd tip: Plan only what you need to plan and force yourself to improv at the table. It makes for a much more open-ended game in the end.
#dnd tip: One of my favorite tips: Put yourself to sleep daydreaming through the eyes of your NPCs.
#dnd tip: 4e battles work best as large set-pieces and scenes. Build your adventures around these big scenes.
#dnd tip: Try running Fiasco with your #dnd group to give them insight into a game focused on group storytelling.
#dnd tip: Grab a set of re-usable maps to keep on hand. A lazy dungeon master focuses time on the RIGHT things!
#dnd tip: Consider building sets of themes for your short campaign, letting PCs choose the set and then randomly determining the theme.
#dnd tip: Preparing for improvisation means having the right tools available to you. What is your improvisation tool list?
#dnd tip: Understanding the motives of your NPCs and villains makes it easier to improvise their reactions to the PCs' actions.
#dnd tip: Instead of building your world or re-statting monsters, spend time understanding the backgrounds and motivations of the PCs.
#dnd tip: During your #dndnext playtest, experiment with both Theater of the Mind and gridded combat experiences.
#dnd tip: Keep your notable NPC list short for your mini-campaign. It makes it easier for the players to remember who's important.
#dnd tip: Build your NPCs and their actions as stand-alone characters and events, not just how they react to the PCs.
#dnd tip: Give your PCs a chance to parlay with defeated monsters instead of just always having them die off.
#dnd tip: For powerful solos, let them convert debilitating status effects int damage, vulnerability, or combat advantage.
#dnd tip: For your mini-campaign, work with your player to choose a set of classes and races that makes sense for the campaign world.
#dnd tip: Keep a random loot chart with your copy of the DM Kit to save yourself prep time:
#dnd tip: Use the DM Cheat Sheet to make rulings instead of worrying about hard rules for DCs and damage:
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to come up with terrain effects and powers on the fly. Maybe that slime patch grants CA!
#dnd tip: What three things do you need to happen in your next game? Keep things simple.
#dnd tip: Tune your lazy DM powers. Force yourself to come up with a random on-the-spot NPC at your next game.
#dnd tip: Wrap three layers onto your encounter area: What did it used to be? What is it now? What happens to it during the battle?
#dnd tip: Try to break stereotypes in your NPCs. Make the big brute an articulate poet or master of business.
#dnd tip: Let humor flow into your game but don't be afraid to make things serious. Think about how WoW handles humor and drama.
#dnd tip: Plan ahead for creatures being dominated. Give boss monsters two sets of actions, one dominated and one not.
#dnd tip: Did your big boss monster get dominated? See where that takes the story!
#dnd tip: Need a dungeon and don't have one ready? Grab one from this huge map archive:
#dnd tip: Give your rules lawyer the job of rules mediation to take some of the pressure off of you.
#dnd tip: Focus on building an environment and interesting dynamic NPCs instead of telling a story.
#dnd tip: Think your players know where the story is headed? Maybe it's time to reveal the TRUE villain.
#dnd tip: Things getting too mainstream? Pull a Joss Whedon and kill off some folk.
#dnd tip: The dungeon and overland poster map from the Starter Set has a great amount of versatility for the lazy DM:
#dnd tip: What makes your locations familiar, fantastic, and functional?
#dnd tip: In the prime of their life, what were all these tunnels, dungeons, or old ruins supposed to be?
#dnd tip: Always have a battle on hand to stir things up in the beginning of your adventure so it doesn't get too slow.
#dnd tip: Be prepared to throw your encounter away if your group finds a creative way to get around it.
#dnd tip: Be prepared for the PCs to drop fast, all at once. Give them room to come back or be prepared for their defeat.
#dnd tip: Instead of building encounters, prepare the tools you need to build encounters at the table.
#dnd tip: Keep the book from the DM Kit handy to reskin traps and quickly pick some fantastic terrain:
#dnd tip: Write down the goals and quests of the PCs and review them before planning each game for tie-ins.
#dnd tip: Keep old dungeon maps handy in case your PCs go off the path.
#dnd tip: Use the generic tiles in the Dungeon Tile Master Set instead of drawing featureless rooms:
#dnd tip: Keep things running smooth at your table by putting out all the accessories beforehand: pencils, dice, paper, init cards, etc.
#dnd tip: Is the battle losing steam but you still have a couple of monsters left? Give them extra standard actions each turn.
#dnd tip: #dndnext's "Advantage" and "Disadvantage" work very well for ad-hoc environmental effects. Add them to your lazy bag of tricks.
#dnd tip: Want a more even 4e skill experience? Houserule a free feat, Bard of All Trades, that gives a +3 bonus to untrained skills.
#dnd tip: When building a soundtrack for your game, mix big hits with classical soundtracks.
#dnd tip: Consider using #dndnext's "advantage" as a terrain benefit. Unlike "disadvantage", it speeds up combat instead of slowing it down.
#dnd tip: Consider a "boss" template that lets bosses remove status effects but grants "advantage" to all enemies instead.
#dnd tip: Sort your minis so you don't have to bother setting them aside for game day. Just grab your "orc" box and go!
#dnd tip: Keep poster maps for roads, inns, dungeon rooms, castles, and overland forest areas handy for improvised encounters.
#dnd tip: When running Gardmore, always consider what the NPC adventurers are up to as the PCs move forward.
#dnd tip: Work with your players to find interesting ways to feed the PC's story into the game world. It isn't YOUR story, it's the group's.
#dnd tip: Battles with a single monster type run much faster than with multiple monsters. Use them for in-between fights.
#dnd tip: With the length of 4e battles in mind, make sure every battle has its own story to tell and a part in the big picture.
#dnd tip: The 1e Dungeon Master's Guide contains a wealth of charts and tables useful for any D&D game.
#dnd tip: when running gridless combat, favor the attacker.
#dnd tip: No leader in your group? Give everyone a once-per-encounter minor-action healing surge use they can use on themselves or...
#dnd tip: Run a smaller multi-room dungeon as a single encounter with monsters running in at different times.
#dnd tip: Short rests don't always need to be 5 minute breaks. Maybe the PCs drank some refreshing Fey-water for an instant recharge.
#dnd tip: Where you can remotely justify it, give your melee-based monsters a ranged attack in case they get pinned down.
#dnd tip: Convert monster dominates to "as a free action, take a move action and make a basic attack"
#dnd tip: Try to have three choices available for your players to take at the beginning and ends of games.
#dnd tip: Think of encounters as part of the structure of your story. Make every one of them matter to the story.
#dnd tip: Keep your primary villains mobile. Ensure they're doing stuff while your PCs are on the move.
#dnd tip: Before planning a mini-campaign, run ideas past your group on what they might be interested in.
#dnd tip: Want a full 1-30 experience in a short period, try @squach's 5 levels betwee sessions mini-campaign idea.
#dnd tip: Stick to lower-level characters for one-shot campaigns so players don't have too much trouble figuring out their capabilities.
#dnd tip: Use the dungeon tiles in the Dungeon Command sets for some Dragon-Age-style random encounter maps.
#dnd tip: Build a nice 4 hour playlist of instrumental music and some rock music to keep your game's pace high.
#dnd tip: Keep a set of potential environmental and situational effects handy for improv. Ensure they all help keep the pace fast.
#dnd tip: Need to do some environmental damage to a PC? Use 2d6+level as your equation for normal damage. +1d6 per tier for higher damage.
#dnd tip: Vary your encounter design so you don't get stuck in similar battles.
#dnd tip: Prep your game table 30 minutes early so things go smooth at game time.
#dnd tip: Take the time to read through a pre-published adventure should you decide to run one.
#dnd tip: Don't start off an adventure with an apology. Just go with what you have.
#dnd tip: Add some old-world flavor to your handouts by printing them out on copper parchment paper:
#dnd tip: #dndnext characters have far fewer hit points and far fewer ways to get them back. Consider this in your dungeon designs.
#dnd tip: Throw some action into the middle of long periods of role playing with a good old fashioned bar brawl!
#dnd tip: Be like @alphastream and review the PC's motivations, goals, and backgrounds before each game to tie them in.
#dnd tip: When improvising flavor of an area, describe all the senses.
#dnd tip: In sandbox games, always have an idea what adventure locations are near by. Ancient dungeons, old caves, slavers keeps, etc.
#dnd tip: The #dnd adventure novels can give you a lot of good background and inspiration for your adventure.
#dnd tip: Want your traps to feel real? Describe the sounds of counter-weights moving behind the walls.
#dnd tip: Practice the fine art of not writing down great ideas. If they're really great, they'll come back.
#dnd tip: Consider running the old Ravenloft module with your #dndnext playtest on Halloween!
#dnd tip: Looking to build your own Perkins-style map archive? Here's a link to the WOTC Map Archive:
#dnd tip: For those on a budget, the Monster Vault is worth it just for the tokens, adventure, and map.
#dnd tip: Use Star Trek as a model for island adventures just like Chris Perkins.
#dnd tip: Tap into the imagination of your players to fuel your game's story.
#dnd tip: From Perkins: if you're going to rip off someone's idea, rip off @montecook. He's a master.
#dnd tip: Spend prep time on hand-outs and other table gimmicks to make your game interesting.
#dnd tip: Play tons of other games and steal the mechanics and stories that work for you.
#dnd tip: Always be ready for PCs to throw your primary quest-giving NPC off a cliff.
#dnd tip: Skill as a roleplayer and as a DM comes with practice. Get out there and do it - a lot.
#dnd tip: Take a queue from Borderlands 2 and have your villain interacting with your PCs often, even very early on.
#dnd tip: Want an example of a sandbox story? Check out True Blood.
#dnd tip: Get over the fear of failure. Recognize this fear and allow yourself to make mistakes.
#dnd tip: Convey a new piece of information with each piece of improvised dialog.
#dnd tip: Imitate voices from TV and movie characters.
#dnd tip: This episode of @planetmoney has a fantastic description of 1400s era money management including sand-abacuses:...
#dnd tip: If you use "theater of the mind" take the opportunity to go big. Vast rooms, huge statues - things you can't do with a map.
#dnd tip: At the epic tier, threaten what the PCs love. Superman's weakness is his love for humans:
#dnd tip: Don't save your great ideas, use them!
#dnd tip: Leave big wide gaps in your game's story and let the players fill them in.
#dnd tip: Choose NPC actions not on a flow-chart of decisions and outcomes but from their own background and desires:
#dnd tip: These folios are a tad costly but they're perfect for campaigns or portable DM kits:
#dnd tip: Keep some battles handy if your game starts to get wordy. There's always a pack of robbers or a bar brawl waiting to happen.
#dnd tip: Elminister's Forgotten Realms gives a ton of detail to help fill out any traditional fantasy world. Absorb it:...
#dnd tip: Sometimes its ok to let the PCs nuke your main bad guys:
#dnd tip: Interesting article on the future works of Pathfinder by @JasonBulmahn: The NPC Codex sounds awesome.
#dnd tip: Be like Ed Greenwood and make your next magic item something crazy and fun: It's all about the memories.
#dnd tip: Focus on tone and pace when imitating voices.
#dnd tip: Steal characters and seeds from three Kurt Russel movies: Escape from New York, The Thing, and Soldier
#dnd tip: A great DM comes from skills in improvisation. How will you improve your improv skills?
#dnd tip: How can you break up your next adventure into three acts?
#dnd tip: Take a tip from Ed Greenwood and build cities from the senses of the PCs:
#dnd tip: Everybody poops. Consider the daily habits of your monsters when building out their lair.
#dnd tip: A single monster type in an encounter makes for a much faster battle. Use a single type of monster for a quick skirmish.
#dnd tip: Give every magic item you hand out a name. In 4e, use "inherent bonuses" to remove the requirement for constant upgrades.
#dnd tip: Old 1st edition modules convert very easily over to #dndnext. Give them a try!
#dnd tip: Use well-known stories as a template for adventure, but add a twist!
#dnd tip: Chris Perkins takes a look at trustworthyness in NPCs and True Romance, a great movie for NPC templates:
#dnd tip: Force yourself to improvise by leaving big open choices for your players' at your next session.
#dnd tip: Don't correct your players as they noodle a story through out loud. Instead, try to change your story to fit their ideas.
#dnd tip: Have a player who just jumped into your game? Ask the group to figure out how his or her PC arrived.
#dnd tip: Random encounters don't have to be boring. How do those random encounters lead to more interesting story threads?
#dnd tip: How is ending a #dnd campaign similar to leaving a patient? @theiddm tells us!
#dnd tip: Jot down hooks your players come up with during the game so you can wire them back into the story as it unfolds.
#dnd tip: You don't need a thousand monsters. A couple of hundred well-designed ones can be re-skinned forever.
#dnd tip: Need a 4e monster? AC: 15+lvl, Def: 13+lvl, Attack: lvl+5 vs AC, damage: level+8 - there you go.
#dnd tip: Sort your minis or monster tokens by the method that lets you retrieve the right one the fastest.
#dnd tip: Using a battle map? Come up with some interesting way to use the terrain.
#dnd tip: For a bit of random fun, have magic item vendors with only a random selection of five pieces of loot:
#dnd tip: Running a low magic 4e campaign? Use Inherent Bonuses and give out only selected rare items of great importance.
#dnd tip: Don't force your players back into the rails if they go off track in your published adventure. Go with it!
#dnd tip: If you're looking for fantastic film-noir characters, check out Way of the Gun:
#dnd tip: Running Epic Tier? If your group didn't blow up Vecna with a nuclear bomb, you're not playing right:
#dnd tip: Monsters seeming stale? Give one or more of them a bit of plot and personality to make things interesting.
#dnd tip: Not hitting any random encounters in Isle of Dread? Show the PCs the tracks of the monsters that came by recently instead.
#dnd tip: What's the winter holiday in your game world?
#dnd tip: Experiment using Theater of the Mind for smaller fights against single monsters without crazy terrain features.
#dnd tip: Don't fall too much in love with roleplaying an NPC. Sometimes your players just want things to move along.
#dnd tip: Remember the roots of our games as a group of people telling a story.
#dnd tip: Use these excellent rich NPCs from the deep brain of Ed Greenwood in your lazy DM toolkit:
#dnd tip: Want to see the adventure worksheet of a master? Check out Chris Perkins's adventure sheet:
#dnd tip: Like Pope in Sons of Anarchy, what time bomb has your villain set up to go off when he or she dies?
#dnd tip: For one-shot campaigns, focus character backgrounds around the general seed or primary location of the story.
#dnd tip: Use flashbacks as a way to drive interest in a game's world without forcing a direction.
#dnd tip: The first scene in Prometheus is actually a pretty interesting story seed for a lot of campaigns.
#dnd tip: Let your players name their magic weapons when they acquire them. Take note of it and mention it later.
#dnd tip: Don't go too hard on the "damned if you do, damned if you don't" choices. Sometimes people don't want the extra stress.
#dnd tip: Let stories evolve and digest in your mind for a while before you sprint to the word processor and solidify them.
#dnd tip: Leave yourself unanswered questions in your thoughts about your campaign ideas.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to pull back the curtain and let players see what's going on in the background with flash fiction or a montage.
#dnd tip: Try putting the DM screen away and removing the physical barrier between you and the rest of the group. Be one of them!
#dnd tip: Give your group options on directions to take the game. Let them vote on the game's future.
#dnd tip: Don't forget to use the three Fs when describing an area: Functional, Familiar, and Fantastic.
#dnd tip: When running "Isle of Dread", use the random encounter chart to describe tracks found by the PCs or mix two groups together.
#dnd tip: Let players discuss their options, then summarize them, and have them choose. Move things forward without forcing directions.
#dnd tip: Sometimes its fun to return to old-school graph paper mapping. Ask your group if any of them are interested and map away!
#dnd tip: Use Story Cubes to add quick backgrounds to enemies or random NPCs:
#dnd tip: Organize your minis so you can easily pull out the ones you need during your game. Saves you the effort of sorting beforehand.
#dnd tip: Use published adventures as inspiration and a loose guide instead of running it  room-by-room.
#dnd tip: It's very easy to convert 1e adventures over to #dndnext. Slave Pits of Undercity is one such example.
#dnd tip: As you begin your mini-campaign, sit with your players and understand their expectations:
#dnd tip: Here's a great article on DM pitfalls recommended by Chris Perkins:
#dnd tip: Develop your story from the ideas your players generate during the game.
#dnd tip: What one word describes you as a DM?
#dnd tip: Heed the wise words of @theshedm when considering betrayal in your game:
#dnd tip: Follow the wise even-toned words of @theangrydm and keep your background stories brief and focused:
#dnd tip: Random encounters don't have to be throw-aways. Let them evolve into the story or become the seed for a new one.
#dnd tip: What will the legacy of your PCs and your campaign be?
#dnd tip: Gather all the minis for a single adventure location and let the PCs face dynamic pacs of bad guys as they go.
#dnd tip: Pick up a copy of Dungeon World. The advice in the book is outstanding for any version of D&D:
#dnd tip: Don't worry about mixing up a battle with waves of enemies. You never know who will stumble through the door.
#dnd tip: Use Story Cubes to give a quick origin flashback on that orc the PCs just killed:
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to mash up game worlds with different systems. There's no reason Dark Sun can't work with Gamma World PCs.
#dnd tip: Have another player track monster damage. You have enough to worry about.
#dnd tip: Before you start going crazy with your game world, sit with your players and get an idea for what they want out of it.
#dnd tip: Seek every opportunity to learn from the experiences of other DMs. Listen and understand before you judge them.
#dnd tip: What are the eccentricities of your nobles like?
#dnd tip: Read some of the original fiction Gygax read to learn a bit more on the origin of our hobby:
#dnd tip: Hidden Cults = Known Cults + 1
#dnd tip: Take a look at this good practical article on running a Lazy #dnd campaign by @SnarkKnight1:
#dnd tip: Have your players guess what trope you have prepared that begins their adventure. Then pick the best choice! Zing!
#dnd tip: How does love play a part (or not) in your games? Comedy? A mirror of real-life romance?
#dnd tip: Dungeon World, Fiasco, 13th Age, Fate; all of these systems have interesting ways to bring PCs together. Steal the ones you like.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to give villains interesting effects PCs might not have seen before. No reason they can't research unique magic.
#dnd tip: Always stick some sort of PC-available terrain effect to a big battle area. Give them something unique to do.
#dnd tip: Jot down a few principles by which an NPC acts in situations. Let them react to PCs as they would in real life.
#dnd tip: Keep your Pathfinder Face Cards handy during your game. You never know if a minor NPC will become major.
#dnd tip: Follow the wise words of Dungeon World: Be a fan of the PCs.
#dnd tip: Organize your minis in a way that makes it easy to reference during a game. Save time by storing them the way you use them.
#dnd tip: Quit all this boring RPG shit and get back to some core table top gaming experiences:
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to steal fluffy campaign books from any setting to use in your #dnd game.
#dnd tip: Use published adventures as inspiration for the stories you and your group share at the table.
#dnd tip: If a member of your group goes off on a wacky direction, don't shut it down, try going with it!
#dnd tip: Who are the three big forces moving things in your campaign? How are these forces rubbing up against the PCs?
#dnd tip: Need some templates for royalty? Use the aristocrats in Downton Abbey!
#dnd tip: The Closer Precursor by NiN makes for some awesome creepy dungeon music:
#dnd tip: Don't build out your campaign arcs until you've seen what sorts of characters your group brings to the table.
#dnd tip: Is this prep activity you're spending so much time on really bringing more enjoyment to your group?
#dnd tip: Make frequent use of large geographic poster maps to keep your group's imagination on the world their PCs inhabit.
#dnd tip: As you hang on loose to your story, remind your players to do the same. Let them build their story during the game.
#dnd tip: After each session, think of was to refactor stories towards the actions of the PCs.
#dnd tip: Find out what drives each character and work that into your next game's outline.
#dnd tip: Pour yourself into the setting material for your game instead of writing up your own story. How will the world react to the PCs?
#dnd tip: The most useful published setting material usually sits between game worlds and adventures. Gloomwrought, Neverwinter, Magnimar.
#dnd tip: Of all your purchases, world and geographic sourcebooks will probably last the longest and remain system independent.
#dnd tip: Use 3x5 cards to write out the quests and leads your players discover as the story unfolds.
#dnd tip: Managing the various drives and personalities of the members of your group can be the hardest part of being a good DM.
#dnd tip: If your group runs into an encounter well above their capabilities, ensure you give them enough clues to know when to run.
#dnd tip: Use published adventures and sourcebooks as seeds and material for the stories you and your group come up with during the game.
#dnd tip: "Describe your killing blow" is an easy way to draw your slayer player types into the story.
#dnd tip: Let players discover their own quests, then write the goal clearly on a 3x5 card and give it to them.
#dnd tip: Don't try to save major villains if they die early. Maybe they become minor ones and some other beast becomes the boss.
#dnd tip: Always have an idea what roaming band of bad guys might spring on the party if the players start getting bored.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to mark up your sourcebooks. Your not a museum curator. Give them some character and add to them!
#dnd tip: Always look for ways to tie the PCs together.  Get them working as a group. Nothing focuses like a murder!
#dnd tip: Use journals and letters as both hand-outs and story seed organizational aids.
#dnd tip: Follow the wise path of @aquelajames and build a campaign around a pack of adventures:
#dnd tip: Set up story hook land mines throughout your lazy mini-campaign to propel the PCs forward:
#dnd tip: Build story hooks from character backgrounds during PC creation.
#dnd tip: Dealing with and managing the different personalities at the table is probably the hardest job a DM has.
#dnd tip: Keep rules arguments down to ninety seconds then make a judgement and move on. Let people look it up between games.
#dnd tip: When in doubt of a rule, have them roll a skill or ability check and move on.
#dnd tip: If you happen to be playing Pathfinder, here's an excellent treasure generator for the Lazy DM:
#dnd tip: Do something really nice for your DM on his or her birthday! Especially if he just turned 40 =(
#dnd tip: Group having trouble understanding the game's current structure? Have core NPCs outline the potential paths the PCs might take.
#dnd tip: Use physical things like notes or objects to clarify the tying up of loose ends in a mystery campaign.
#dnd tip: Forgot a NPC's name? Change it and when your players correct you, tell them their PC heard it wrong.
#dnd tip: Make your life easy and give everyone the same amount of total experience points.
#dnd tip: Give players chances and opportunities to rebuild their characters if they aren't having fun.
#dnd tip: This is my number one single-word tip to run a great D&D game: "relax".
#dnd tip: Stealing from @dungeonworld, play to find out what happens instead of building out a pre-fab story.
#dnd tip: The "DM's Friend", a +2 bonus, works across just about any d20 game. Don't be afraid to use it to reinforce awesome ideas.
#dnd tip: If a battle starts to feel stale, don't be afraid to set the room on fire.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to use random encounters, the chaos might add quite a bit to the story.
#dnd tip: Understand both the intention and approach when adjudicating actions. Thanks @theangrydm!
#dnd tip: Dig deep into Ed Greenwood's treatise on the shit hauling trade and add the stinky details to your own game
#dnd tip: As you think up cool ideas for dungeon chambers, jot them down and save them for later!
#dnd tip: The best minis to invest in are the ones you can use most often at the table.
#dnd tip: Have a good idea for an encounter? Keep it handy and drop it into the right point in your improvised game.
#dnd tip: When writing flash fiction or handouts, make sure to make the essential information clear.
#dnd tip: Prioritize your miniature painting around the minis you plan to use at the table the most.
#dnd tip: The red priestess from Game of Thrones makes for a perfect evil wizard or cleric villain.
#dnd tip: Nothing says you can't limit your game worlds to give it a clear flavor.
#dnd tip: The random tables in the Pathfinder GameMastery Guide make the whole cost of the book worth while:
#dnd tip: The most important miniatures are those of the PCs. Sometimes it's the best way for a player to connect to a character.
#dnd tip: Don't let the rules get in the way of a good time. Make a ruling and move on.
#dnd tip: Take a lesson from @dungeon_world; if a PC does something, they do it, unless there is a distinct danger associated to failure.
#dnd tip: Instead of pre-building encounters, keep a set of potential monsters for a larger area. Choose from the set at the table.
#dnd tip: Always use character names to address your players. It keeps the sense of immersion going.
#dnd tip: In dungeons, give players useful information to help with choices. "Great heat on the left, smell of death on the right"
#dnd tip: Get a feeling for your players' desire for fluffy stories and crunchy simulations. Adjust accordingly.
#dnd tip: Build your own campaign cheat sheet with the tables, names, and other things to help you run your specific game.
#dnd tip: Keep a few easy skill and encounter ideas in your head to use in the most appropriate situation in your game.
#dnd tip: End your game with an open decision tree to force you to improvise at your next game.
#dnd tip: Use notes and letters you hand out as an organizational aid for your game. Tie your characters, NPCs, and villains together.
#dnd tip: Don't punish your group for coming up with fun "cheating" spell combinations. Give them the avenue to use them.
#dnd tip: Your most dangerous villain may never actually show up in an encounter. They're too smart to scrap it out.
#dnd tip: You don't need to plan everything, but prepare your game's opening scene and opening lines. Let it grow from there.
#dnd tip: Harvest locations and flavor-text from your favorite published adventures. Use them how they best fit your group's story.
#dnd tip: Capitalize on the flexibility of your dry-erase maps by sketching diagrams and larger maps in addition to encounter maps.
#dnd tip: Save your creative energy and use published flavor-text as much as it suits you.
#dnd tip: Foxgrove Manor in the Rise of the Runelords adventure book makes for an excellent haunted house adventure.
#dnd tip: Let players spend time exploring a city, restocking supplies, and gathering info. Throw in an encounter if it gets too quiet.
#dnd tip: Be mindful of your game's ending time. It's better to end with your players hungry than it is to leave with them tired and bored.
#dnd tip: Did one of your players miss the previous game? Ask them how they got back to the PCs. Let players drive their return.
#dnd tip: A series of small two sentence handouts leads the story better than pages of background material. Expose the story gradually.
#dnd tip: If skills are cumbersome in your game, add a set of generic attribute DC checks. 10, 15, 20 works well for easy to hard.
#dnd tip: Clarify what makes your campaign unique among campaigns. Make it simple for your players to understand these ideas.
#dnd tip: You don't need much more than a good book of monsters to run a #dnd game with just about any campaign world.
#dnd tip: Focus on one particular small area in your campaign. Don't go too big in the beginning.
#dnd tip: Missing a week? Write up some flash fiction and send it around to keep your players thinking about the game.
#dnd tip: Watch, read, and listen. Steal ideas from everywhere to incorporate into your game.
#dnd tip: Spend time immersing yourself in medieval art, armor, and architecture to build a fertile bed for #dnd improv.
#dnd tip: Keep a list of interesting characters from your favorite books, movies, and shows to keep in mind during your game.
#dnd tip: Even if you don't get to play them all, digging through other RPG rule books can give you some great ideas for your own game.
#dnd tip: Use your favorite action scenes as models for your own encounters.
#dnd tip: Keep descriptions as brief and focused as you can. Impact = message / words.
#dnd tip: Before you drop a monster on the table, take the time to review it's stat block to look for any oddities you might miss.
#dnd tip: Even PC death can lead to interesting story paths. Revenge is a great motivation.
#dnd tip: Be careful giving monsters too many surprise rounds. Ensure the PCs get the drop on the monsters once in a while.
#dnd tip: Try to find a stat-block you can reskin instead of spending your time building a monster from scratch.
#dnd tip: The substitution cypher are a great puzzle mechanic that's really easy to set up.
#dnd tip: As long as the threat of a major villain is clear, it doesn't matter if the PCs wipe it out in the first round.
#dnd tip: Simple substitution cyphers can make for interesting ancient wall scrawlings.
#dnd tip: Build some musical playlists that fit the general themes of your campaign. Play when appropriate.
#dnd tip: Turn the Pathfinder ghost monster into a solo by spreading its attack dice across multiple targets.
#dnd tip: Battle getting stale? Make sure to throw in some visual imagery or story hooks to remind players you're in a story.
#dnd tip: Have your players summarize the last session so you know what they remembered and what is important to them.
#dnd tip: Ask players about the details and background of their new fancy magic weapons. Put storytelling in their hands!
#dnd tip: Don't try to steer players away from their character concepts. Try to change your campaign to fit their ideas.
#dnd tip: Lay out city or region maps before your game to remind everyone how far they've come and how far they have to go.
#dnd tip: Like Fate Core, award action points when characters put themselves at a disadvantage.
#dnd tip: Focus on a number of creatures instead of a big powerful one to avoid getting "save or sucked".
#dnd tip: Leave journal notes on your dead bosses to teach the players a little big about the guy they just killed.
#dnd tip: Is a scene starting to drag out? Kill an NPC! Blow something up! Open a gateway to hell! Fireball the village! Red dragon attacks!
#dnd tip: Think of your larger encounter areas like big zones that resemble the levels in Dishonored with lots of different paths.
#dnd tip: Pair your traps together to keep your PCs on their toes.
#dnd tip: Always know the most important elements an NPC has to relay to a PC during an interaction. Jot them down in bullets.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to skip the boring travel parts of an adventure and get right to the meaty bits.
#dnd tip: Pair your traps together to keep your PCs on their toes.
#dnd tip: Keep a set of rich location areas on hand as your players explore areas you hadn't prepared.
#dnd tip: Skip the boring parts. Use cut scenes, montages, or groupings of skill checks to move to the interesting stuff quick.
#dnd tip: Write down interesting and usable room, zone, or encounter effects on 3x5 cards so players stay aware of them. Thanks @mikemearls
#dnd tip: The Fate Core zone aspect is a great way to think about encounter effects. Helps you focus on what matters.
#dnd tip: When running Next, write enemy ACs on a visible 3x5 card so players know if they hit or not. Thanks @jasonmflow!
#dnd tip: Write enemy ACs on a visible 3x5 card so players know if they hit or not.  Thanks @jasonmflow!
#dnd tip: Judge in favor of the players in descriptive combat. "Can I get around him without provoking?" "Sure!"
#dnd tip: Get your players to say "done" at the end of their turn to speed up rounds. This will speed up just about any game with turns.
#dnd tip: Add layers of history to the areas your PCs explore. Describe ancient statues lost in the forest.
#dnd tip: The secret accounts and ledgers of your villains can make for excellent handouts containing valuable clues.
#dnd tip: Prepare adventure locations that can be used for a variety of situations to keep your game flexible but well prepared.
#dnd tip: There's no need to be negative about other game systems in order to be positive about the one you love.
#dnd tip: Rewatch some of your favorite old movies to reinforce story seeds, adventure locations, and rich NPCs.
#dnd tip: Include an appropriate set of treasure rewards in your lazy DM toolkit.
#dnd tip: Even pre-gen characters should have some elements they can customize. Consider how 13th Age handles pregens.
#dnd tip: For a more open-ended game, keep your adventure locations abstract from the threats or villains they might find there.
#dnd tip: Keep things exciting by describing the actions of your monsters in prose rather than just the math results.
#dnd tip: Always prepare a strong beginning for your game. No one likes to see a deer in the headlights.
#dnd tip: Looking for a good way to handle a travel scene? Try @hellcowkeith's Travel Montage:
#dnd tip: If you have the means, adding some 3d components to your encounter locations can really get players excited.
#dnd tip: Build a clear "Game is starting" line to let your players know your game is beginning and side conversations should cool off.
#dnd tip: Regardless of system, four to six players tends to be ideal to give players enough screen-time during your game.
#dnd tip: Another universal tip from @13thAge; ask your players what elements of the story they want to see return in the future.
#dnd tip: Write down the main points you need to get across in your starting scene for your next game.
#dnd tip: Drive new story elements from the actions and interactions of the PCs.
#dnd tip: Always consider what fantastic element is taking place.
#dnd tip: Steal the idea of the "living dungeon" in @13thAge to make unrealistic PC-hating dungeons interesting.
#dnd tip: Build your own campaign worksheet that focuses on the elements of your game most interesting and fun for the group.
#dnd tip: Keep the true origin of your mysterious villains a secret - even from yourself! Let the truth come as the story expands:...
#dnd tip: Add one environmental element usable by your PCs and NPCs in every battle.
#dnd tip: Time to dust off your copy of Ravenloft and schedule your yearly halloween game!
#dnd tip: Pay attention to integrating new PCs into the group. It can be clumsy if you don't clear a good path to tie them together.
#dnd tip: Don't force a fight over a parlay with a hostile enemy. Let the scene play out from the motivations of PCs and NPCs.
#dnd tip: Focus on preparing the stuff that most makes you feel comfortable improvising at the table. What you actually use is secondary.
#dnd tip: When you can, try answering questions with questions to give players the agency to build out part of the world.
#dnd tip: Always know what makes any particular battle interesting. Figure out what part of the story you can tell.
#dnd tip: Try thinking about your settings and locations as their own sort of NPC. What does this dungeon actually WANT?
#dnd tip: Exploding mushrooms are a great environmental effect for nasty swamps or damp natural caverns.
#dnd tip: The search for lost magic is always a great motivation for PCs, NPCs, and villains.
#dnd tip: Get to a fight in the first hour of your game to keep things interesting.
#dnd tip: Come up with improvised interesting terrain effects for the terrain features found on pre-printed maps.
#dnd tip: Keep a hand-full of pre-printed maps handy for your next session. Don't feel like you have to use them all.
#dnd tip: Use Dungeon Command tiles for quick and flexible terrain setups with lots of little interesting details built in.
#dnd tip: Knowing what to reveal and what to keep hidden is a big part of the art of Dungeon Mastering.
#dnd tip: Describe individual character scenes while waiting for other players to show up.
#dnd tip: In 13th Age, on an icon roll of 6, give a PC a free skill success on a related skill check.
#dnd tip: Monster trapped far away? Give it an improvised ranged attack based on the mechanics of its least powerful melee attack.
#dnd tip: Try out a Theater of the Mind battle in your next game just to stretch your wings a bit.
#dnd tip: Keep Theater of the Mind battles simple, fast, and flavorful. Go out of your way to describe the action.
#dnd tip: Keep in mind that a player's investment in their character is often greater than their investment in your story.
#dnd tip: If one PC seems to outshine the rest, ensure you design encounters that let others outshine just as much.
#dnd tip: It's not enough to write a 3x5 card to prepare for your game, you have to READ the stupid thing DURING the game to get the benefit
#dnd tip: Finding creative entrances for the PCs of part-time players is a great time to improve your improvisational techniques.
#dnd tip: Keep a list of interesting story bits to drop in throughout your adventure at opportune moments.
#dnd tip: Find ways for PCs to use environmental hazards to their advantage. Reward them for doing so.
#dnd tip: If the PCs find a way to circumvent a particularly dangerous threat, let them do so and applaud their ingenuity.
#dnd tip: Finding the right balance between story and combat can be one of the hardest talents we DMs face.
#dnd tip: The 13th Age Living Dungeon is a great way to justify your convoluted contrived dungeon tropes. The dungeon IS an NPC!
#dnd tip: What makes your next battle unique among battles? What element of the story will it move forward?
#dnd tip: If you're stuck for ideas, go back to the PC's backgrounds and themes and build off of them.
