#dnd tip: Two-stage battles, with the second enemy or set of enemies coming in near the end, makes for a great epic fight.
#dnd tip: Follow the wise words of @rdonoghue and build some of your game off of the PCs' strengths.
#dnd tip: Bad guys who surrender are great vehicles to give PCs useful information. It's commonly used but still great.
#dnd tip: Keep a list of character hooks your players care about on hand while pondering your next adventure.
#dnd tip: End your mini-campaign with a "what happens two years later?" montage. Let the players drive it.
#dnd tip: Listen to the discussion of players to each other to understand what they are really absorbing from your bullshit story.
#dnd tip: Published adventures make great guidelines but never feel like you have to run them word for word. Make them your own.
#dnd tip: Find out what makes each player love their PC. Use that as a cornerstone for the expanding story.
#dnd tip: Everybody poops! Who is your Lord of Sewers?
#dnd tip: A fast and easy way to tie a group to an adventure is to let them, as a group, choose a single faction to already align with.
#dnd tip: Flash forwards are a great way to show your group the excitement that's about to come.
#dnd tip: If your players come up with a villain they want to hunt, replace the one you had come up with that they don't know about.
#dnd tip: Location maps under a plexiglass sheet makes for a great table setting for your D&D game.
#dnd tip: If the party splits up during an investigation scene, make sure to switch between the groups often to keep the players engaged.
#dnd tip: Preparing interesting NPCs, their motivations, and interesting adventure locations is always worth while.
#dnd tip: Refer back to a nice overland map as the PCs travel throughout the adventure. Give them a sense of place.
#dnd tip: Don't be a slave to canon. Your instance of a shared game world is yours to twist and change to keep your game fun.
#dnd tip: Sometimes "majority rules" doesn't work for a group's decision. Sometimes it needs to be unanimous if the stakes are high.
#dnd tip: Focus your preparation on interesting locations and rich NPCs. Let the story grow naturally at the table.
#dnd tip: It's always worth reviewing what people enjoyed and didn't enjoy at your game. Don't take criticism personally.
#dnd tip: How did your past year of #dnd go? How do you want your next year to go? Reflect!
#dnd tip: Always consider the variables that make scenes interesting: environment, NPCs, evolving circumstances.
#dnd tip: Build opportunities for each character to shine. Give them a chance to be the best in a scene.
#dnd tip: Steal your favorite adventure locations from any published adventure you can find. Aim for interesting and unique details.
#dnd tip: You can always steal NPC ideas from your favorite book, movie, or TV characters.
#dnd tip: Steal NPC physical descriptions from one fictional character and the personality from another so players can't guess who it is.
#dnd tip: Instead of plotting out your campaign, set the pieces in place, push it forward with a story hook, and see where it goes.
#dnd tip: Always remember, the PCs are the real heroes of the game. Not your favorite NPC, not your game world, and not your story.
#dnd tip: Random encounters can sometimes lead your game's story into awesome new directions. Don't fear them.
#dnd tip: Consider adding Jarasson, Founder of Guilds, into your city for a bit of added NPC variety.
#dnd tip: Railroading isn't always evil. Sometimes your group just wants to watch their PC mechanics work.
#dnd tip: Is your group taking some time off? Take the time to consider what they enjoy most and developing interesting adventure locations.
#dnd tip: Good video games can be an excellent source of inspiration for your tabletop game.
#dnd tip: Always include a clear villain in your game. Moral ambiguity isn't always that much fun.
#dnd tip: How are the three pillars of #dnd; exploration, roleplaying, and combat;  incorporated into your game?
#dnd tip: Incorporate in-game holidays to match real-world holidays to give some feeling of seasons into your world.
#dnd tip: Adventure seeds, fantastic locations, and interesting NPCs are the three cornerstones of a good #dnd adventure.
#dnd tip: Not all groups thrive on difficult choices. Don't overload your players with moral quandaries all the time.
#dnd tip: Always get to the point with your flavor text or narratives. Know the important elements and get them out fast and back to action.
#dnd tip: Take material from any game system. Don't worry about what brand goes with what system, steal from everywhere.
#dnd tip: If level 1 and 2 feels too wimpy for your more advanced #dndnext players, don't fret starting at level 3.
#dnd tip: When converting or running old modules, look for the seeds that made them unique and fantastic. Cut the boring shit.
#dnd tip: Seek every chance to get feedback on your game. Always look for ways to improve it and make it more fun for the group.
#dnd tip: Seize the opportunity to let your players grab the story and run. Don't shut them down to tell your own story.
#dnd tip: Instead of trying to mold the PCs around your published adventure, mold the adventure around the PCs.
#dnd tip: Always favor changing the story to bring the PCs backgrounds into play.
#dnd tip: Seek to understand what interests each of your players in your game the most and try to give it to them often.
#dnd tip: Be ready to abbreviate sections of your adventure to fit the time you have allowed.
#dnd tip: Take a break to figure out how to make an unexpected success interesting:
#dnd tip: Turn unexpected successes into interesting story turns like @mikemearls:
#dnd tip: Follow the wise words of @mikemearls and let your old campaign die to grow a new one:
#dnd tip: With any encounter, what bit of information will the PCs learn that moves the story forward?
#dnd tip: From @montecook, don't ever feel like you have to fill everything out. Leave blanks.
#dnd tip: Notes between NPCs are a great physical reminder to players of their potential paths, options, villains, and quests.
#dnd tip: Not every clue needs to make sense at the time the PCs receive it.
#dnd tip: Combining traps is a great way to make every trap unique and deadly. A spiked pit filled with exploding fire pots? Whooyeaahhh!
#dnd tip: Reward players with +1 single-use bonuses when they remember NPC names or intricate plot threads.
#dnd tip: Don't forget to use your handouts as a way to organize your game's threads.
#dnd tip: Never forget that your primary intent is cultivating a great time with good friends. That, and TPKs...Thanks @theangrydm!
#dnd tip: How easy or hard it is for your group to uncover clues is an element of your game worth paying attention to.
#dnd tip: Before you put a lot of brain time into a new campaign, ensure it's the kind of campaign your players want to play.
#dnd tip: Spend some time inserting treasure into your adventure. It's easily forgotten. Every sword has a name.
#dnd tip: Dungeon Command tiles make for quick random encounter maps including interesting terrain features.
#dnd tip: It's always worth having a few battle maps ready for the areas your PCs may choose to visit.
#dnd tip: Choose a different spell or two to differentiate your spellcaster NPCs. Flavor them to the theme of the NPC.
#dnd tip: The random encounter charts in the original DMG work just as well today as they did 35 years ago.
#dnd tip: For big events, spend the time to really plan out an interesting encounter. Railroading isn't always bad.
#dnd tip: Before you plan your campaign, let your players build PC backstories. Use what they build to generate ideas for the world.
#dnd tip: Think less of your game as a story arc and more as a free flowing and ongoing tale.
#dnd tip: Give your PCs some piles of mooks to eat through so they can remember what it's like to be powerful
#dnd tip: Let your players decide what limits you might incorporate into your game such as a limited set of 13th Age icons.
#dnd tip: Conventions are the perfect time to run that new game system you've always wanted to run.
#dnd tip: Know where you might cut your material to get your game to end on time.
#dnd tip: During your descriptions, don't worry about going from big to small details. Focus in and zoom out.
#dnd tip: A pile of one-hit bad guys who still can throw out damage make for a fast and threatening encounter.
#dnd tip: Give Story Cubes to your players and have them describe the history of every bad guy they kill.
#dnd tip: If pressed for time, replace monsters with nasty environmental effects like poison gas.
#dnd tip: When preparing a new campaign, write a short "five things about this campaign" guide to guide both you and your players.
#dnd tip: Don't veto the backgrounds your players come up with, use them to enrich the campaign all of you build together.
#dnd tip: When starting a new campaign, pick one particular area and focus on it. Pour in fantastic locations and deep NPCs.
#dnd tip: Spend some time coming up with interesting magic items based on the PCs to sprinkle throughout your campaign.
#dnd tip: Follow the keen advice of Dungeon World: ask questions and use the answers to build adventures.
#dnd tip: Spend time considering what tools you need to aid your ability to improvise during your game.
#dnd tip: What's your campaign about?
#dnd tip: Take @robheinsoo's advice and don't sweat the results of the @13thAge icon rolls too much.
#dnd tip: Pay attention to the dead spaces in your game so you know what to prep for your next session.
#dnd tip: Have an idea what your key NPCs are going to say when approached. Nothing's worse than uncomfortable PC / NPC silence.
#dnd tip: Always have three paths ready to offer in case your group doesn't really know where they want to head next.
#dnd tip: Experiment with interesting house rules on the GM side of the table but let your players know what you're up to.
#dnd tip: "What do you think?" and "you tell me!" are fine ways to skirt the issue that you don't know what the hell you're talking about.
#dnd tip: Sometimes your player aren't looking for open-ended storytelling. Give them some plots and fights to keep them engaged.
#dnd tip: Ask your players what they enjoyed and what they would have changed at the end of each game you run.
#dnd tip: give your group at least one interesting NPC to roleplay with each game.
#dnd tip: Get creative with your set-piece battlespaces. Use Legos, Lincoln Logs, whatever!
#dnd tip: Try to add at least one interesting environmental effect to each battle you run that bit PCs and monsters can use.
#dnd tip: Describe powerful spellcasters as using magical forms of protection to give them such high hit points.
#dnd tip: Give your players 3 + infinite options. They can pick one of three clear paths or choose their own in a new direction.
#dnd tip: What is the first cool scene and setting you want to describe at the beginning of your next adventure?
#dnd tip: Take some time after your game to review what worked, what didn't, and what areas you wish you had spent more time preparing.
#dnd tip: Did your PCs turn 180 degrees away from that awesome dungeon you prepared? Maybe it should move 180 degrees as well!
#dnd tip: Separate dungeons and encounter areas from monsters and villains to help you customize encounters based on PC decisions.
#dnd tip: Don't force player participation in group storytelling if they don't want to do it. Some folks want to relax and enjoy the ride.
#dnd tip: Improving improvisation skills takes practice and time. Be patient and persistent.
#dnd tip: Keep three villains in mind and consider how their actions and motivations affect the story.
#dnd tip: If you can't remember the PC's names, you likely aren't paying enough attention to them.
#dnd tip: Awesome fiction spawns from mashed up ideas. Combine two traps, two characters, two dungeons, or two scenes into one awesome one.
#dnd tip: Use skill checks to uncover parts of a puzzle when players have a hard time figuring it out. Fail forward with hard moves.
#dnd tip: Split up battles with exploration, puzzles, investigation, and roleplaying to change up the pace of your game.
#dnd tip: Keep battles interesting by mixing up monster types or adding an interesting dangerous terrain feature.
#dnd tip: Try to start your game with action. What does the world do? What can the PCs do?
#dnd tip: Group players together that are working on different parts of a scene so they're not yelling over one another.
#dnd tip: Use skill checks or @13thAge icon rolls to give clues to puzzles when people are stuck.
#dnd tip: Resist the urge to tell players what they missed or how the story could have gone but didn't based on their actions.
#dnd tip: @montecook's Return to the Temple of Elemental Evil has some fantastic maps to hack into your game.
#dnd tip: My most valuable tip: Relax, have fun, and go with what the players give you.
#dnd tip: "Theater of the mind" combat works well in simple rooms with a single type of monster.
#dnd tip: Use handouts to organize NPCs, locations, and motivations for both you and your players.
#dnd tip: Check with each of your players independently face to face to see how they feel about the game and the atmosphere.
#dnd tip: If a player's assumption ends up being better than the truth, go with it. The truth is highly malleable in your #dnd game.
#dnd tip: Fill your "theater of the mind" battles with flavor and detail. Bulbous otherworldly spiders slick and dripping with black oil.
#dnd tip: Always keep track of your time and pacing of your game. Use a stopwatch or alarm to keep track. Thanks @JTGrummell!
#dnd tip: Get everyone's attention by starting your adventure with some action. Nothing gets a table's attention like "roll for initiative!"
#dnd tip: Trim down exposition and narration. Stick to important details and turn the story back over to the players fast.
#dnd tip: You can hide some shoddy story work or poor sandboxing with a beautiful and interesting encounter area.
#dnd tip: Leave open the party's next course of action until the beginning of your next game so there's no way to prep ahead of time.
#dnd tip: Assign a table auditor to check on those strange character abilities that just don't seem right.
#dnd tip: Keep a few groups of monsters at your PC's power level on hand for improvised encounters.
#dnd tip: Immerse yourself in great fiction (books, movies, TV shows) and steal liberally for your game.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to fix small errors in your story threads. Embrace the fun with an old sage named Lord Retcon who fixes truths.
#dnd tip: Think about ways to improvise the goals in battles where slaughter isn't the only choice.
#dnd tip: Know when to call for a break during your game, both for yourself and for the group.
#dnd tip: What feature makes your town fantastic and memorable?
#dnd tip: Take adventure inspiration from interesting tactical maps, miniatures, and artwork you come across.
#dnd tip: Don't force the direction of a scene. Progress the scene on the actions of the PCs.
#dnd tip: Powerful monsters should mean something. Avoid low level lichs, death knights, and beholders.
#dnd tip: Don't eclipse the actions of PCs with the actions of NPCs. The PCs are the heroes of your story, not your favorite NPC.
#dnd tip: Releasing a bound beast is a great potential "combat out" for an encounter.
#dnd tip: Ask your players to summarize the game to one another and use what they remember to steer its direction.
#dnd tip: Use @13thAge Icon rolls of 5 to determine which evil agenda moves forward.
#dnd tip: Have players describe the history behind weapons or magic items they find.
#dnd tip: If you stick in a large environmental effect into your encounter, make sure PCs have a way to screw with it. Don't just make it so
#dnd tip: If you only have one type of monster in a fight, make the fight fast or it will get pretty boring.
#dnd tip: Combine two encounters, a clear goal, and some interesting encounter effects into your own Lair Assault style scenario.
#dnd tip: A plexiglass sheet over a blank gridded flip mat makes for excellent dry-erase battle map options.
#dnd tip: Use a mix of simple narrative combat with more detailed big-set battles.
#dnd tip: Put out interesting terrain into your battle space and let players improvise their use. Say yes!
#dnd tip: Physical icon tokens in your @13thAge for 5 and 6 rolls gives players the ability to improvise their uses and saves you energy.
#dnd tip: Comb through old adventures, find interesting rooms, and skip the boring parts.
#dnd tip: Even in an open improvised game, it's important that goals are clear for the PCs.
#dnd tip: If you have more than five PCs, you'll likely have to step up the number of monsters even more to make up for PC synergy.
#dnd tip: Don't force improvised montages on players. Let them volunteer for it.
#dnd tip: Key location questions: Why is it interesting? What is it now? What did it used to be? What makes it fantastic?
#dnd tip: Bosses in boss fights almost always need a way to protect themselves from a PC nuclear strike.
#dnd tip: Many players don't mind a railroaded story. Some are just happy to enjoy the ride.
#dnd tip: There's room for interesting choices even in railroad campaigns. NPC interaction, kill or free villains, battle tactics, etc.
#dnd tip: Give players a choice to kill or capture villains on defeat. Dropping to zero hp doesn't have to mean death.
#dnd tip: Always consider how NPC's would react to the words or deeds of the PCs. Don't force their reaction.
#dnd tip: Don't presume how PCs or players will approach or follow through on a scene. Go with their direction.
#dnd tip: Keep a portfolio of interesting, relevant, fantastic, and detailed adventure locations always on hand.
#dnd tip: Write and keep an NPC dossier when building NPCs on the fly. It's easy to forget them.
#dnd tip: Use each battle as a way to experiment with challenge and difficulty. Make small yet interesting changes to see how they work out.
#dnd tip: Not every battle needs to be a balanced challenge. Short and easy battles can reveal a deeper world not built around the PCs.
#dnd tip: Give clues into the origins of interesting NPCs to keep your players' guessing. If they guess right, reinforce their victory.
#dnd tip: break up exposition and narrative by turning the spotlight back to the PCs often, especially if they're split up.
#dnd tip: Experiment with other game systems and steal liberally to make your main game better.
#dnd tip: Discovery is a huge draw in our games. What can the PCs discover in your next game?
#dnd tip: Keep note of the names and fates of NPCs the PCs let go. Where are they now? What are they doing?
#dnd tip: Give players a regular recap of the major factions they face and the major decisions that lay ahead.
#dnd tip: When teaching someone new to #dnd, begin with the concept of cooperative storytelling and explain the idea of rolling d20 checks.
#dnd tip: Many of the techniques for protecting elite bosses work well in @13thAge as they did in 4th Edition.
#dnd tip: Use poster maps to give you ideas of the dungeons the PCs may explore.
#dnd tip: Being distracted players back to the game with a calm "what does your character do?"
#dnd tip: New players can easily get lost in lingo and acronyms. Take the time to explain them.
#dnd tip: Let new players reference popular examples (Aragorn, Hawkeye, the Hulk) when defining their characters.
#dnd tip: Go ahead and let your players know how many hit points a monster has. Save your mysteries for elsewhere.
#dnd tip: Take all advice, including these tips, at your peril. Most tips are hypotheses and experiments stated in the declarative.
#dnd tip: Keep handy a list of monsters appropriate for the PCs to face based on power level or location. Improvise battles as they fit.
#dnd tip: Let the players decide what loot is in a treasure horde. Build their results into the story.
#dnd tip: Vampires and their spawn make for great waves of monsters that mix into the PCs in mist form.
#dnd tip: You can railroad your encounters and locations but still give PCs lots of opportunities to make meaningful choices.
#dnd tip: Don't bother doing much more than an outline beyond your next session. A lot can happen between now and then.
#dnd tip: Use story dice and face cards to help you avoid stereotypical storylines. Thanks @wamplify!
#dnd tip: Have a good handle on the appropriate DCs for your potential improvised environmental effects or challenges.
#dnd tip: A good evening's adventure has four to six scenes: intro, encounter, exploration, encounter, ending is a solid model.
#dnd tip: If you see a pile of narrative coming on, ask yourself what meaningful choices the PCs can make as part of it.
#dnd tip: Staged multi-wave battles are a great way to build huge epic fights without wiping out the party with too many monsters.
#dnd tip: Start your adventures off with some action! Save the background and story for bits and pieces interleaved within action.
#dnd tip: Send emails to your players with narrative you don't want to bother describing at the table. Work off of what they remember.
#dnd tip: Mix dungeon tiles, dwarven forge, and dry-erase maps for some really interesting 3d battlescapes.
#dnd tip: Hit points represent whatever you and your group want them to represent. Quit worrying about what the pundits say.
#dnd tip: You can use @13thAge style distances to speed up your #dnd Next game with "near", "far", and "engaged" distances.
#dnd tip: You can use #dnd's "inspiration" mechanic in just about any game that doesn't already have something like this.
#dnd tip: #dnd's "inspiration" can be used in ways outside of just gaining advantage. It can be a license to bend the rules or even the...
#dnd tip: If you're nervous but curious about narrative combat, try it out on a small battle against a single type of monster in a simple...
#dnd tip: Sometimes a boss monster getting killed with a single powerful attack defines the Rule of Cool. Go with it.
#dnd tip: Video game soundtracks make for great background #dnd music. Try Assassins Creed 4, Borderlands 2, and Mass Effect 3.
#dnd tip: Always seek to add interesting choices into narrative scenes of exploration. How can the PCs make a difference?
#dnd tip: Boss monsters should almost always have defending support monsters at their sides.
#dnd tip: There are few game aids more useful than a Paizo flip mat and a dry-erase marker.
#dnd tip: When adding a sixth player to a group, you'll likely need more than just an equal amount of additional monsters.
#dnd tip: Let players choose NPCs to lead charges in an epic battle. Make sure there's good reason to choose the right NPC for the right...
#dnd tip: Think of your adventure as a current situation with variables rather than a series of scenes one after another.
#dnd tip: When you have a boss monster, make sure it has minions who can put the threat on those the boss can't attack.
#dnd tip: Reskin monsters to create monster-behaving environmental effects like living fire or animated traps.
#dnd tip: Take a moment to restate the layout and situation of the scene to aid wandering minds.
#dnd tip: Study artwork from other RPGs to fuel your imagination for whatever game you play.
#dnd tip: Make it clear when it's OK to split the party up for multiple lines of investigation.
#dnd tip: Inattention between GMs and players can self propigate into a viscious cycle. Pay attention to the inattentive player.
#dnd tip: Ask yourself why your players might be thinking that you're working against them instead of with them.
#dnd tip: The wild magic chart on the new #dnd PHB page 104 makes for an excellent wild magic area effect. @gsllcs was here!
#dnd tip: Is your world full of excitement and adventure or does it simply make the lives of the PCs difficult?
#dnd tip: If players are gravitating towards PCs who act like obnoxious asses, remind them of the importance of fun over accurate RPing.
#dnd tip: If your players struggle for threads of investigation, give them something to grab onto.
#dnd tip: Its an easy trick to grab attention by starting your adventure off with a battle.
#dnd tip: Use @13thage style Icon rolls to keep track of the long-term motions of allies and villains.
#dnd tip: Five players is really the sweet spot for a fun dynamic game. Keep your group between 4 and 6 players.
#dnd tip: It's easy to pay attention to the charismatic player. Consciously steer yourself towards the quiet ones.
#dnd tip: Plot clues may not be nearly as easy for your players to figure out as you think.
#dnd tip: Be prepared to improvise motivations for PCs to move forward. Why do they care?
#dnd tip: Running a group to the end of their ropes? Make the story reason's for their fatigue clear.
#dnd tip: Avoid repeatedly sending your group against an overpowered foe. Don't make your players feel weak too often.
#dnd tip: Build dungeons as actual working environments. If this were a real place, how would it work in daily life?
#dnd tip: Looking for some interesting gang members? Use SAMCRO as your models!
#dnd tip: Are players choosing actions well outside of your plans? What has to change to go with their ideas?
#dnd tip: Feel free to switch from abstract narrative combat to gridded combat depending on what would be most fun at the moment.
#dnd tip: When teaching new players, focus on the core mechanic and dive into the story. The rest will come in time.
#dnd tip: Use the Wild Magic table from the player's handbook to make some fun chaos magic area effects.
#dnd tip: Feel free to break out of the perspective of the PCs to let them get a glimpse of the villains they face.
#dnd tip: Throw a handful of random trinkets from the player's handbook into various loot hoards the PCs come across.
#dnd tip: Add your own villain or henchmen to a published adventure so you have one who is all your own.
#dnd tip: A good DM plays in other peoples' games and takes notes on what works well and what doesn't.
#dnd tip: Throw in one to two additional bad guys for each extra PC above five.
#dnd tip: With the extra room in your 5e game, relax and let players spend some time considering their options.
#dnd tip: Even in published adventures there is room to add a fantastic element. You can't go wrong with ancient huge statues.
#dnd tip: You don't always have to have your players' attention all the time. Sometimes they just want to chill out and check Twitter.
#dnd tip: Add some flavor to your random bad guys. What is the name of the mercenary company? What makes them special?
#dnd tip: Looking for some great NPC templates for your random mercenary company? Look no further!
#dnd tip: Build out NPC details and implement them on whichever NPC the PC's attention focuses on.
#dnd tip: When heading into a location, give players the freedom to plan their course of action. Don't force or promote one particular path.
#dnd tip: Be ready to railroad an adventure if your players are becoming decision weary.
#dnd tip: Add in details for a few colorful NPCs in any group of random attackers.
#dnd tip: Give ambushers with the high ground "advantage" on attacks to make them that much more dangerous.
#dnd tip: When adding a new player with a new PC, go with whatever narrative gets them into the group quickly.
#dnd tip: When running published adventures, change the gender of NPCs or villains to shake up outdated stereotypes.
#dnd tip: Telegraph gameplay styles into in-game choices. Head into the camp for combat, sneak in from the back for infiltration checks.
#dnd tip: Carefully balance spotlight time for each PC in interaction and RP scenes just as you do with initiative in combat.
#dnd tip: Mix in new monsters if you find PCs facing the same foes over and over again.
#dnd tip: Give advantage on skill checks when players have a particularly good idea. Use advantage as a reward for creativity.
#dnd tip: It can be hard to give each PC enough attention when you have more than five players.
#dnd tip: Be careful not to pick on the one loud and powerful PC in combat all the time. It's easy to do.
#dnd tip: Let the dice decide who gets attacked when monsters don't have a super clear target.
#dnd tip: Try out different combat styles (narrative, loose, gridded) and ask your group what they think of them. Tune to suit.
#dnd tip: Give #dnd PCs options to take short rests in dynamic dungeons. Hidden or defendable rooms for example.
#dnd tip: Give weary PCs a "battle surge" that acts as an immediate short rest before boss fights.
#dnd tip: Plan the main points or your narrative ahead of time so you don't spend an hour talking bullshit.
#dnd tip: Give players the hit that caves and dungeons may be well trapped so they know to watch out.
#dnd tip: Give every major magic item a history, origin, and a name to make them unique and special.
#dnd tip: Do you know the names of all the PCs in your game? That's more important than almost any other part of the game.
#dnd tip: NPC wizards might have to rely on Shield to protect themselves. They're big targets.
#dnd tip: Having trouble coming up with interesting loot for your 5e game while we wait for the DMG? Use the 1e DMG's random loot tables!
#dnd tip: If you have a lot of players, reveal the defenses of monsters to speed up combat.
#dnd tip: Just because an enemy dropped to zero doesn't mean it died. Maybe it's coughing blood saying "Wait! I have useful information!"
#dnd tip: How would more vulnerable villains protect themselves from being the lightning rod of attacks?
#dnd tip: Take your time to read the spell lists so you can get ideas on spells NPCs and enemies would use.
#dnd tip: Re-flavor spells based on the background and theme of the enemies who cast them. "Tiamat's Wrath!" instead of Sacred Flame.
#dnd tip: What makes the current location fantastic in the eyes of the PCs? You have a billion dollar effects budget. Use it!
#dnd tip: Instead of a random encounter, plan out a fun one-battle side adventure to throw into your game at the right moment.
#dnd tip: Not all dungeons need to be giant sprawling complexes. Some might be only two or three rooms with a small story attached.
#dnd tip: It's ok to let your PCs steamroll over an encounter. Some of the most memorable battles are one-sided slaughterfests.
#dnd tip: Adding PCs above four to your party may decrease the challenge of an encounter more than linearly. Add two beasts per PC.
#dnd tip: Review your PCs' goals, backgrounds, motivations, and story hooks before you run your game.
#dnd tip: Let your players' interest determine which NPCs become the focus instead of you or your published adventure.
#dnd tip: Read and enjoy #dnd fantasy novels and the Monster Manual to come up with interesting adventure ideas.
#dnd tip: This is a big one. Make sure to reward inspiration to the quiet people at your table. Don't just give it to loudmouths.
#dnd tip: Look at your list of players and ask yourself who needs more spotlight at your game.
#dnd tip: Read published adventures until you can see the fantastic locations in your head. If you can see them, so will your players.
#dnd tip: Take note of the quiet gamers at your table and give them good attention.
#dnd tip: Come up with a loot system that removes any potential bias you might have for one PC over another.
#dnd tip: In a linear adventure, ensure the players understand the clear mission that sits in front of them.
#dnd tip: Understand the proficiencies of the PCs so you know what challenges and rewards to put in front of them.
#dnd tip: Protect boss villains by having them together in pairs.
#dnd tip: Put out big poster maps of the game world to remind the players where they fit in the world.
#dnd tip: Too many players? Create an "on call" list for those who can substitute in when a regular can't make it.
#dnd tip: Get some one-on-one feedback on your game and really listen to what they have to say about it.
#dnd tip: Small props can make a big difference in your game. Get some model trees or covered wagons to make a scene pop.
#dnd tip: Try your hand at narrative combat with a small battle against a single type of foe in an uncomplicated environment.
#dnd tip: A good play group takes careful cultivation. Learn how to bring them in and quit worrying about how it "should" work.
#dnd tip: Use the current seasons and holidays as models for the seasons and holidays taking place in your fantasy RPG.
#dnd tip: Use @asmor's CR calculator before you rain Bugbears on your level 3 party.
#dnd tip: Give out inspiration to players who write the page numbers of their spells on their spell list sheets.
#dnd tip: Pay attention PC factions and potential renown points when running @DnD_AdvLeague games.
#dnd tip: Don't forget the importance of quantitative rewards such as experience, levels, gold, loot, and other tangible rewards.
#dnd tip: Reading fiction set in your game's world is fun homework for adding depth and details to your game.
#dnd tip: Did one or more of your players figure out your secret super early? Don't continue to hide it, make it interesting some other way.
#dnd tip: Be ready for your players to say "nah, not interested" if they don't bite on one of your story hooks. What will you do then?
#dnd tip: Seasons and weather are great ways to make your adventure feel unique and part of a living world.
#dnd tip: Throw in side adventures that focus on one particular PC's background. Let one PC be THE hero once in a while.
#dnd tip: Give weapons fun names like "blacksong" and "vengeance" and "sky's end". They're not just +1 weapons.
#dnd tip: Old D&D Classic adventures and sourcebooks are a great way to pour yourself into Realmslore.
#dnd tip: What is your fantastic location? What did it used to be?
#dnd tip: let PCs upgrade weapons near and dear to their hearts instead of forcing them to switch to a better one.
#dnd tip: Want to make that bad boss last a little longer? Make it two partner bosses instead!
#dnd tip: Mix limited wishlist rewards with random loot when distributing treasure.
#dnd tip: Base in-game weather on current real-world weather to help players sympathize with their PCs.
#dnd tip: Give enemies a cool name even if they're only ever seen once. Everyone and everything has an identity.
#dnd tip: What is the bare minimum you need to have on hand to run a good game?
#dnd tip: Every magic weapon should have a cool name.
#dnd tip: Spend time understanding the spells best used by enemy spell casters. Play them smart.
#dnd tip: Find opportunities to slide in personal quests for individual PCs.
#dnd tip: Mix individually-selected magic items with random items to mix balance with random interest.
#dnd tip: Break up stories into specific clues or tweet-sized lore discoverable with PC skill checks and investigation.
#dnd tip: Start out by digging right into the middle of the action rather than spewing flavor text for 20 minutes.
#dnd tip: Never worry about going outside the bounds of a published adventure. It's YOUR adventure. Feel free to make it your own.
#dnd tip: Mix up weapons on humanoid monsters to add some flavor with a touch of mechanics in an otherwise straightforward battle.
#dnd tip: What are your villains up to right now?
#dnd tip: Dream sequences where Tiamat wipes out your level 5 party may seem like fun but not everyone will appreciate the nuance.
#dnd tip: Introduce campaign villains so your PCs can build their own Kill Bill style "Death List 5".
#dnd tip: Even if your game is mostly investigation, exploration, and interaction, throw in a battle so the action folks have fun.
#dnd tip: Work with great rolls for NPC interaction. Maybe that villain becomes the party's new toady with a well-placed charisma roll.
#dnd tip: Take some time to read over the spell lists so you know what options your players have at their disposal.
#dnd tip: Semi-intelligent weapons are a great way to give PCs a clue they might otherwise miss. It's the literal clue-stick.
#dnd tip: Use unique miniatures for villains and show them continually so players can remember them visually.
#dnd tip: Did an unnamed villain escape? What is their name? Where do they go next?
#dnd tip: Instead of having a secret cabal of NPC choose the storyline, put the PCs in the cabal itself! Give them political power.
#dnd tip: Keep the story clear but don't shy away from interesting complications. Let the PCs insert these complications as they play.
#dnd tip: In a published adventure, always feel free to replace a new NPC with an old one that your players know already.
#dnd tip: Are assassins hunting down the PCs? What clues are they discovering? How are they hunting them down?
#dnd tip: Large enemy organizations have the same communication problems as real ones. Often one side of an org doesn't know of the other.
#dnd tip: Running a 5e Mage? Shield, Misty Step, and Counterspell are lifesavers. Consider a quick gulp of a potion of invulnerability.
#dnd tip: How does your 1,000 year history actually affect what the PCs are doing at your next game?
#dnd tip: Follow the story threads between episodes of a published adventure. What HAS to happen to keep things on track?
#dnd tip: Loose wish lists are a good way to know what treasure you might seed into your adventures.
#dnd tip: Take inspiration from everywhere. Have a cool mini? Who is the villain it represents?
#dnd tip: Use miniatures or face cards to represent major villains and reinforce them with your players. Names alone are hard to remember.
#dnd tip: When designing your own mini-systems to drop into your game, make sure they're easy to take back out if they suck.
#dnd tip: Test out house rules by trying them in just a couple of scenes or battles rather than an all-or-nothing insertion.
#dnd tip: Jot down interesting character hooks that come from the PCs as you play. Review them often.
#dnd tip: Rewire quest lines to fit the backgrounds of the PCs for built-in story investment.
#dnd tip: Is your published adventure heading to a boring location? Wrap it in your own ideas until you love it.
#dnd tip: Give your PCs a stake and vote at bureaucratic council meetings so they aren't jus waiting for orders.
#dnd tip: In published adventures replace new NPCs with old ones your PCs already know and love.
#dnd tip: When houseruling, ask yourself what you're REALLY trying to accomplish. Do you really need it?
#dnd tip: Write adventure summaries between sessions. If they're too long and complicated, that may be an indicator.
#dnd tip: Sidequests can be fun but give players indicators that it won't screw up main quests if followed.
#dnd tip: Design encounters so each PC has an opportunity to show off what they do best.
#dnd tip: Two enemy spellcasters make it much harder to pin down the one big enemy damage dealer.
#dnd tip: If players stall in a scene, lay out the decisions and give each one a chance to choose.
#dnd tip: When calling for a player vote, check with the minority voters to ensure their game isn't ruined because of the choice.
#dnd tip: Give players a chance to "flash back" to a city if they forgot to buy something they wish they had.
#dnd tip: Take some time to think about what sorts of magical things (if any) are available in small towns or big cities.
#dnd tip: Using a Mage from the 5e Monster Manual? Give it a 16 Con and +27 hit points to make it a bit more survivable.
#dnd tip: Another tip for 5e Mages. Shield, Counterspell, and Misty Step are your best defensive spells. Mages also have Mage Armor precast
#dnd tip: Build your own "random" encounter lists based on the direction and story of your campaign.
#dnd tip: Avoid random encounters that have no connection to the rest of the story.
#dnd tip: Use "random" encounters as a way to show players the details of the world and its history.
#dnd tip: Leave open lots of options for PCs to navigate through sandboxed mysteries, heists, and investigations.
#dnd tip: Always consider how you can incorporate the PCs' backgrounds into your next game session.
#dnd tip: Combat shouldn't always be a negotiation or stealth failure state. How can combat be a reward instead of a penalty?
#dnd tip: Spending ten minutes to write a summary of your last session forces you to consider the actions of the PCs rather than just story.
#dnd tip: Use the rules for "adjudicating area effects" on page 249 of the DMG to handle blasts, bursts, cones, and lines in narrative.
#dnd tip: Take your DM screen and lay it flat so you don't build a wall between you and the players. You're all on the same side.
#dnd tip: Use hoard treasure rewards pg. DMG page 137 every couple of game sessions to make your life easier and the game more interesting.
#dnd tip: You don't have to memorize everything. Know enough of the rules to be confident in moving the game forward.
#dnd tip: What makes your next adventure interesting and exciting? What are the hooks per session and per encounter?
#dnd tip: Don't like the battle you're seeing in a published adventure? What battle do you wish was there? Do that.
#dnd tip: Is your group a bit more powerful than expected? Max the monster's hit points from their hit dice instead of using the average.
#dnd tip: When preparing your next game, start with a review of the PCs, their backgrounds, and motivations. Build off of those.
#dnd tip: Roll on tables in the Dungeon Master's Guide to help break out of stereotypes.
#dnd tip: Don't like the way a boss battle played out? Maybe they were just a henchman for a silent overseer.
#dnd tip: Use two interesting monsters in a battle so the PCs don't just focus fire on a single one and kill it in the first round.
#dnd tip: Pay attention to your reference material and DM screen. It's easy to overlook the stuff right in front of you.
#dnd tip: Write down the main interesting things you want to get across in your next session. Reference it often during the game.
#dnd tip: Switch out NPC and monster weapons to make each one of them unique.
#dnd tip: Turn maguffins into relics so those useless objects become things the PCs can use.
#dnd tip: Dealing with overpowered PCs or a strong group? Increase encounter power by tuning around  one extra PC than you actually have.
#dnd tip: Use physical clues, skill checks, and NPC narratives to spell out the interesting history of the region.
#dnd tip: Set up two or three ways the PCs can find a vital clue or required physical item.
#dnd tip: Go with what seems the most fun first and then what makes sense in the scene second.
#dnd tip: Prep light: Where does your adventure start? What are the main scenes? What PC-driven seeds or clues exist? Wing the rest.
#dnd tip: PCs doing a bunch more damage than you expect? Max monster hit points instead of using the average.
#dnd tip: Let your players know that flat DCs for skill checks means they don't have to focus just on high attribute skills.
#dnd tip: Some players don't resonate with open sandboxes, make their potential options clear with opportunities for other ideas.
#dnd tip: Attunement to only 3 magic items means you can give out a lot of interesting treasure without fear of overpowered PCs.
#dnd tip: Write down a list of ten or twenty clues PCs might discover anywhere in an adventure that reinforce the story or the background.
#dnd tip: Keep track of the number of battles between short rests. If it's been more than 3, find a way to give them the equivalent.
#dnd tip: Are the players trying to find a non-traditional way to deal with a battle? Go with it! Find ways to make it work.
#dnd tip: Go big with the descriptions of the battle in narrative combat. Ask players to describe their actions.
#dnd tip: Even small battles should have something to draw in the players. What are they fighting for? What's the real pressure?
#dnd tip: No cleric in the party? Probably a good time for the PCs to find boxes of healing potions laying around!
#dnd tip: More than five PCs? Throw in two monsters per PC above 5.
#dnd tip: What ten clues might your PCs learn in your next adventure?
#dnd tip: 5e uses average hit points for monsters. There's no reason you can't raise or lower it depending on the power of your group.
#dnd tip: Aerial combat is a great way to shake up a traditional fight now and again.
#dnd tip: Speed up combat by ignoring the grid and saying what is "within a move action" or not.
#dnd tip: Fill your encounter with objects and "toys" that could be used to improvise actions by either side.
#dnd tip: All good magic items have names and interesting descriptions.
#dnd tip: Write down a list of the magic items you'd like to give away across your whole campaign. Review it before every adventure.
#dnd tip: Describe weapons, armor, or notable physical features as a way to identify one monster from another.
#dnd tip: Don't force a battle if your players find a creative way around it. Go with the flow of the story.
#dnd tip: Give boss monsters max hit points and a couple of 18 attributes to make them a little harder than the standard beastie.
#dnd tip: Large enemy organizations have the same communication problems and internal politics. That's fun for PCs to navigate.
#dnd tip: Drop a few Fate-like "aspects" into your combat encounter that your PCs can "invoke" to make a battle more dynamic.
#dnd tip: Round dice pools bigger than six by removing a pair of dice and adding 1 + the max value of the die for each pair removed.
#dnd tip: Running Hoard of the Dragon Queen and Rise of Tiamat? It's worth printing a poster of the Sword Coast map.
#dnd tip: Did your PCs just raid a Red Wizard's library? Write "Red Wizard Books and Scrolls" on a 3x5 card and let them learn from it later
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to let PCs negotiate their way out of a fight even if it wasn't what you planned.
#dnd tip: Discuss the moral boundaries of the PCs early in your campaign to keep your players happy together at the table.
#dnd tip: Use miniatures to represent key villains in a campaign. Bring them out regularly to remind the players who they're up against.
#dnd tip: Use Fate-style "Aspects" to define interesting components in your encounter. Let players improvise how they work.
#dnd tip: Initiative can have a huge effect on combat. What will you do if all the monsters go first? What if they all go last?
#dnd tip: Speed up combat by skipping initiative, letting all the players go first around the table, and adding a few extra monsters.
#dnd tip: Be careful having boss monsters flee from a fight. Players may rarely consider this a victory.
#dnd tip: Don't try to prevent PCs from finding a creative way to circumvent a major enemy. Sometimes banishing a major demon is great fun.
#dnd tip: Ask players "what did you enjoy most about today's game" to get good, positive, and useful feedback.
#dnd tip: 5e rule of thumb for building combat encounters: have one monster per PC with a CR of 1/3 the value of the PC's level.
#dnd tip: Pay attention to loot rewards. Mix random loot with hand-picked items to give PCs both useful and interesting things.
#dnd tip: Where does your game start? What are three interesting potential scenes or locations? That's about all you need to run a game.
#dnd tip: Take the time to remember the names of each of the PCs. It's the first step in making the game about them.
#dnd tip: Reinforce the need to build well-rounded PCs that have something they can do in interaction, exploration, and combat.
#dnd tip: a single NPC mage in a fight is likely to have spells countered continually. Add a second mage.
#dnd tip: Don't get mad when your big boss gets disrupted. Limiting the effectiveness of bosses is fun too.
#dnd tip: Give your players a large view of the location and let them decide how they'll get inside.
#dnd tip: "What did you enjoy most about the game?" is a good positive way to get feedback about what people enjoy.
#dnd tip: Encounters shouldn't all be well balanced but ensure players get the clue when it isn't.
#dnd tip: Always look for ways to offer inspiration for players' creative and story-building ideas.
#dnd tip: Don't force the PCs to go into that crazy encounter you designed if they aren't headed there already.
#dnd tip: Ask your players what they enjoyed most about the game. Write down their answers.
#dnd tip: The less time you spend designing boss monsters the less you'll give a shit when they're killed too easily.
#dnd tip: Mages won't cast magic missile on other mages unless they're too stupid to know better.
#dnd tip: Have the freedom to add silly elements into the game like an orc walking into a room in a ruffled apron that says "kiss the chef".
#dnd tip: Did your monsters get the drop on the PCs or vice versa? Switch to side-initiative and save a bunch of time.
#dnd tip: Outline your campaign's big beats but don't fill in the details until the PCs are about to get directly involved.
#dnd tip: What makes your next fantasy location interesting and fantastic?
#dnd tip: Don't force the story to ensure a villain gets away but play villains smart. Let the players see how smart they are.
#dnd tip: 250 word flash fiction in email is a great way to give players a glimpse of the movements of villains and off-camera NPCs.
#dnd tip: Intelligent magic items are the NPCs that keep on giving. Great for giving clues to the PCs when needed most.
#dnd tip: It's quite interesting when the alignment of intelligent magic items and the PCs who wield them don't quite match.
#dnd tip: Use randomly selected targets to ensure you aren't biasing attacks or giving the perception that you are.
#dnd tip: When you come up with a random name for a random NPC. Write it down. You'll never know when you meet them again.
#dnd tip: Just like combat initiative, ensure every player gets a chance to do something interesting in a roleplay scene.
#dnd tip: Start your game preparation by reviewing the PCs and their hooks. Can you build your next adventure off of that?
#dnd tip: Use pictures from the internet to define key NPCs your players will see more than once.
#dnd tip: Don't punish PCs for splitting up in a town. If they're going to get in a fight, find a way for the groups to get back together.
#dnd tip: If the PCs split up in an investigation or roleplay scene, ensure each group gets the right amount of screentime.
#dnd tip: When rolling for random weapons and armor, define the type to make sure it's useful for PCs in need.
#dnd tip: Send out an email RIGHT NOW to learn the birthdays of your players (and DMs!) and celebrate with a game focused on their PC.
#dnd tip: Sometimes players are happy to have a clear direction and a set of focused and well-designed encounters.
#dnd tip: Write out a random encounter list for each level range and location type your PCs are likely to visit.
#dnd tip: If your PCs are having an easy time with "hard" fights. Treat them as though they have one extra PC for a big difficulty boost.
#dnd tip: Whenever you're lost thinking of a direction for your story, look back at the PC backgrounds and work from there.
#dnd tip: Have a good gauge of what your group enjoys and what they find too disturbing. Make the game comfortable for everyone.
#dnd tip: Each encounter or scene should have a seed or series of clues to help the players see the bigger picture.
#dnd tip: Don't bring monsters out one at a time or they're likely to all get nuked one round after the next.
#dnd tip: Use artwork you find on the web to show your players people, places, and things. Save the ones that matter.
#dnd tip: Use physical coins (like @campaigncoins!) to represent Inspiration, Icon Rolls, or Fate Points in your RPGs.
#dnd tip: Mix in two types of monsters in a battle to make it more interesting and increase the choices players have to make.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to give a monster a special attack that represents its unique place in the world or the story.
#dnd tip: Think of each encounter as a puzzle. What do the PCs need to do to succeed? It shouldn't always be "kill the monsters".
#dnd tip: In 5e, you can use a monsters with CR significantly higher than the PCs above level 5 or so as long as there is only one of them.
#dnd tip: Want some large-scale environmental damage? Use 1d10 per level / 4 and give them a Con save to avoid or half it.
#dnd tip: Mix pre-planned treasure designed for the PCs with a good pile of randomly generated treasure for fun weird stuff.
#dnd tip: If the PCs haven't gotten any loot in a while, give them a roll or two on one of the higher-end loot charts.
#dnd tip: For interesting environmental effects, tie concentration spells to destructable objects and place them in a villain's lair.
#dnd tip: Instead of planning out roleplay encouhters, create three NPCs with motivations and backgrounds and improvise it.
#dnd tip: At higher levels in 5e, you can challenge tough PCs with monsters with a CR higher than the average PC level.
#dnd tip: Give bosses a way to reroute debilitating "save or suck" effects to their minions.
#dnd tip: Intelligent weapons are fantastic quest NPCs for side trecks. Give PCs quests to upgrade their intelligent weapons.
#dnd tip: When you split the party, ensure you take care to give each group their share of screen time.
#dnd tip: Don't let NPC's overshadow player characters. Any powerful NPC should be severely limited in a way that PCs can offset.
#dnd tip: Use random charts to avoid cliche grooves we often fall into when forced to improvise stories.
#dnd tip: Use multiple spellcasters in a fight to keep a single caster from being destroyed too quickly.
#dnd tip: Customize monsters by changing weapon types. The gnoll with the two hand-axes and the gnoll with the glaive.
#dnd tip: Use short flash fiction in email to give players a view behind the scenes only involving the PCs.
#dnd tip: Let humor come spontanously at the table. Don't try to push it away or attempt to plan for it ahead of time.
#dnd tip: What evocative scene will you open with at the start of your next session?
#dnd tip: Even the biggest and baddest dragon is likely to have an ally or two in a fight.
#dnd tip: Drawing from a spell card deck is a good way to determine a random spell on a scroll.
#dnd tip: Villains aren't static. They don't sit on their thrones or in their chambers waiting for the PCs. What are THEY doing?
#dnd tip: Don't box your PCs into a corner. Success should lead down one interesting road and failure leads down another interesting road.
#dnd tip: What secrets and clues might your PCs uncover in your next adventure? Sprinkle them in wherever they fit.
#dnd tip: What opportunities exist in your next game for interesting NPC interaction and fantastic exploration? What will they uncover?
#dnd tip: Always keep an eye on your players. Are they bored? Frustrated? Disengaged? Draw them back into the game with something they enjoy
#dnd tip: In scenes of heavy narration or exposition, give your players plenty of meaningful choices to make.
#dnd tip: Write down the names of NPCs who start to resonate with your players. They're likely to come back.
#dnd tip: Take careful note of the attention you're paying to each player. Don't let any of them get lost in the crowd.
#dnd tip: Sometimes annoying NPCs can be the most fun for you and your players.
#dnd tip: Give flat bonus magic items interesting backgrounds, appearances, and traits. Give them a lot of fun flavor.
#dnd tip: Show your PCs the value of their gold. If they invest in a stronghold, show them what got upgraded for their cash.
#dnd tip: Is your villain or NPC unsure how to act? Maybe they ask the PCs for advice!
#dnd tip: If you find yourself saying "no" a lot when it comes to approaching a situation, maybe you want to make it more open.
#dnd tip: Give PCs good opportunities to use their crazy powerful abilities. Don't just short circuit them.
#dnd tip: Find opportunities to bring back older NPCs and villains. Don't make your players remember all new people when old ones will do.
#dnd tip: Always find an interesting event going on in town. Town's anniversary? Birthday party for a hero? The pigs got loose?
#dnd tip: What PC hook ties in to the next adventure you're about to run?
#dnd tip: Does one PC have a significantly high skill check? Let their obnoxiously high results tell something even more interesting.
#dnd tip: Dig into the Monster Manual monster descriptions for some great adventure seed ideas.
#dnd tip: Princes of the Apocalypse is packed with great NPC monster stat blocks. Reskin to suit your own adventure.
#dnd tip: Be wary of using monsters of a challenge rating higher than the PCs' level. Add more monsters, not bigger ones.
#dnd tip: In narrative combat, give players a choice of 1d6 enemies in a burst if they don't target their friends or 2d6 if they do!
#dnd tip: Give PCs interesting quests to upgrade their magic items with added artifact-style properties.
#dnd tip: Use monster groups and themes to give an adventure an overall consistent flavor.
#dnd tip: Take some time ahead of time to learn the spells your monsters are likely to use. Write down page numbers.
#dnd tip: Build swarms of ghouls and zombies by re-skinning higher CR monster stat blocks and using swarm traits.
#dnd tip: Be careful of falling into the trap of spilling too much narrative when you don't know what to do with the table. Ask for a break.
#dnd tip: Running Rise of Tiamat? How about sending high-level PCs to the Mausoleum of Ebondeath!
#dnd tip: Bring back old NPCs in longer campaigns to reward the players who paid attention early on.
#dnd tip: Build interesting fixtures into a combat area that evoke the details and history of a location.
#dnd tip: Use emailed flash fiction to give players a sense of the larger picture in their campaign.
#dnd tip: Because most magic items in 5e have flat math, don't fret giving too many out as long as they aren't all +3 weapons and armor.
#dnd tip: Be fans of the PCs first and foremost (thank you Dungeon World!)
#dnd tip: Know the capabilities of the PCs, not just to thwart them but to give them the chance to show off.
#dnd tip: Mix monster types so they won't all suck at the same thing. Do all your monsters have the same key attributes? Mix it up.
#dnd tip: Are some of your monsters likely to get screwed by a "save or suck" spell? Consider adding a couple more.
#dnd tip: Give your boss monsters legendary resistance and telegraph it to the players so they don't burn out spells finding out.
#dnd tip: Plan loot ahead of time and give your monsters a chance to show them off in a battle.
#dnd tip: Need to spice up a boring hallway? Try a random two-effect trap to make things exciting!
#dnd tip: Legendary encounter design is a careful balance of challenge and PC empowerment. You must include both.
#dnd tip: Not every battle needs to be a well-designed masterpiece. A quick skirmish is fine if it adds to the story.
#dnd tip: With legendary monsters, it's easy to forget your lair actions and legendary actions. Give yourself physical tokens to remember.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to increase a legendary monster's hit points by 25% for each additional PC above 4. Max HP is fine too.
#dnd tip: Give legendary creatures an extra action for fun things like magic item use or interesting spells.
#dnd tip: Expect players to pour everything they have onto your legendary monster. Max HPs or rerouting damage can help mitigate.
#dnd tip: Temporary monsters who come and go can spice up a legendary encounter.
#dnd tip: Consider using a hit point pool when you have more than eight monsters of the same type in a battle.
#dnd tip: What five fantastic locations will you stage your adventures in during your next game? What makes them fantastic?
#dnd tip: Use a random NPC generator to make every humanoid enemy unique and interesting.
#dnd tip: 5e Beholders fight well outside their weight class, especially when they make the most out of flying and the antimagic eye.
#dnd tip: What three interesting things do you want to ensure you describe to the players when they enter the location for a scene?
#dnd tip: Try rolling in the open to force yourself to adapt to unexpected dice rolls.
#dnd tip: Start each adventure prep session by going over the backgrounds and motivations of the PCs.
#dnd tip: Give the 5e vampire an extra melee attack, double it's damage dice, and make charm break if the PC takes 10 damage from any source
#dnd tip: Is an encounter going to start with something other than a straight fight? Jot down some notes on the start of it.
#dnd tip: Never miss an opportunity to foreshadow an interesting enemy.
#dnd tip: Name every villain by using the Sly Flourish random name generator!
#dnd tip: Looking to fill in a hallway with something interesting? Try a two-part random trap.
#dnd tip: Build your villainous lair in a way that makes sense from the point of view of the villain.
#dnd tip: An ancient forgotten temple to Shar under Waterdeep makes for a great assassin's guild hall for the Night Masks.
#dnd tip: Want to beef up that NPC mage? Start it off with mage armor, mirror image, and greater invisibility.
#dnd tip: Don't give a PC a secret unless you're prepared for the player to not share it.
#dnd tip: You can almost never go wrong starting your game off with a battle.
#dnd tip: Take some time to prep magic item rewards before the game. Give them to the enemies to use against the PCs.
#dnd tip: Interesting details in narrative are great, but always try to give players an opportunity to act and make a choice.
#dnd tip: It is perfectly acceptable for the masked lords of Waterdeep to leave the fate of the city to the choices of the PCs.
#dnd tip: Give players the option to get involved in political struggles or not. Don't force them to make a choice if they don't care.
#dnd tip: Run NPC vs. NPC battles as background scenery or quick single d20 rolls. Don't play them out like regular combat.
#dnd tip: Allow for unexpected outcomes in combat. Don't force "all victory" or "all defeat" as the only options.
#dnd tip: Waves of enemies can be cool but there should be a limit to them. Mercenaries are expensive.
#dnd tip: Avoid battles with more than twelve enemies. Use swarms instead.
#dnd tip: Use a shared hit point pool like 13th Age's mooks when running lots of creatures.
#dnd tip: Even if you end a battle early, do it behind thes screen. Don't kill the victory by stating "I'm going to call it here".
#dnd tip: Use the opportunity to create really fantastic environments when running "theater of the mind" narrative combat.
#dnd tip: If the pace of the game starts to slow, move the story forward quickly. Don't force a battle to the end.
#dnd tip: Always include areas in your narrative to give the PCs choices and let them take actions.
#dnd tip: Don't give a job to an NPC that can be given to a PC instead.
#dnd tip: Don't put a single monster up against a party unless you want it to die a swift and anticlimactic death.
#dnd tip: Prepare for PCs to target the odd person out in a fight. That single mage is tasty!
#dnd tip: Give each NPC an interesting physical trait, unique weapons, or other mannerisms even if they share the same stat block.
#dnd tip: Change up weapons and their respective die-types to easily customize NPC enemies.
#dnd tip: Take a break in your game every 90 minutes to two hours so everyone comes back recharged and ready to play.
#dnd tip: A well balanced #dnd 5e battle takes about 45 minutes. Manage your time accordingly.
#dnd tip: If a scene seems to start dragging, move on! You are in full control of the pace of the game.
#dnd tip: End dragging battles early by reducing remaining hit points to 1, lowering DCs, or having enemies explode.
#dnd tip: Be like @SFVDnDAL and stand when you run your games. It keeps everyone's energy up, including your own.
#dnd tip: Use your experiences in the games you play in, both positive and negative, to learn how to be a better DM yourself.
#dnd tip: Mix in some detailed set-piece battles into your game along with narrative combat for big climactic fights.
#dnd tip: The dry-erase flip-mat is useful for just about any RPG. It's a big white board you can set down in front of all the players.
#dnd tip: Give unique characteristics to each monster so people can say "I hit the one with the tattoo of an octopus on his face".
#dnd tip: Spend the time to pick out interesting treasure before the game begins.
#dnd tip: As long as they don't abuse it, adjudicate in favor of a PC's awesome actions rather than saying "no".
#dnd tip: The Doomvault from Dead in Thay makes for an awesome drop-in megadungeon.
#dnd tip: Did a PC kill a legendary foe? Perhaps their weapon absorbed part of the foe and became something new and powerful!
#dnd tip: Many villains, deep down, think they are doing good. What good does your villain think they're doing?
#dnd tip: Need some good random D&D 5e tables? Check out the Donjon!
#dnd tip: Know the motivations of your enemies and, if appropriate, their motivations to flip sides and work for the PCs.
#dnd tip: Let combat flow into the rest of the story if your enemies get caught in save-or-suck effects. Don't just negate it.
#dnd tip: Reward PCs with the plans and components to build interesting magical weapons or armor.
#dnd tip: Never expect a single monster to last very long. Give bosses powerful bodyguards.
#dnd tip: Use narrative combat to keep the story smooth from scene to scene, blending into exploration and NPC interaction
#dnd tip: How many targets should an area hit in narrative combat? Somewhere between 2 and 4 depending on the circumstances.
#dnd tip: What five clues might your PCs learn in your next game?
#dnd tip: Take the time to read the full Dungeon Master's Guide. There are tons of great ideas you might otherwise miss.
#dnd tip: Consider carefully whether you should fudge rolls to fuel a fantastic story or let the dice fall where they will and steal thunder
#dnd tip: Balance the seeds for exploration, roleplaying, and combat in each adventure you prepare.
#dnd tip: If you feel unprepared for your next game but dive in anyway, you might well be on the path of the Lazy Dungeon Master.
#dnd tip: Prepare to give PCs the revenge they deserve against a hated foe. Maybe they live after 0 hp and the PC gets to choose their fate.
#dnd tip: Solutions often come at a cost. What will the PCs give up to un-petrify the victim of a medusa?
#dnd tip: Leave enough blanks in your adventure for players to fill with interesting comments, motivations, or backgrounds.
#dnd tip: Use interesting props, dungeon tiles, or 3d terrain to build Chris Perkins style battle arenas once in a while.
#dnd tip: If you build an interesting battle area, start the PCs there but give them freedom to use it how they will.
#dnd tip: Roll randomly for interesting loot and improvise its origin and background story. Where did that +3 battle-axe come from?
#dnd tip: Draw your players into the story by asking them about the interesting physical characteristics of the enemies they fight.
#dnd tip: Are your players considering bailing out on their current quest? Let them. Don't force them to stay the course.
#dnd tip: Don't know a detail about an NPC or location? Ask your players to fill it in for you!
#dnd tip: Looking to draw out fantasy maps? Check out this site for some great tutorials!
#dnd tip: Build stories off of interesting random results from things like magic item tables or weird dungeon rooms.
#dnd tip: Ask players what the name of their new magic item is. Let them come up with silly ones until a good one comes out.
#dnd tip: Attacking the PCs with a big pile of low-level monsters? Pool their hit points into a big pool 13th Age style.
#dnd tip: Build environments with lots of variables instead of scenes with clear paths and solutions.
#dnd tip: For some variety, give magic items a once-per-day casting of a spell relevant to the item's origin.
#dnd tip: In every dungeon there are always three hidden levels for each level discovered.
#dnd tip: Roll for magic items when you prepare for your game so you know what weapons your villains possess.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to throw a side adventure into your long campaign. Not everything needs to be tied to the big plot.
#dnd tip: There is tons of room in #dnd to ask the players world-building questions and use the results in your game. Keep an open mind.
#dnd tip: Stick to a single big boss fight in single session. Don't try to pack in more than one or it just overwhelms everyone.
#dnd tip: Every so often it's fun to build out a @ChrisPerkinsDnD style Acq. Inc. big set piece arrangement. Build UP!
#dnd tip: Try breaking your reliance on gridded combat with an off-the wall battle that simply can't be mapped out in 5 foot squares.
#dnd tip: Differences in height can make battles really interesting. Flying foes, high ledges, massive waterfalls.
#dnd tip: Revel and celebrate when PCs instantly kill or incapacitate a powerful foe. "You feebleminded the wizard! Awesome!"
#dnd tip: PCs needing to spend their money? Maybe a shady dealer has access to 5 random magic uncommon magic items!
#dnd tip: Want to make Out of the Abyss a little easier in the beginning? Start PCs at level 3 instead of level 1.
#dnd tip: Need some good random D&D 5e tables? Check out the Donjon!
#dnd tip: Take the time to read over a monster stat block in full before you start running it at the table. Some things are easy to miss.
#dnd tip: What fantastic feature exists in each of your scene locations?
#dnd tip: Exotic tattoos, weapons, and armor are great ways to tie NPCs to the story or seed all new ones!
#dnd tip: Good scenes focus on exploration, interaction, or combat. Great scenes include all three!
#dnd tip: Pay attention to expensive spell components. Some spells aren't as easily cast as others.
#dnd tip: A small random assortment of expensive magic items from a shady dealer is a good way to shed PCs from their barrels of gold.
#dnd tip: Let PCs get decide if they want to get involved in far-reaching decisions of politics and war.
#dnd tip: Don't try to negate the PC's awesomely powerful defense. Revel in their power and find a new way to threaten them.
#dnd tip: Keep a to-do list of things you really want to insert into your campaign at some point. Review each time you prep your session.
#dnd tip: Take the time to write a 3x5 card for each scene's location with its most interesting and fantastic feature.
#dnd tip: Use war as a huge backdrop for the story with the actions of the PCs steering the larger course.
#dnd tip: Tie powerful concentration spells to physical objects for an interesting twist in a battle.
#dnd tip: Even for combat-heavy sessions, try to put in interesting facts or secrets that the PCs can learn.
#dnd tip: Even legendary monsters likely have a couple of minions around to cause problems for unattended PCs.
#dnd tip: A great battle provides a difficult challenge that leads to a monumental victory.
#dnd tip: Party having too easy a time with a green dragon? Throw a Storm of Vengeance over the area that only stops on the dragon's death.
#dnd tip: Improvised monsters only need ACs, hit points, an attack score, some damage, and a unique attack.
#dnd tip: Foreshadow upcoming bad guys by giving PCs a glimpse of secret covens or stories of their horrible deeds.
#dnd tip: A picture is worth a thousand words. Use your cell phone to show pictures of the monsters the PCs encounter.
#dnd tip: Be careful using the spell "blink" to protect your wizards. It's powerful but can end up just frustrating players.
#dnd tip: Too many protections on your Big Bad Evil Guys (BBEGs) can seem more of a slog than a fun fight. It's hard to balance.
#dnd tip: Attacking the PCs with a big pile of low-level monsters? Pool their hit points into a big pool 13th Age style.
#dnd tip: Always consider how you can make the abilities of the PCs shine in combat, exploration, and interaction. THEY are your heroes.
#dnd tip: It's always better to end a game early than end a game late. If time is short, call it there and prep for the next game.
#dnd tip: Adding more monsters is always a way to make a battle more challenging and is often more effective than using bigger ones.
#dnd tip: Good ideas come from everywhere. Keep your senses open or you'll miss them.
#dnd tip: Look for interesting people and places throughout your daily lives. Fill your improvisation bucket.
#dnd tip: Mixing two or three ideas together can often make something new and interesting.
#dnd tip: The easiest way to increase the challenge of a 5e battle is to add more monsters.
#dnd tip: Don't build monsters to thwart the abilities of the PCs. Let battles flow naturally.
#dnd tip: Scale is an easy way to make an area fantastic. Mile-high waterfalls, hundred-story pyramids, mountainous cyclopean statues.
#dnd tip: Use the campaign worksheet to keep a focus on the PCs and how they're bending the story.
#dnd tip: Don't go overboard with sub-systems or strange new rules. Stick to the main mechanics that the players are used to.
#dnd tip: Keep your final campaign battles straight forward. Too many twists and turns can ruin an expected climax.
#dnd tip: Fun should always trump realism when building encounters, spells, traps, characters, or monsters.
#dnd tip: Near the end of your campaign, let players tell you what THEY found in the treasure hoard instead of you telling them.
#dnd tip: Avoid the "blink" spell for NPCs and monsters. It just ends up being a pain in the ass instead of an interesting challenge.
#dnd tip: Don't try to circumvent the ability of the PCs. Let them enjoy their asymmetric advantages and overpowered abilities.
#dnd tip: The asymmetry of 5e's design is what fuels interesting stories. Don't houserule around it.
#dnd tip: Don't counteract the PCs success in avoiding what you thought was going to be a big battle. Go with the flow of the story.
#dnd tip: Be prepared with interesting story hooks, interesting NPCs, and fantastic locations in case you start to run out of material.
#dnd tip: Put in lots of opportunities for your PCs to act in your piles of narrative. PCs don't want to be passive observers.
#dnd tip: The number one rule to good dungeon mastering? Relax and have fun.
#dnd tip: Legendary actions and legendary resistances are an easy template to drop on potential boss monsters.
#dnd tip: Use random rolls to determine targets and remove your bias to punish the munchkins.
#dnd tip: Aim for the sweet spot of five PCs for your game. The game is optimal for four but you can usually get away with six.
#dnd tip: Avoid designing your own monsters and instead focus on reskinning existing monsters in the Monster Manual.
#dnd tip: The looser you plan your game, the less you care when players go off the rails or bypass battles you expected them to fight.
#dnd tip: "Your lives end here" is about the weakest thing a boss monster can say. "I murdered your sister" gets more attention.
#dnd tip: Most game sessions can come down to five interesting scenes. Jot them down on a 3x5 card and you're all set.
#dnd tip: Steal and reskin your favorite rooms and chambers from classic adventures to build fantastic locations on the fly.
#dnd tip: Don't fight against the PC's "save or suck" effects. Revel in their joy of the victory!
#dnd tip: Bloodborne's soundtrack (along with its amazing atmosphere) makes for great D&D background music.
#dnd tip: Never expect a single creature to survive if the PCs want to kill it. Instead, expect the threat to come from a group of foes.
#dnd tip: Hit points are a gauge you can turn up or down. The listed amount is the average, not set in stone.
#dnd tip: Want that Tiamat mini to look really big? Make every square a 10 foot square instead of 5!
#dnd tip: What is the winter holiday in your campaign? Perhaps it is Deadwinter Day?
#dnd tip: Don't worry about giving out too many magic items. Attunement is a built in limitation.
#dnd tip: End every campaign with a "three years later" montage driven by the players. Let go and enjoy how their campaign ends.
#dnd tip: There's nothing like a nice walk sans-cellphone to ponder ideas for your next game.
#dnd tip: Keep your primary plot motivations relatively simple but wrap it in all sorts of juicy complications.
#dnd tip: Deep histories can be revealed through small tweet-sized clues left all throughout a dungeon.
#dnd tip: Changing the elemental flavor of a monster is a great way to make it feel different with very little effort.
#dnd tip: "What is its name?" is a great way to help a player bond to the story of a new magical weapon.
#dnd tip: What sort of hopes and dreams do your notable NPCs have for the new year?
#dnd tip: Sometimes threef big chambers tied through with a single hallway is all the dungeon you need.
#dnd tip: Sometimes its fun to leave major plot elements open but always good to have something ready as a backup.
#dnd tip: Keep good notes when your players give you backstories of your characters. They're full of great story seeds.
#dnd tip: Asking world-building open-ended questions to your players can be great. Too open and your players will be simply lost.
#dnd tip: Be careful putting players on the spot with open story building questions. Sometimes they don't want to make stuff up on the spot.
#dnd tip: Narrative combat can be fine but many times players are more engaged when they have a pretty map and some minis to look at.
#dnd tip: Start off your new campaign with some character building and maybe a short battle to get folks into it.
#dnd tip: Every adventure is yours to twist and morph for the fun of you and your group. Never feel you must run it as written.
#dnd tip: when asking players for improvised stories, let them jump in rather than you call them out.
#dnd tip: Don't give your group megadungon access if you don't expect them to start exploring it.
#dnd tip: If your group starts exploring random rooms in a random dungeon, what story seeds can you plant that gives it some backbone?
#dnd tip: Be prepared for your players to hate your quest giving NPC. Find a new way for the PCs to get involved...or not!
#dnd tip: If you have the opportunity, try running games at your local gaming store instead of just at home. Great exp and new friends!
#dnd tip: 13th Age style player-driven montages are a great way to enjoy long scenes of travel.
#dnd tip: Not all player-driven improvisation works well but when it does, it's pure gold. Say yes!
#dnd tip: Cool names add a lot of depth to otherwise faceless enemies. Captain Belmont Graycleaver is better than "leader of the orc mercs".
#dnd tip: Blank dry-erase maps with interesting textures is a great way to balance flexibility with detail.
#dnd tip: Even if you love narrative combat, some minis on the table can draw in the attention of your players.
#dnd tip: Think of NPCs and monsters as piles of clay to be molded into interesting beings by the themes, backgrounds, and drives of the PCs
#dnd tip: A tip from @13thAge: ask players what elements of the game they'd like to see come back in the future.
#dnd tip: Keep track of the number of magic items PCs have so you know which one could use some magic item love.
#dnd tip: Use out-of-character scenes to give players a wider view of the big goings ons in the world.
#dnd tip: If you have one course that is clearly more fun, don't put in an artificial choice. Add more choices elsewhere.
#dnd tip: Building a Fantastic Location: What was your fantastic location originally? What happened to it? What is it used for now?
#dnd tip: Describe profound hits, misses, and even close calls in narrative: "Her blade cuts deep into your left flank!"
#dnd tip: You can begin your journey of PC-focused gameplay by taking the time to memorize the PCs' names.
#dnd tip: In any tough fight, always consider how the PCs will fail forward if they happen to get TPKed.
#dnd tip: Remind players to let you know when they feel like another player deserves inspiration for a cool deed.
