#dnd tip: Give the characters a reason to interact with the scenery in a fantastic location. Why would they risk investigating the strange starscape-filled pool?
#dnd tip: Let characters navigate bottomless pits using reasonably safe ideas without requiring a skill check.
#dnd tip: Smile. Laugh.
#dnd tip: In complicated situations players are probably in trouble understanding what's going on about half the time. Keep this in mind and help them out.
#dnd tip: Set up situations. Let the players decide how to deal with them.
#dnd tip: Run big battles in the background story. Focus on the skirmishes the characters deal with during the bigger wars.
#dnd tip: Show art.
#dnd tip: Spread a thin layer of history and lore over the whole adventure. Let it be discovered through attribute checks and character backgrounds.
#dnd tip: The world is built upon the ancient remains of a thousand civilizations.
#dnd tip: Respond to the decisions of the players as the world would respond to the actions of the characters.
#dnd tip: Spend ten minutes before your game going over the characters. Who are they? What do they want? What do they like to do?
#dnd tip: Steal bigger dungeons, particularly dungeon maps, from other published adventures if you're worried the characters will take a dungeon path you didn't expect.
#dnd tip: Make sure the characters have something to do in each of the locations they might explore. Otherwise they'll just wander through.
#dnd tip: Reward curiosity.
#dnd tip: Use miniatures or tokens to show positioning. Who's up front? Who's in the back?
#dnd tip: Drop in one interesting magic item into each session. If you're worried about imbalancing the game, make it a one-use item.
#dnd tip: Move the spotlight to the NPCs the characters seem to like the best.
#dnd tip: Before you plan out your campaign, talk to your players and make sure its the sort of campaign people want to play. Do this even BEFORE a session zero (session negative one?)
#dnd tip: Vary the types of monsters your characters face. Two or three battles of zombies in a row can get boring and repetitive.
#dnd tip: Add or remove encounters to change up the pace of the game. Too many battles can be weary and too few can lose the action
#dnd tip: Add magic items that fit the backgrounds and desires of the characters. Let's face it, Sting was made for Bilbo.
#dnd tip: Let confrontations go from verbal to physical and maybe back again. Don't expect or force a scene to go one way or the other. Let the players choose.
#dnd tip: Write a one-page campaign summary that focuses on the characters and their role in the campaign. Write it in the second person.
#dnd tip: Use hand torn crumpled copper resume paper to make cool in world  notes.
#dnd tip: Keep your session zero relaxed and let your players know not to expect crazy powerhouse action. It's a time to get to know the characters and the world.

#dnd tip: Use downtime between adventures as a way for the players to get to know one another's characters. "What was your character up to over the past two tendays?" is a great way to learn more about a character.
#dnd tip: Nothing beats a body washing up on shore to start a mystery.
#dnd tip: Change the hooks in published adventures if the one in your head will grab your players more than the one in the book.
#dnd tip: Make vampires more dangerous by increasing their life draining bite to 21 (6d6) necrotic damage and requiring Greater Restoration to restore the drained hit points.
#dnd tip: Spend time learning how to draw cool maps. Regional, dungeon, and battle maps are a great way to draw your players visually into the story.
#dnd tip: Change the weather.
#dnd tip: Zombies that explode like fireballs when they finally die.
#dnd tip: Block and schedule some time in your week to spend real time preparing for your game.
#dnd tip: Award inspiration to reward risk taking that moves the story forward. Putting your head into a well full of poisonous snakes? You get inspiration!
#dnd tip: Level one is its own special game. It's far more dangerous and lethal than any other level in the game. Treat it accordingly.
#dnd tip: Keep an eye on the damage output of a monster. It may swing harder or softer than the challenge rating indicates.
#dnd tip: Drop hints of interesting things the characters might otherwise miss. Strange thudding noises in the attic, strange glowing shining reflections in the mud at the bottom of the well.
#dnd tip: Tie the PCs' backgrounds to future adventures. Maybe one of the characters sailed on the ship that sunk the pirate vessel Tammeraut.
#dnd tip: Build handouts to draw players into the world. Strange fonts on copper-colored resume paper with torn edges works well.
#dnd tip: Build two layers of deception into your villains. The first one discovered covers up the second.
#dnd tip: Review the material on the DM screen every so often to refresh you on the tools you have right in front of you.
#dnd tip: Keep track of character hit points so you can get a more accurate gauge of monster difficulty.
#dnd tip: Add accessories and details to your terrain builds. The details make it come alive.
#dnd tip: Use larger encounter areas with a few rooms. Monsters can come from many sides and the characters might need to split up to keep them at bay.
#dnd tip: When a horde of monsters attack the characters you can assume about 1/4 of them will hit. Edge up and down depending on big differences in AC.

#dnd tip: Even if you only have ten minutes to prepare for your game, spend those ten minutes on the most important elements of your game prep: Who are the characters? Where will it start? What secrets and clues might they discover?
#dnd tip: Even rot grub swarms have interesting physical characteristics that separate them from other rot grub swarms (little mohawks, spiral stripes, ugly spots).
#dnd tip: Even in open sandbox scenarios, it helps to clarify what the characters can and can't do. Give some guidelines so they're not completely flailing.
#dnd tip: Are the players smiling? You're doing it right.

#dnd tip: When putting a big scenario in front of your players, like infiltrating a villa or invading a pirate ship, take the time to understand all of the variables. How will the NPCs act? Where are they going? What do they want?
#dnd tip: Clarify when the characters have exhausted all the information they're going to get in a scene. "You're pretty sure you've learned everything you can here."
#dnd tip: Let the players discover the number of enemies they're likely to face in a big dynamic area. How many hill giants can they expect to find in the steading of the hill giant chief?
#dnd tip: Sometimes skill checks go so catastrophically wrong that it shakes up the whole world. A simple attempted distraction might capsize an entire ship.

#dnd tip: Help guide the players' discussion of their plans for an infiltration or ruse. Steer the conversation towards what will likely work, away from what won't, and towards what will bring the most fun for the group.
#dnd tip: Hide your secret villains from the characters and leave clues of their existence and their impact on the surrounding world.
#dnd tip: In any open situation offer three plausable paths plus any the players come up with themselves.
#dnd tip: Are the villains in a hard situation? What would you do in their shoes? Sometimes a pirate captain will scuttle their own ship if it means their own survival and killing the characters.
#dnd tip: In "breather episodes" in which the characters return to town, let the players know its coming ahead of time and offer options for downtime activities.
#dnd tip: Change out boss monsters based on the backgrounds of the characters. Is a character hunting a black ship-eating whale that ate her parents? Get that sucker into the adventure!
#dnd tip: Foreshadow future adventures with quest hooks and rumors the characters hear about around town.
#dnd tip: Read one or two chapters ahead in any big campaign adventure you're currently running. Read up the next session within a day of running it.
#dnd tip: Prep small add-in encounters to add in when things go quicker than expected in your planned adventure.
#dnd tip: Expose multiple paths.
#dnd tip: Leave options open for dialog even after combat has begun.
#dnd tip: Have quest givers offer multiple quests and let the players choose the ones they want.
#dnd tip: Clarify objectives.
#dnd tip: Increase the legendary actions, hit points, and damage of legendary monsters for each character above four.
#dnd tip: Show maps.
#dnd tip: In combat, think about how your monsters would act given the current situation. Would they run? Would they stay and fight? Would they surrender?
#dnd tip: Set up big set-piece encounter areas and leave open lots of potential options. Let the characters approach the situation how they will.
#dnd tip: Allow for encounters with lots of enemies who act sub-optimally. Sure, there are more than a dozen bullywugs but they're clearly not coordinated.
#dnd tip: End with a cliffhanger and give yourself a built-in strong start next game.
#dnd tip: Before running any monster, give its lore section in the monster manual a read and see if it fires up any ideas.
#dnd tip: Perhaps a malenti, a sahuagin spy and assassin who appears as a sea elf, has infiltrated the local lizardfolk lair as a false ambassador with plans to assassinate the queen.
#dnd tip: A gelatinous cube with a single-use magical relic floating inside is its own encapsulated D&D adventure.
#dnd tip: A few miniatures on the table just to show general positioning can help players better understand how a battle is going.
#dnd tip: Understand how the action economy affects combat difficulty. The number of actions on each side compared to the ither matters a lot. Four on four is much more balanced than one on four.
#dnd tip: Keep the number of items you need to run a game small. Only keep what you need.
#dnd tip: Award inspiration for creative and detailed descriptions of the previous game session.
#dnd tip: Describe the NPCs the characters might want to visit in a downtime scene.
#dnd tip: Add rumors to your secrets and clues. You never know what you might learn when hanging around down at the docks.
#dnd tip: What plot is your secret villain hatching right now?
#dnd tip: Use strange, wondrous, and horrible descriptions to change up common monsters. There are infinite notable variants of the common swarm of insects.
#dnd tip: The age of wood and stone has a story to tell.
#dnd tip: Switch out villains for ones who have a clear connection to the characters.
#dnd tip: In combat, the side with more actions has a big advantage over the side with fewer.
#dnd tip: A single monster is roughly equivalent to a single character when it's CR is a quarter of the character's level below level 5 or half the character's level if above level 5.
#dnd tip: Foreshadow your adventures with sinister weather or the attitudes of the crowds.
#dnd tip: Run small experiments.

#dnd tip: Keep your descriptions in the fiction. Don't describe mechanics, describe the story behind them. "You take 8 damage" becomes "The orc's greatsword slashes across your thigh leaving a weeping wound. You take 8 damage."
#dnd tip: 500 word bits of flash fiction is a great way to give the characters a glimpse of what happened before. Ship's logs, letters, journals; give them a small taste of the larger story.
#dnd tip: In longer mysteries, hold back incriminating evidence until it's time for the discovery.
#dnd tip: The warlock's relationship with their patron is a complex one. It can be just as antagonistic as the strength of its bond. Warlocks are not slaves to their patrons.
#dnd tip: Be careful turning a liked or beloved NPC into a secret villain. Your players may be committed to them and the betrayal might break them out of the story.
#dnd tip: Reskin spells to give villains particularly unique abilities and effects.
#dnd tip: You need little more than the core books, an adventure, and some dice to run a great D&D game.
#dnd tip: Ask what the characters can do in any given narrative scene.
#dnd tip: Model NPCs after interesting characters in books, movies, or TV shows; then change their genders.
#dnd tip: Are 5th-10th level characters getting attacked by fifty skeletons? Assume one quarter of the skeletons will hit their targets or make their saving throws.
#dnd tip: Sinister and secret plots sometimes are so secret that the characters never discover them. Expose them.
#dnd tip: Even smart villains make mistakes and reveal too much of their hand. Even powerful villains sometimes have horrible luck.
#dnd tip: Throw in a random conversational NPC if you find you're having too many battles in a row. The characters sometimes need someone to talk to.
#dnd tip: There's always another cult.
#dnd tip: Review the players' character sheets, not to circumvent their abiltiies but to spotlight their specialities.
#dnd tip: Game time starting in ten minutes and you have nothing prepared? Steal a map, write out a strong start, and write down ten secrets and clues.
#dnd tip: Give the characters a reason to talk to NPCs and vice versa.
#dnd tip: Reveal the wider world through ancient relics, statues, tapestries, scraps of old books, and other elements of ancient history.
#dnd tip: Layer your cultists. What secret does the inner circle keep from the outer circle? What's dark secret lies below the four elemental cults?
#dnd tip: Keep a collection of good maps handy. Every old tree has a dungeon below it.
#dnd tip: Pay attention to the players who, through bad luck, roll low or get hit all the time. Give them a boost somewhere else in the story.
#dnd tip: Use the environment as a tool to tell the story.
#dnd tip: Discern intent
#dnd tip: Mix good things with bad things in your dungeons. Mix in healing fonts, blessing statues, and powerful relics with your acid-bolos, psychic razor-wire, and ethereal javelins.
#dnd tip: What is the larger story going on in your dungeon?
#dnd tip: Drop in secrets in clues into dungeon crawls so the characters learn the story while navigating the dangers.
#dnd tip: Include interesting NPCs in your dungeon crawl such as ghosts, intelligent items, lost explorers, or enemy turncoats.
#dnd tip: Telegraph to the players when they'll likely be in a resource-draining dungeon with little to no chance for a rest for some time.
#dnd tip: Drop in a sentient weapon.
#dnd tip: Drape environments with lore.
#dnd tip: Note player interests from downtime scenes.
#dnd tip: Move the enemy's plans forward.
#dnd tip: Move things forward in towns while the characters are away.
#dnd tip: Ensure everyone gets a chance to describe their actions in downtime scenes.
#dnd tip: Did someone die and get immediately revified? How many years did they experience in limbo in the seconds that passed in the world?
#dnd tip: Make common monsters interesting by shaking up their appearances, weapons, armor, and your descriptions of their attacks.
#dnd tip: What does that skeleton smell like? What do its fingers feel like when their ragged ends scrape the character's skin? What drips from their open dead mouths?
#dnd tip: Put something in the hand of your NPC.  Spinning knives, twirling moonlight, cats cradle; anything.
#dnd tip: A friendly priest casts "aid" on your 1st level party before they begin their adventures.
#dnd tip: Highlight three meaningful options for infiltrating the enemies' fortress.
#dnd tip: Assume the adventurers are smart, capable, and observant. Clarify what they might see that the players might not realize.
#dnd tip: Players have trouble understanding what your describing about half the time. Be patient and clarify.
#dnd tip: Give the characters leeway on infiltration missions. The whole dungeon shouldn't come down on the group for a single failed stealth check.
#dnd tip: Bathe dungeons in interesting iconography.
#dnd tip: Change up the number and types of monsters based on the best forward pace of the adventure.
#dnd tip: Avoid awarding similar magic items. Give them something new and cool.
#dnd tip: Tie sentient weapon origins to the backgrounds of the character.
#dnd tip: Run adventures twice.
#dnd tip: Include juicy set-piece battles roughly every other session.
#dnd tip: Read over your players' character sheets and come up with interesting hooks to draw them into the story.
#dnd tip: Customize monsters with weapons armor and traits from other monsters.
#dnd tip: Think about the histories of your characters and their families while considering the history of your world.
#dnd tip: Sink your adventure hooks deep.
#dnd tip: Introduce shady NPCs that can't simply be killed.
#dnd tip: Inspire yourself with cool maps and art.
#dnd tip: When running with three or fewer players, tailor the story of the adventure around those characters.
#dnd tip: Simplify.
#dnd tip: Write for the players at your table.
#dnd tip: Use existing stat blocks.
#dnd tip: Focus more on the story and less on the mechanics.
#dnd tip: When a character counterspells your big boss's big spell, let them.
#dnd tip: Put yourself in the mind of your monsters; how would they behave?
#dnd tip: Mix monster traits to fit a special creatures unique story.
#dnd tip: Customize monsters with flavor.
#dnd tip: Spend less time on Twitter and more time reading your source books.
#dnd tip: Describe enemy spells by the components they use. Let the players guess what they're casting or use Xanathar's rules for identifying spells.
#dnd tip: Save time and money by using a dry-erase marker and a flip mat to draw monsters. Get cool hero minis for the characters.
#dnd tip: Offer multiple options for the characters in a big assault. Will they protect the gates? Will they stop the sewer infiltrators? Will they hunt down the assassins?
#dnd tip: Are your monsters getting beaten down too quickly? Give the survivors more actions to account for their dead fellows.
#dnd tip: More monsters pose a greater challenge than bigger monsters.
#dnd tip: Just getting started with D&D? Start with the inexpensive Starter set and the adventure Lost Mine of Phandelver.
#dnd tip: Describe even common monsters with the details and flavor that make them unique to the characters.
#dnd tip: Shake up the weapons and monsters of humanoids to make them different and exciting.
#dnd tip: Enemy NPCs can dual wield even if its not in the stat block.
#dnd tip: Describe what's happening in the story instead of the details of the mechanics.
#dnd tip: Provoke opportunity attacks. Players love a free hit.
#dnd tip: Keep your adventures simple. Let them get complicated when the characters smash up against them.
#dnd tip: Take some time to research the history and lore (or write it yourself) for the areas immediately surrounding the characters.
#dnd tip: Be prepares to shrink your dungeon to its most interesting rooms if time and pacing demand it.
#dnd tip: Let the players plan a strategy but move things forward if the planning starts to get stale or boring.
#dnd tip: Tweak monster hit points and damage to suit the upward or downward beat of the scene.
#dnd tip: Smile. Laugh. Have fun.
#dnd tip: Negotiate. Offer deals.
#dnd tip: Areas of effect can almost always be manipulated to hit a single target. Adjudicate those situations fast and easily.
#dnd tip: Review your players character sheets. Show off their strengths and note their limitations.
#dnd tip: Avoid denial fights. Players want their characters to do stuff.
#dnd tip: Don't worry about matching challenge ratings to character levels. A hundred goblins is an awesome fight against a group of 8th level characters.
#dnd tip: Use advantage and disadvantage as easy mechanics for improvised terrain features.
#dnd tip: Run combat fast and with a focus on the in-world story.
#dnd tip: Fall into the fantasy.
#dnd tip: Focus on the big picture.
#dnd tip: Keep note of who enjoys political intrigue and who prefers more straight forward adventuring. Season to taste.
#dnd tip: Recap the cinematics of the previous rounds of combat. (Thanks @JoeManganiello!)
#dnd tip: Know when to stay behind the curtain and when to pull it back. Only pull it back if it brings delight to the players.
#dnd tip: When in doubt, lean towards revealing too much.
#dnd tip: Feel free to announce ACs, DCs, and legendary monster status.
#dnd tip: Reskinning is the most powerful of a DM's tools. Skim off of the inertia of others.
#dnd tip: Start with a combat to get the players' energy up.
#dnd tip: Keep monologues short and sweet. Get to the point.
#dnd tip: Good villains think what they're doing is right. Great villains might actually BE right.
#dnd tip: Don't assume a conversation won't turn into a fight or a fight might turn into a conversation. Let the pillars bleed together.
#dnd tip: Keep some action-packed encounters on hand up the pacing when required.
#dnd tip: Characters, and players, want to do stuff. Make things happen.
#dnd tip: Develop a menu of options for downtime scenes.
#dnd tip: Let players describe and upgrade their lair, home, tavern, or ship.
#dnd tip: Steal cities, steal worlds, steal universes, steal the gods themselves!
#dnd tip: Build a menu of downtime activities tailored for the characters and their interests.
#dnd tip: The strong start is a great place to use a detailed set-piece battlemap. You already know they're going to begin there so there's no railroading.
#dnd tip: Focus on the fundamentals.
#dnd tip: Teach using the core classes.
#dnd tip: When teaching new players, get into the game as fast as possible.
#dnd tip: Ask for individual character goals and use downtime as a way to explore them.
#dnd tip: Set up situations and let the gameplay style find itself during the game.
#dnd tip: When teaching someone new to D&D, show them the core mechanic and then get into the game.
#dnd tip: Start with as few tools as you need and add them in when they clearly add to the enjoyment of your game.
#dnd tip: Draw maps. Leave blanks. (Thank you Dungeon World!)
#dnd tip: Focus on the fiction.
#dnd tip: Review the skill proficiencies of the characters and call upon those skills in the game.
#dnd tip: Tailor magic items to fit the characters.
#dnd tip: When running online, test your audio and video for each player beforehand.
#dnd tip: Listen more than you talk.
#dnd tip: Run off-line downtime activities when you can't run a regular session.
#dnd tip: Keep the game going with email and chat between games.
#dnd tip: Reveal grim portents.
#dnd tip: Keep the story simple. Let the characters complicate it.
#dnd tip: Denote useful location features.
#dnd tip: In focused scenes of roleplaying, watch the body language of other players to see if they're getting bored.
#dnd tip: Manage time early on in your session.
#dnd tip: Extend or shorten battles behind the screen by shifting hit points to suit the desired pacing and beats.
#dnd tip: Summarize the current main point of the current story frequently to help players catch up.
#dnd tip: Take breaks.
#dnd tip: When characters use encounter breaking spells or abilities, let them. You have an infinite number of monsters.
#dnd tip: Worry less about tactical challenge and more about what's happening in the world.
#dnd tip: Let clerics use channel divinity to boost religious checks in circumstances where it makes sense. Blowing up unholy altars and the like.
#dnd tip: The Dungeon Master's Guide includes a selection of maps perfect for improvised gaming. Review them and keep them handy.
#dnd tip: Even a quick sketch of a map is better than no map at all. It doesn't have to be fancy but should be real enough in your head to make it feel real to the players.
#dnd tip: The best tools help you improvise during the game.
#dnd tip: Encourage at least one of your players to take notes during the game.
#dnd tip: Ask players to send you pictures of their characters. Use them for initiative tents, character tokens, and other aids. Internalize them.
#dnd tip: Let players break out of a fear, stun, or charm by accepting a pile of psychic damage. Maybe 1d10 per CR of the effect.
#dnd tip: Hang loose.
#dnd tip: Prepare the minis you need when you know you'll need them.
#dnd tip: Don't assume how the characters will react to any given situation.
#dnd tip: What would happen in your world if the characters weren't there?
#dnd tip: Don't steal the kill from a character to support some external story event.
#dnd tip: What monsters make sense given the situation?
#dnd tip: Project your excitement.
#dnd tip: Step away from the news. Grab a D&D sourcebook and escape to another world.
#dnd tip: There's a time for deep tactical fun and big explosive narrative. Know the difference.
#dnd tip: Be careful slamming the same character down to zero over and over again. What should seem dangerous ends up being just annoying.
#dnd tip: Keep your exposition and narrative tight and to the point.

#dnd tip: Work with the players, not against them.
#dnd tip: Try keeping your prep down to a single sheet of paper.
#dnd tip: Ask the players regularly what sort of arcs they see for their characters in the campaign.
#dnd tip: Adjudicate towards high adventure.
#dnd tip: Start and end with the fiction.
#dnd tip: Use clear tactical maps for location defense scenarios.
#dnd tip: Think as your villain thinks. They make mistakes but learn from them.
#dnd tip: Be careful that your political intrigue doesn't turn into the D&D equivalant of eight hours of CSPAN.
#dnd tip: Break up political tension with blinding acts of violence.
#dnd tip: Use face cards when the characters are interacting with a lot of NPCs.
#dnd tip: Keep the number of front-facing NPCs to around three. Too many becomes too hard to keep track of.

#dnd tip: The best improvements to your D&D game cost no money at all.

#dnd tip: Know when your players want some tense politics and when they just want to fight the bad guy.
#dnd tip: Ask your players what they're enjoying and what they hope for in future games.
#dnd tip: Know the lore. know the situation. Adapt.
#dnd tip: Use the tools and accessories that help you tell a fun, fluid, and flexible game.
#dnd tip: Keep a realistic reign on social media FOMO. The fanciest dice still roll ones.
#dnd tip: Craving an old-school feel to your D&D game? Use only the Basic Rules for character generation and cap levels to 6th level. Ignore feats and multiclassing options.
#dnd tip: How does the world respond to the characters? That's the primary question that helps us run our games.
#dnd tip: Limit battles to three types of monsters or fewer.
#dnd tip: When things get stale in combat, change the stakes or switch to fantastic finishes.
#dnd tip: Go with what the players bring you.
#dnd tip: Avoid a series of hard battles. Let the players enjoy smashing down weaker foes.
#dnd tip: Foreshadow future threats early and often.
#dnd tip: Help players meet their intent.
#dnd tip: Understand The mechanical abilities are the characters so that you can build scenes to make them awesome
#dnd tip: How does the world respond to the characters? That's the primary question that helps us run our games.
#dnd tip: Don't overuse monster hoards. The game expects between one and twelve monsters.
#dnd tip: Ask players what they want from the game as your campaign comes to a close. Give it to them.
#dnd tip: Build a fun final battle for the conclusion of your campaign. Give it the time it deserves.
#dnd tip: Tell your players to prepare for a "one year later" montage at the end of your campaign. Give them some time to consider it.
#dnd tip: Start with the characters and build off of what they bring to the world.

#dnd tip: Use the right background music for relaxation, suspense, and combat.
#dnd tip: Ensure there's something for the characters to do in any given location.

#dnd tip: Let the story go perpendicular. Enjoy the change.
#dnd tip: Stay in initiative order even in non-combat scenes to ensure every character gets their spotlight.
#dnd tip: What hook will draw the characters into the adventure?
#dnd tip: Pay special attention to the backgrounds of the characters. Build your game from them.
#dnd tip: When running online, use the tools that help you share the story and omit those that use up more time and energy than they're worth.
#dnd tip: Run for fewer players when running D&D online. Split your groups.
#dnd tip: Facetime or Hangouts is a great way for an absent player to still play.
#dnd tip: Keep a long playlist of sinister video game music playing in the background.
#dnd tip: Don't judge your games by what you see on the net. Learn from them but remember, you're doing great.
#dnd tip: If you have players fooled into thinking you're a good DM, you're a good DM.
#dnd tip: Give players an overview of the structure of the city when running big city adventures.
#dnd tip: Keep a solid list of random events taking places in big cities to give them continual activity and flavor.
#dnd tip: Start your city-based adventures with a big event; a contest, a riot, or a religious festival brings the city to life.
#dnd tip: Of your three villains or factions, have one that requires no big moral choice to beat the snot out of.
#dnd tip: Every inn, university, or noble house might have an old forgotten dungeon underneath full of dangers and adventure.
#dnd tip: Focus your city-based adventures on a particular region or neighborhood.
#dnd tip: Give your characters an early headquarters in city-based adventures. Perhaps they hang out in the room above an old inn, a old pawn shop, a tea house, or a gambling hall.
#dnd tip: Every outhouse has a gray ooze lurking in the bottom. Sometimes its an otyugh. Sometimes its a purple worm.
#dnd tip: Even in dungeon delves, ensure there are opportunities for exploration, roleplaying, and combat.
#dnd tip: Two groups seeking the same item is a great way to complicate and otherwise static dungeon.
#dnd tip: Let the characters learn about the world through discoveries in ancient crypts, frescoes on ruined temple walls, and strange tattoos on their assailants.
#dnd tip: Keep your default levels of sex and violence to PG-13. Think Raiders of the Lost Ark.
#dnd tip: Borrow liberally from other RPG products and stick their best pieces into your game.
#dnd tip: Want to turn a legendary monster into a normal monster? Ignore legendary resistance, legendary actions, and lair actions. Give it an extra attack on its attack action.
#dnd tip: Prepare one scene for every 30 minutes of gameplay.
#dnd tip: When playing remote, check in oftem with your players to see how they're feeling about the game.
#dnd tip: Review your players' character sheets. Spotlight their strengths.
#dnd tip: Which movies feed the theme of your campaign?
#dnd tip: Play to your campaign world's strengths.
#dnd tip: What song or album is the theme to your adventure or campaign?
#dnd tip: Give your players a home base. Let them customize it.
#dnd tip: Draw players back into the game by asking for skill checks to reveal details about the situation.
#dnd tip: Let the players go shopping before a big party or social event. Ask them how their character prepares for the event.
#dnd tip: When developing situations, review the character sheets to ensure you have the right hooks to draw in each character.
#dnd tip: Warn characters when it looks like they're about to bite off more than they can chew. The players may not be getting the more subtle warning signs.
#dnd tip: Help your players out. They're probably lost about half the time.
#dnd tip: Develop exploration hooks and reveal secrets during scenes of social interaction.
#dnd tip: When things get slow, a gnoll kicks in the door.
#dnd tip: Some monsters are perfectly suited for particular jobs. A mimic spy? Why not!
#dnd tip: Set up the situation and steer it towards the fun.
#dnd tip: Steer towards the action.
#dnd tip: Know the characters' skills. Set up situations that fit them.
#dnd tip: Shift the game continually through the three pillars: combat, exploration, and roleplaying.
#dnd tip: "What does that look like?" is a great question to draw players into the fiction.
#dnd tip: Set things on fire.
#dnd tip: Give players forewarning of a coming downtime scene and potential options the characters can follow.
#dnd tip: Draw secrets and clues from the intersection of character backgrounds and the lore of the world.
#dnd tip: Start strong with an action packed battle against weaker foes to build up the energy of the players.
#dnd tip: Know and broadcast regularly what makes your world unique among worlds.
#dnd tip: Use a simple visual to show the general positioning of combatants even when running theater of the mind combat.

#dnd tip: Know clearly what drives the characters through the story. Why are they doing what they're doing?
#dnd tip: Why will your players care about the upcoming story arc and big reveals?
#dnd tip: Ensure each scene in your game has lots of opportunities for the characters to act.
#dnd tip: Be grand in visuals and specific in details.
#dnd tip: Steal from fiction and mash ideas together.
#dnd tip: Always be ready to grab what the characters bring to the story and wire it into the game.
#dnd tip: Offer three plausible options.
#dnd tip: Reward with tangible benefits.
#dnd tip: Give 1st level characters five extra hit points.
#dnd tip: Be wary of 1st level published adventures. They're often unexpectedly deadly.
#dnd tip: What ten fantastic features will the characters find in your next dungeon?
#dnd tip: Ensure the characters have things they can do in any given scene. This isn't a movie.
#dnd tip: Focus your narration on the most important information in any given scene.
#dnd tip: Write down the proficient skills of each character. Tug on those skills to bring the characters into the world.
#dnd tip: Remember that players are grasping about half of what you're describing.
#dnd tip: Build situations and let the players choose their approach.
#dnd tip: Mash together your favorite stories into something entirely new.
#dnd tip: Use maps to inspire your adventures.
#dnd tip: Give players an overview map of known locations when preparing for a heist.
#dnd tip: Use random tables from the Dungeon Masters Guide for inspiration when preparing adventures.
#dnd tip: Have a backup communication tool if your main one fails during your online game.
#dnd tip: Give players options for roleplaying, exploration, or combat when entering into adventure situations.
#dnd tip: Ask players to customize and define their pets, companions, and figurines of wondrous power.
#dnd tip: If players struggle with plans; restate the goal, clarify the options, let them in on details they may have missed.
#dnd tip: Chasing a single spy through city streets can be as exciting as a big battle against dangerous foes.
#dnd tip: Draw out locations, even if it's just for you, to help them solidify from your fuzzy brain into a real place.
#dnd tip: Things going slow? Blow something up!
#dnd tip: Powerful and dangerous magic items are wonderful vehicles for the story.
#dnd tip: Reflavor standard magic items.
#dnd tip: Two villainous groups seeking the same item in the same dungeon as the characters is a great way to make the whole dungeon come alive.
#dnd tip: Put something interesting in every room.
#dnd tip: Stuck for inspiration? Write down ten things for your game. Secrets, locations, hooks, villains, items and so on.
#dnd tip: Write out custom downtime activities for each character based on their own interests and backgrounds.
#dnd tip: Sometimes a silly encounter can break up the continual grim nature of most encounters. Use them as a break.
#dnd tip: Try new tools but don't fool yourself into overweighting their importance in preparing and running a great game. A stack of 3x5 cards can go a long way.
#dnd tip: Look at each step you take for your game prep and ask if it's really helping you run a great game next session.
#dnd tip: Find and refine the tools that help you prep faster and aid in your flexibility and ability to improvise at your next game.
#dnd tip: Look two horizons out.
#dnd tip: Use the tools that you love and that get you excited to prep and play.
#dnd tip: Strong starts can be good or bad. It may be a parade or it may be a crashing airship full of ghouls.
#dnd tip: Always be ready to drop in an interesting conversational NPC into your dungeon.
#dnd tip: Give the players enough information to make more meaningful choices than left or right.
#dnd tip: Use the tools that keep you and your players focused on the transpiring story.
#dnd tip: Inspire yourself with art.
#dnd tip: The main DM mechanic: choose a DC between 10 and 20.
#dnd tip: What can the characters do in every scene?

#dnd tip: Use the tables from chapters 3, 5, and Appendix A of the Dungeon Master's Guide to inspire adventure ideas you can drop in front of the characters and see what types of adventures they want to go on. Build your own job board.
#dnd tip: The DM doesn't tell the story. The DM facilitates the story that happens at the table.
#dnd tip: Ensure your battles don't continually favor one type of character.
#dnd tip: Seek inspiration from everywhere.
#dnd tip: Build characters together.
#dnd tip: Keep the basics in mind: a quest, a location, some monsters.
#dnd tip: Have one scene in hand for every 45 minutes of gameplay.
#dnd tip: Build situations and let the characters navigate them.
#dnd tip: Improvise encounters based on the situation and evolving circumstances.
#dnd tip: Change dungeon configurations to fit the pacing and timing of your adventure.
#dnd tip: Dial back the urgency and let the players choose what they want to do.
#dnd tip: Provide three meaningful options.
#dnd tip: Protect your delicate villains. Players love to pin them down and kill them first.
#dnd tip: Waves of combatants is a great way to put the pressure on the characters without overwhelming them completely.
#dnd tip: Working off-camera is the easiest way for a villain to screw with the characters and not get instantly killed.

#dnd tip: What the villains would reasonably do may not be what's most fun for the group. Just as "that's what my character would do" is a BS excuse for players, "that's what my villains would do" iSs a B excuse for DMs. A bad time is a bad time.
#dnd tip: Don't force a story angle to happen if the characters can thwart it. Let the thwarting occur and figure out what would happen next.
#dnd tip: Hordes of monsters don't all act in a well coordinated battle. Some get scared, some run in fearlessly, some act smartly. Get into their heads and act as they would act.
#dnd tip: Ask for stars and wishes. What did the players love in the previous game? What do they want more of in future games?
#dnd tip: Be wary of taking away the characters' stuff.
#dnd tip: Keep your descriptions brief and fantastic.
#dnd tip: Sometimes even dead villains have laid careful traps and plots for the characters.
#dnd tip: Villains need not be strong in combat. Perhaps a single blow would fell them. It's the monsters and obstacles they've put in the way that cause trouble.
#dnd tip: Things getting complicated? Default back to an old fashioned dungeon romp.
#dnd tip: Drop the dungeons from Princes of the Apocalypse beneath any big town or city.
#dnd tip: Use minis and maps to draw the players into the world.
#dnd tip: A quick list of who is next to who in what area may be all you need to articulate combat.
#dnd tip: Characters above 5th level? Bring on the pain!
#dnd tip: Do your characters counterspell? Change how you describe enemy spellcasting to give them time to respond.
#dnd tip: Give cool magic weapons. Don't be stingy.
#dnd tip: Prep one scene for every 30 to 45 minutes of gameplay.
#dnd tip: Aim for six regular players and be willing to run with as few as three.
#dnd tip: Aim for a regular day and time every week or two. Try hard to run at that time.
#dnd tip: Use your favorite image editor (Preview, MS Paint, whatever) to quickly annotate @DysonLogos maps with evocative descriptions for your D&D game.
#dnd tip: Build quests and adventures from the backgrounds and drives of the characters.
#dnd tip: Rescuing people being attacked is a good way to get characters into the adventure without having them continually beset upon.
#dnd tip: failed Athletics check? Describe the searing pain that rips down from the side of one's neck to their lower back. A pain that will twinge them awake for three nights.

#dnd tip: When improvising scenes or situations, ask yourself what makes sense given the current situation. What would be in those sewers? How would the bad guys prepare ahead of time? What makes sense?

#dnd tip: It's common for DMs is to feel unprepared and nervous before the game and feel awesome during and afterwards. No matter how long you've been running games, that nervousness is always there. It'll be fine.
#dnd tip: Run published adventures months after their release and capitalize off of the shared experiences of hundreds of other DMs who jumped on it early.
#dnd tip: End early. Keep your players hungry for more.
#dnd tip: Be careful with majority-led choices. Check in with those who haven't spoken up before choosing the path of those who have.
#dnd tip: Build out cool locations for big boss battles.
#dnd tip: Give yourself dials to tune battles as they happen. Tweak damage, hit points, number of attacks, spells, and number of combatants when running potentially deadly encounters.
#dnd tip: Offer character-driven suggestions for downtime activities if you worry players don't have anything in mind.
#dnd tip: Add 3 (1d6) necrotic damage to the wights longsword attacks.
#dnd tip: When needed, beef up monsters by giving them an additional attack as part of their attack action.
#dnd tip: Choose the tools that help you best stay flexible and able to improvise during the game.

#dnd tip: Need quick monster or NPC stats? Choose a challenge rating:

AC / DC = 12 + 1/2 CR
Attack and primary saves = 3 + 1/2 CR
HP = 15 + 15 x CR
Damage = 5 + 5 x CR

Tweak to suit individual particularities.
#dnd tip: Playing D&D is more important now than ever before. Find ways to get together with your friends and family and share tales of high adventure.
#dnd tip: Take a break every 90 minutes.
#dnd tip: Take a walk and ponder your game.
#dnd tip: Start and end with the fiction.
#dnd tip: What would happen in this situation if the characters didn't exist?
#dnd tip: Write lists of ten. Encounters, monsters, story seeds, locations, secrets, etc.
#dnd tip: What can the characters do in any given scene?
#dnd tip: What skills are the characters proficient in?
#dnd tip: Keep some dials on hand to increase or decrease the difficulty of a boss battle while it's going on. Hit points and damage output are the two easy ones.
#dnd tip: Let the characters see connections between magical environmental effects and your villains with passive Perception checks.
#dnd tip: Think carefully when an enemy would coup de grace one of the characters; telegraph it ahead of time if you can so it isn't a sad surprise.
#dnd tip: Think less about puzzles the villains would put in place to thwart characters and more about the environment they built for themselves to operate in.
#dnd tip: Smile. Laugh.
#dnd tip: Explore other RPGs. Read them even if you don't play them.
#dnd tip: When using a marilith, have her make her tail attack first to grapple and restrain her enemy and then make six attacks with advantage >=)
#dnd tip: Keep tabs on which villains the players dig and which can safely fade away.
#dnd tip: Aim towards satisfying conclusions in battles or be prepared for disappointed players.
#dnd tip: Drive the story towards and from the meaningful actions of the characters.
#dnd tip: Drive towards opportunities for separated characters to get back together.
#dnd tip: Ensure battles have meaning, purpose, and valuable outcomes.
#dnd tip: Give players a mix of easy and hard encounters.
#dnd tip: When exploring a city, make sure the characters' goals and motivations are clear so the characters aren't wandering aimlessly.
#dnd tip: Give your players a trusted contact in strange cities to help guide them.
#dnd tip: Inspire yourself with maps.
#dnd tip: What monsters make sense for the location?
#dnd tip: What locations in the city would YOU want to go to?
#dnd tip: Make city locations fantastic and remarkable.
#dnd tip: Drop in an interesting encounter during travel from one place to another.
#dnd tip: Not comfortable with burning soul coins in Descent into Avernus? Maybe the war machines are powered by demons!
#dnd tip: Fill dungeons with what would actually be there, not just what matches the characters' level.
#dnd tip: Help players understand how locations work so they can make better decisions to navigate them.
#dnd tip: Reiterate quest goals regularly.
#dnd tip: Describe the world through the eyes of the characters.
#dnd tip: Catastrophe follows a string of failures, not just one.
#dnd tip: Reward bold actions.
#dnd tip: Dial up the damage on monsters above CR 10.
#dnd tip: Find the players who dig your style.
#dnd tip: Squeeze all you can out of a campaign setting. Let the players experience all that makes it unique.
#dnd tip: Treat 1st level as it's own tier. Avoid monsters higher than CR 1.
#dnd tip: Remind the players of what their characters would certainly have remembered.
#dnd tip: Give players warning of potential downtime sessions. Give them suggestions if they come up blank.
#dnd tip: What ten secrets might the characters uncover in the next session?
#dnd tip: Every encounter can teach the players something about the world and the campaign.
#dnd tip: Want to know the average hit points of a character at a given level? 7 x level + 3 gives you the answer. A handy number to keep in mind when considering traps, encounters, or hazards.
#dnd tip: Listen more than you talk.
#dnd tip: Sometimes helping pacifist warforged run a farmer's market is just what we need in our game.
#dnd tip: Build locations your players would want to visit.
#dnd tip: Beneath the most beautiful garden lies forgotten caves with unspeakable horrors.
#dnd tip: Use your fastest image editor to drop location names right onto your favorite map.
#dnd tip: What ten things will the characters find in the next dungeon they crawl?
#dnd tip: Running lots of monsters? Switch to static damage to speed things along.
#dnd tip: When it makes sense, give lower challenge monsters pack tactics to challenge higher-level characters.
#dnd tip: If facing demon princes or archdevils, turn on "hard mode" by doubling the damage they inflict.
#dnd tip: Build cities with ten locations, monuments, and potential encounters.
#dnd tip: Offer three choices.
#dnd tip: Fill ruined cities with interesting factions.
#dnd tip: Steal liberally from your favorite fiction.
#dnd tip: Inspire yourself with your favorite books, movies, or published adventures before your prep.
#dnd tip: Build some encounters from the backgrounds of the characters.
#dnd tip: How does your world's history present itself to the characters in the present-day world?
#dnd tip: When running "theater of the mind" combat reinforce the monks enhanced movement by using the phrase "with your monk-like speed" before describing their options.
#dnd tip: Darkvision in full darkness means everything is in dim light and thus imposes disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks and -5 to passive Perception. Torches are still important.

#dnd tip: An encounter is potentially deadly if the sum total of monster challenge ratings is greater than half the sum total of character levels, or one quarter of character levels if the characters are below 5th level.
#dnd tip: Keep a handful of your favorite maps on hand to fill in improvised locations.
#dnd tip: Work with the players, not against them.
#dnd tip: Worry less about balanced encounters, encounters per day, and draining character resources. Build encounters naturally from the story and situation.
#dnd tip: Always consider what options are available for the characters to talk, explore, or fight their way out of a situation.
#dnd tip: When stealing ideas from books or movies, remember that they don't have to play out as they did in the original fiction. Let the characters change how things work out.
#dnd tip: Take a break from intricate deep campaigns with a small fun dungeon crawl.
#dnd tip: Throw interesting NPCs into your dungeons so characters have someone to interact with without stabbing them.
#dnd tip: Looking for some solo D&D fun? Build out your character's background using Xanathar's "This Is Your Life" chapter. Excellent random inspiration to build fun backgrounds.
#dnd tip: Bathe dungeons in historical lore. Who built it? Who took it over?
#dnd tip: Pool damage when running huge hordes of monsters. Every time the pool takes damage equal to the hit points of one monster, remove one from the horde.
#dnd tip: When attacking or rolling saves with huge hordes of monsters, assume one in four succeeds. Round up or down depending on circumstances.
#dnd tip: What one word theme summarizes your campaign?
#dnd tip: Need a quick dungeon? Grab a map from and annotate it with one or two word descriptions in Paint or Preview.
#dnd tip: Shake up scenes of combat, exploration, and roleplaying. Avoid runnng a long series of just one type of scene.
#dnd tip: Bake in opportunities for roleplaying, exploration, or combat into most scenes.
#dnd tip: Mix up combat encountes with lots of low-challenge monsters and a few with big high-challenge monsters.
#dnd tip: Describe how characters might use the environment to their advantage. Offer opportunities for cover or feats of heroism.
#dnd tip: Offer deals for moderately risky skill checks to gain advantage on an attack. Applaud it when the character's advantages lower or even remove the risk.
#dnd tip: Break up travel scenes with an interesting location backdrop and an encounter that can be approached many different ways.
#dnd tip: In treasure bundles offer interesting thematically-rich items through which characters can cast powerful spells a single time.
#dnd tip: Tell different players different facts about NPCs they know about out of the game. Let them share their secrets at the table.
#dnd tip: Trouble getting inspired for your D&D game? Grab on to the coolest thing in your next session and run with it.
#dnd tip: Prepare to improvise but if you know something is going to happen, spend the time to make it awesome.
#dnd tip: Describe interesting terrain and offer deals so the characters can use it in cool heroic ways.
#dnd tip: Set up situations and let the characters choose how to approach it.
#dnd tip: Let the story unfold at the table. Enjoy the surprises.
#dnd tip: Build out cities and overland areas with lists of ten interesting locations or features.
#dnd tip: Reveal secrets and clues during random encounters to make the world feel chaotic and alive while still moving the story forward.
#dnd tip: There are few more powerful tools thank curated randomness. Use your creative brains to fill out adventures fueled wirh random tables.
#dnd tip: Develop three geographic exploration routes with three interesting potential features along each route.
#dnd tip: Build wilderness encounters from the environment, a fantastic feature, interesting monsters or NPCs, and weather.
#dnd tip: The best tools are those that help you stay flexible and improvise during the game.
#dnd tip: What choices lie in front of the characters in each upcoming scene?
#dnd tip: Wrap random encounters in the history, lore, and secrets of your campaign and your world. Every encounter teaches something.
#dnd tip: Drop an interesting encounter in an interesting location in the middle of scenes of overland travel.
#dnd tip: Having trouble finding inspiration for your game? Roll on some random tables and see what it fires up in your imagination.
#dnd tip: Having trouble with an adventure concept? Go back to the Dungeon Master's Guide and see what it has to say about it.
#dnd tip: Diagram multiple paths through a location to help the players make clear decisions.
#dnd tip: Describe what spells look like.
#dnd tip: Take breaks every 90 minutes.
#dnd tip: Most effective way to deal with counterspell? Stay more than 60 feet away from the counterspeller.
#dnd tip: Drop non-hostile NPCs into even the most deadly of dungeons.
#dnd tip: Regularly outline the choices in front of the characters.
#dnd tip: Assume characters act smartly; they see what players often do not.
#dnd tip: Offer choices with enough information for informed decisions.
#dnd tip: Use the default tokens in Your instincts tell you to customize every token but the default tokens work just as well and you can better spend that time on other aspects of your game prep.
#dnd tip: Take notes.
#dnd tip: How does the next scene propel the story forward?
#dnd tip: Shift the spotlight of the story to the next most interesting and exciting moment. Move quickly past the mundane.
#dnd tip: Build out your toolbox with every tool that helps you share stories of high adventure and none of the tools that get in the way.
#dnd tip: Let go of old ideas, techniques, and tools you find no longer serve you. Be conscious of your own bias towards loss aversion.
#dnd tip: Get VTT tokens for every D&D monster with the Avrae D&D bot's "!token" command in Discord. See
#dnd tip: Reuse and recycle NPCs so the characters maintain continuity with people they've already met.
#dnd tip: Make sure the players have something to do in any given scene. It's not enough to simply observe the situation.
#dnd tip: Use the environment to tell the story of the world and its history.
#dnd tip: Share the history of the world in small bite-sized bits of mysterious and interesting lore.
#dnd tip: Include secret doors, rooms, and chambers in your locations.
#dnd tip: Use maps with short cuts and loop backs to give a sense of discovery.
#dnd tip: Talk to new potential players before they jump into your game; find out if their style matches your own, the other players, and the rest of the game.
#dnd tip: The best things you can do to improve your game are free.
#dnd tip: The plural of cyclops is "cyclopes" (sy-klo-peas).
#dnd tip: Avoid decision paralysis by offering useful information to make informed decisions.
#dnd tip: Find the easiest path to bring in a new character and integrate them into the group. The story comes second behind the fun of the game.
#dnd tip: Include multiple paths, entrances, secrets, and short cuts.
#dnd tip: Build adventures around interesting locations.
#dnd tip: Prepare the ingredients you need to cook the story at the table. Don't come to the table with the story already fully prepared.
#dnd tip: Wrap traditional monsters in the cool and unique flavor of your world. They're not just armored hill giants, they're the armored giants of Maena's Fist.
#dnd tip: Chapter 3 of the Dungeon Master's Guide is an excellent resource for generating straight forward adventure ideas. It should be the first chapter DMs read.
#dnd tip: Lost for ideas? Get back to the basics with a fun dungeon romp.
#dnd tip: Bathe locations in layers of history, each peeling away revealing frescos of past civilizations.
#dnd tip: Size and age are the two easiest ways to make something fantastic.
#dnd tip: Expect and prepare for challenging battles above level 10 to take some time.
#dnd tip: Give your locations hidden shortcuts the characters can discover and exploit.
#dnd tip: Add daily-use spells to typical +1 magic items and a flavorful name to go along with them.
#dnd tip: Keep the books you need close at hand.
#dnd tip: Ending early is better than ending late.
#dnd tip: End a session after major choices and directions have been set. This lets you focus your prep on the right area.
#dnd tip: End a session before a major battle so you have time to fully prepare it.
#dnd tip: Talk to your players out of game to see what hooks in the campaign grab them and deserve to be resolved.
#dnd tip: Easy battles are a great way to let the characters show off what they can do.
#dnd tip: Scenes can often fall into exploration, roleplaying, or combat. Don't assume a scene will fall only into a single category.
#dnd tip: Take the time to plan your boss battles.
#dnd tip: Keep track of story threads important to the players. Resolve as many as you can by the campaign's end.
#dnd tip: End campaigns with a "one year later" montage in which each player participates. Warn them ahead of time so they can think about it.
#dnd tip: Planning a battle with the disruption of a dark ritual? Consider how the ritual works so players can figure out how to disrupt it.
#dnd tip: Trade skill checks for advantage on one's next attack to inject cinematic action into your game.
#dnd tip: Give villains magic items and be sure they use them.
#dnd tip: Destroying magical objects can usually be done with damage, applicable attribute (skill) checks, or appropriate spells like dispel magic.
#dnd tip: Work with each player to build a secret for their character they hang onto throughout a campaign. Let them choose when and how to reveal it.
#dnd tip: Build a session zero checklist before you run it.
#dnd tip: Have players build characters together during a session zero to integrate their characters together into a cohesive group.
#dnd tip: Run a short adventure at 1st level at the end of your session zero and get them to 2nd level quickly.
#dnd tip: Give characters a home base they can build up during their campaign.
#dnd tip: Inspire yourself with the sourcebooks and adventures from previous versions of the game.
#dnd tip: Build your campaign from the characters outward. Where are they? What matters to them? Where can they go?
#dnd tip: Help new players mesh well into your group by remembering that what everyone else knows may be brand new to them.
#dnd tip: Pay careful attention to inter-character conflict so it doesn't bleed into inter-player conflict.

#dnd tip: Even in an established group, going over potentially troublesome subject matter during a session zero is important. Understand what should be handled off screen (veiled) and what lines should not be crossed.
#dnd tip: When playing online, offset your lack of understanding through body language by checking in with players individually between games to make sure they're enjoying what's going on.
#dnd tip: When playing online, keep your technology stack as simple as you can make it so people can focus on the game and on each other.
#dnd tip: Getting lost in the depths of your game? Come back to a fun dungeon romp seeking some treasure and fighting some baddies.
#dnd tip: Let your game go in whatever direction it heads as long as it's fun for you and the group. Be flexible.
#dnd tip: Use monsters appropriate to the situation and environment.
#dnd tip: Worry less about mechanical sub-systems and use flavorful descriptions to get the point across.
#dnd tip: Build interesting NPCs by reflavoring characters from your favorite books, movies, and TV shows.
#dnd tip: Give villains three evocative nicknames and a sidekick who goes around towns talking about how dangerous and awesome they are.
#dnd tip: Give players opportunities for roleplaying, exploration, and combat even all within the same scene.
#dnd tip: Use rough abstract maps for quick combat.
#dnd tip: Spend time getting to know your players' characters. What do they want? Where do they come from?
#dnd tip: Use published adventures as a framework and toolbox to put togeter your own adventures.
#dnd tip: Recast the motivations of published NPCs to suit the story unfolding at your own table.
#dnd tip: Ask your players regularly what they want for their characters. Write it down and drop it in when you can.
#dnd tip: Be ready to drop in options for exploration, roleplaying, or combat depending on the pacing and feeling of the game at the moment.
#dnd tip: Bathe your campaign in overarching themes and atmospheres. Drop in clues and flavor of these themes throughout.
#dnd tip: End adventure after big decision have been made so you know where to prep next.
#dnd tip: When stuck for ideas, get back to the basics of monsters in a dungeon guarding an item the characters need.
#dnd tip: Focus your narrative towards offering choices and leading to the actions of the characters.
#dnd tip: Mix in unexpected benefits and unexpected complications to keep the pace of the game exciting.
#dnd tip: Give players the information their characters would know. Their characters have a far greater understanding in the world than the players do.
#dnd tip: Help the players refine their plans towards likely solutions.
#dnd tip: Clarify the situation as characters develop their plans.
#dnd tip: Bathe the world in fantastic descriptions.
#dnd tip: Spice up the world with weather.
#dnd tip: Go where the story leads.
#dnd tip: Worry less about balancing challenge and draining resources and more about building fun situations the characters can navigate.
#dnd tip: Give each town its own theme, flavor, and notable landmark.
#dnd tip: Road ambushes are a good way to squeeze a fight into some travel scenes.
#dnd tip: Prepare for characters to try to talk their way out of violent confrontations.
#dnd tip: Be on the players' side.
#dnd tip: Looking for a more open and flexible framework for skill challenges? Check out Progress Clocks from Blades in the Dark.
#dnd tip: Keep a handful of character archetypes from your favorite books, movies, or TV shows on hand to improvise NPC personalities during the game.
#dnd tip: Let threads die if the players aren't following them.
#dnd tip: Write out a list of ten to twenty cool backdrops for random encounters that make sense for your game's world.
#dnd tip: Use single-use magic items to offer continual rewards without making your characters too powerful.
#dnd tip: Ambushes are an easy and gripping strong start.
#dnd tip: Give players interesting secrets and clues while battling their foes.
#dnd tip: During your session zero, ensure characters have a reason and motivation to help townfolk survive the forces of evil.
#dnd tip: Getting jumped by ghouls is a good strong start.
#dnd tip: Grab onto beloved NPCs with both hands.
#dnd tip: Describe your whole campaign with a single word.
#dnd tip: Build the world from the characters outward.
#dnd tip: Throw out lots of plot threads and let those die that hold little interest.
#dnd tip: Use the right tools for the right form of combat.
#dnd tip: Always be foreshadowing.
#dnd tip: Let the players debate questionable choices. Be prepared to break character and ensure everyone's cool with the result.
#dnd tip: Are the characters eating through "hard" encounters? Treat them as one or more levels higher than they are when checking encounter difficulty.
#dnd tip: Let NPCs grow as you roleplay them. You may suddenly find an NPC acting completely differently once you step into their character.
#dnd tip: Be willing to take the thread of a published adventure into a new area you find more interesting.
#dnd tip: Monsters make mistakes. Don't be afraid to let the characters get the upper hand.
#dnd tip: Few creatures are more dangerous than the swarm of rats.
#dnd tip: Give characters the opportunity to dramatically change the course of the story with a single action or die roll.
#dnd tip: Let the story and situation drive appropriate ability checks which further drive the story and situation into new areas.
#dnd tip: Think of success and failures as analog dials instead of a binary True or False.
#dnd tip: Build hard situations and help the characters navigate them towards success.
#dnd tip: Give each town an interesting characteristic that sets it apart from all other towns.
#dnd tip: Use your amazing universe-simulating brain to determine the outcomes of a complicated series of ability checks instead of a narrow flowchart.
#dnd tip: Ignore complicated sub-systems. Focus on adjudicating the situation, the choices of the characters, and the results of their ability checks. Adjudicate the situation as these things change.

#dnd tip: Prep in the fiction, not the mechanics. How does that dark ritual work in the world? Let the characters figure out how to disrupt it and then work with them to find the right mechanics to do so.
#dnd tip: Build locations that will make your players say "wow".
#dnd tip: Change up the situation round-by-round in big climactic battles that take hour to run.
#dnd tip: Don't drop all of the big story reveals at once. Space the out so players have time to digest and enjoy them.
#dnd tip: How do the villains relate to the characters?
#dnd tip: Give major villains a spokesperson. Antlers the Killer Moose has Thumper, the shit-talking hare.
#dnd tip: Plan for multiple possible outcomes in any given situation. Ideally, plan no particular outcome at all.
#dnd tip: Give the characters a home base with a unique fantatic feature.
#dnd tip: Warn players ahead of time of the potential for downtime so the can plan their actions.
#dnd tip: Customize a published campaign adventure by tying it to the characters, their backgrounds, and their goals.
#dnd tip: End at the beginning of a huge battle to build a strong start for your next session.
#dnd tip: Choose magic items both randomly and from those that make sense for the characters.
#dnd tip: Give your villains access to magic items that will soon fall in the hands of the players.
#dnd tip: Potions and scrolls are a great way to beef up a villain.
#dnd tip: Characters having an easy time? Treat them as one level higher when calculating potentially deadly encounters.
#dnd tip: When in doubt, run a dungeon full of cultists. Everyone loves cultists.
#dnd tip: Set up situations and let the players choose how their characters navigate them.
#dnd tip: Offer three options + any others they come up with.
#dnd tip: Keep a list of quest and adventure templates that work well in a variety of situations. Kill the boss; steal the MacGuffin; rescue the prince; stop the ritual; etc.
#dnd tip: Look for the spaces in published adventures where you can stick in your own ideas.
#dnd tip: Build your physical and mental toolkit to help you facilitate the stories that bloom at the table.
#dnd tip: End on cliffhangers.
#dnd tip: Add secret doors, secret passages, loops, and short cuts to you dungeon maps or seek those maps that have them.
#dnd tip: Prepare and be ready to drop in easy battles, hard battles, interesting discoveries, and interesting NPCs into your dungeon crawls.
#dnd tip: Drive narration from the points of view, backgrounds, and skills of the characters. Avoid passive voice narrrations. Let the characters discover the world around them.

#dnd tip: Give weak monsters circumstantial advantages when facing high-level characters. Cultists can drink demonic blood to give them advantage and extra necrotic damage before exploding into demons.
#dnd tip: Give bosses access to powerful potions, scrolls, and other single-use magic items.
#dnd tip: Advantage, disadvantage, inspiration, and the sliding scale of DCs are your tools for improvising just about any situation in D&D.
#dnd tip: Write down ten things you learned after running any given session of D&D.
#dnd tip: Lean in to the unexpected.
#dnd tip: Prep simple adventures.
#dnd tip: Add elements of roleplaying, exploration, and discovery inside your long multi-stage battes. You can run an entire D&D game within the bounds of a big battle.
#dnd tip: Breathe deep. Your game will be fine.
#dnd tip: What did each of your players love in your last game? What do they want to see in the future? Ask them.
#dnd tip: Adventures serve as inspiration and frameworks for the stories you and your players to share at the table.
#dnd tip: Run simple adventures. Your players will make them complicated.
#dnd tip: Keep potential quest to around three. Enough to have meaningful choices but not too many to cause decision paralysis.
#dnd tip: Every few sessions ask players what they're enjoying about the campaign and what they'd like to see in future sessions.
#dnd tip: Build your world and campaign from the characters outward. Build for your next couple of adventures.
#dnd tip: Review your characters first and build in secrets, NPCs, and locations meaningful to those characters.
#dnd tip: Secrets and clues are the treasure and rewards for exploration and discovery.
#dnd tip: Ensure your players are on board with the theme and structure of your adventure, whether it's an open sandbox or a story-driven campaign.
#dnd tip: Use the published material that excites you and looks like the most fun to use.
#dnd tip: Add elements of exploration, discovery, and roleplaying into your huge boss battles.
#dnd tip: Steal great ideas.
#dnd tip: Let characters shine.
#dnd tip: Mash ideas together.
#dnd tip: Give players time to consider their options for downtime scenes.
#dnd tip: Drop fantastic locations and monuments along long overland journeys.
#dnd tip: Ask players to describe their killing blow.
#dnd tip: Turn killing blows into decisive blows that give defeated bosses an opportunity to negotiate or offer interesting secrets.
#dnd tip: Put the characters in hard situations and work with them to escape.
#dnd tip: Bathe the world in texture and details.
#dnd tip: Put options in front of the players near the end of your game so you know what to prep next.
#dnd tip: Tie environmental effects from Tasha's Cauldron of Everything to fantastic monuments the heroes come across in the world.
#dnd tip: Avoid story-driven thefts the character's can't stop. Give them a chance to stop the theft or chase down the stolen goods.
#dnd tip: Let the villians and minions operate as they would in the world, with the information and capabilities they have. Run them like living people, even in the background.
#dnd tip: Little is more fun than two brash bandits who overestimate their chances.
#dnd tip: Build situations, describe options, reiterate the goal.
#dnd tip: Highlight the fantastic accomplishments of the heroes.
#dnd tip: Use heralds that build up the villains for the characters. Sometimes they'll be the most hated NPCs in the game.
#dnd tip: Write down a strong start, three to five fantastic locations, and ten secrets the characters might discover and you're all set.
#dnd tip: Use critical hits and critical misses as ways to push new directions into the story.
#dnd tip: Ask specific players for their thoughts on potential options when the group faces multiple paths.
#dnd tip: When desired, give monsters additional attacks when facing a group of characters alone.
#dnd tip: Drop an interesting location as the characters travel from one main place to another.
#dnd tip: Use rough abstract maps and theater of the mind for smaller battles and more tactical combat for big boss fights.
#dnd tip: Run with as few tools as you need to share an awesome story.
#dnd tip: Build a group of six players plus two "on call" players and be willing to play with as few as three. It takes six cancellations to not run a game.
#dnd tip: Captured enemies serve as easy vehicles for secrets and clues.
#dnd tip: Drop in single use magical relics with interesting connections to the world and its mysteries.
#dnd tip: Develop an understanding for the offensive and defensive capabilities of the characters; it serves you better than encounter balance tools and tables.
#dnd tip: Add fantastic backdrops to your random encounters.
#dnd tip: Check in with players often to ensure the game and their character's role in it is going the direction they want it to go.
#dnd tip: Shift between easy and challenging fights to the players enjoy the full range of their characters.
#dnd tip: Suggest players build and level characters together to work towards complementary abilities.
#dnd tip: Regularly reiterate the goals of the adventure or quest.
#dnd tip: Players understand half of what you're describing.
#dnd tip: Be wary when taking away a player's agency from their character.
#dnd tip: Reinforce that a character cannot adversely affect another character without their player's permission.
#dnd tip: Give your boss a couple of big dumb brutes to give characters something to banish and otherwise crowd control and a big pile of weak monsters to blast to smitherines.
#dnd tip: One-on-one games are a fantastic way to focus a game around the story of a single character. It's a different, yet no less fun, way to play D&D.
#dnd tip: What tools do you need to run a game? What gets in the way?
#dnd tip: Whenever you have questions, dive back into the story and the NPCs in it. Think through their eyes. What would they do?

#dnd tip: At 11th level and above, a battle may be deadly if the sum total of monster challenge ratings is 3/4th the sum total of character levels. Or equal to the sum of character levels if they're 17th or above.
#dnd tip: Save time by using existing maps instead of drawing your own.
#dnd tip: Adding monsters is the easiest way to make a fight more dangerous.
#dnd tip: Highlight the important points of your narration and keep it brief and focused.
#dnd tip: 3x5 cards are the DM's secret weapon for preparing and running games.
#dnd tip: Save time by avoiding transcribing monster stat blocks. Bookmark your books or online pages instead.
#dnd tip: D&D Beyond, Discord, and Avrae together build an excellent online D&D platform.
#dnd tip: D&D is, first and foremost, a shared story with random variables. Build out from that core idea.
#dnd tip: Ask players to describe interesting physical characteristics of monsters beginning with the letter of the monster's token or in your D&D Beyond Encounter Builder roster.
#dnd tip: Give players meaningful options.
#dnd tip: Handle NPC battles off-screen. Describe the results rather than roll dice against yourself.
#dnd tip: Run a new session zero as new players come into your campaign.
#dnd tip: Give players time between sessions to consider their downtime activities.
#dnd tip: Random encounters need not be combat. Sometimes its a friendly merchant. Othertimes its an ancient white dragon swooping down on a yeti.
#dnd tip: Think big and fantasic with your locations and features. You have an unlimited special effects budget.
#dnd tip: Seek books, comics, movies, TV shows, and games that push your imagination into wild new areas. Absorb everything and let it fuel your games.

#dnd tip: Find and tie together the intersections between character backgrounds and the stories in a campaign. Is that villain a cousin? Are those prisoners from your village? Is that skeleton a former adventuring colleague?
#dnd tip: Run turns for downtime scenes for each character like you would for any other scene. Make sure every character gets to do something and doesn't take too much of the spotlight.
#dnd tip: Warn players ahead of time that you'll be including a downtime scene so they can prepare ahead of time.
#dnd tip: Offer custom downtime options tied to the characters and the story. Offer what you think they'd want to do.
#dnd tip: Use an abstract map or some loose visualization for hard fights against lots of monsters so players have a good idea what they face and how they face them.
#dnd tip: Work with the players' intent when running Theater of the Mind combat. What are they trying to do?
#dnd tip: Monsters need not act optimally in every battle.
#dnd tip: Give players the option to break out of debilitating status effects like Stun by taking damage to break free.

#dnd tip: Before your game, spend a minute visualizing you and your friends at the table and ask what you need on hand to run the game. Write a checklist and grab those things before you run the game.

#dnd tip: Things you may need to run your game: numbered initiative tents, character minis, monster minis or tokens, flip mat, 3x5 cards, dry erase markers, sharpies, list of random names, monster books, the DMG, the Lazy DMs Workbook.
#dnd tip: Let action-starved monsters fire off cool abilities as bonus actions or as part of their attack action so they have a chance to show off their unique characteristics.
#dnd tip: Copy and paste or highlight useful bits of lore from published material you can expose to the characters as secrets and clues.
#dnd tip: Interesting and useful lore is the reward for exploration.
#dnd tip: Put yourself in the shoes of the NPC. See through their eyes. How would they act in the situation?
#dnd tip: End on a cliffhanger and set up strong start at your next game.
#dnd tip: Delight in the successes of the characters.
#dnd tip: Lean towards revealing too much instead of revealing too little.
#dnd tip: If a player seems disconnected from the current story, work with them to see how their character might have a deeper connection than either of you realized.
#dnd tip: Know when to drop in combat, roleplaying, or exploration based on the current pace of the game.
#dnd tip: Bathe your adventures in the details of the world and its history.
#dnd tip: What three villains currently weave their webs in the background of your campaign?
#dnd tip: Think through the eyes of your NPCs. How do you think they'll act or react?
#dnd tip: The day after your game, think about how it went and jot down your own tips.
#dnd tip: Check your list of secrets throughout the game to see what you can drop in where.
#dnd tip: Copy and paste text from your published adventures and sourcebooks and format them as handouts you can give to your players.
#dnd tip: Choose monsters that make sense for the story and situation first and THEN figure out if the challenge meets your intent and the pacing of the game.
#dnd tip: Put characters first.
#dnd tip: Prep only what you need for your next session.
#dnd tip: You get to choose what's canon at your table.
#dnd tip: Read the monster manual.
#dnd tip: Expose fantastic lore through secrets and clues.
#dnd tip: Be a kid again.
#dnd tip: Trade cynicism for wonder.
#dnd tip: Be brief in descriptions. Get to the action.
#dnd tip: What can the characters do in the scene? What choices can they make?
#dnd tip: Build situations instead of outlines.
#dnd tip: Think about how things work in the world before worrying about mechanics.
#dnd tip: Use handouts to organize and focus your game for your players and for you.
#dnd tip: It's better to end a session early than to end one late.
#dnd tip: End a session after the characters have made a big decision about where to go next.
#dnd tip: Change published adventures to suit your players and characters.
#dnd tip: Spend time understanding how your players enjoy the game. Are they looking for something relaxed and low key or looking for something brutal and hard core?
#dnd tip: End your session right before a big battle and start strong at your next session.
#dnd tip: Monsters hitting below their weight class? Give them an extra attack or two.
#dnd tip: Build campaigns from the characters outward.
#dnd tip: For players, taking and sharing notes is a great way to avoid distractions and be even more useful to the rest of the group.
#dnd tip: Short one on one games are a great way to get in some D&D in a short bit of time.
#dnd tip: Good cult fanatic tactics: round 1 spirit weapon and sacred flame, round 2 guiding bolt and spirit weapon attack, round 3 inflict wounds and spirit weapon attack.
#dnd tip: Reflavor a cult fanatics spells to fit the dark gods they follow.
#dnd tip: Offer three choices for new quests and adventures. Prune the options that remain unchosen.
#dnd tip: Run survival aspects of your game (food tracking, cold weather travel, encumbrance) as long as it's fun and handwave it when it becomes tedious and boring.
#dnd tip: Offer fast travel options such as airships and portals when the world opens up to the characters at higher level.
#dnd tip: What are the three possible options the characters discover in the next game?
