#dnd tip: Your tools and tricks for running great games are there to serve you. You don't owe them anything. Use what works. Modify to suit. Throw things away.
#dnd tip: Think about the hooks the characters might have with an NPC you're going to introduce.
#dnd tip: Drawing maps may be fun but it isn't necessary. There are hoards of maps out there waiting for you to pilfer.
#dnd tip: Integrate new characters quickly through trust and companionship. Describe the heroic spark in their eyes and get quickly past initial distrust.
#dnd tip: Build a toolbox in your head of tools and tricks that help you improvise your games at the table.
#dnd tip: Offer customized character options for downtime scenes.
#dnd tip: Run games and learn from them.
#dnd tip: Offer three interesting and meaningful choices.
#dnd tip: Skip the boring parts.
#dnd tip: Keep an eye on mood, pacing, and beats. Adjust as needed.
#dnd tip: Keep a list of locations, NPC's, monsters, and secrets on hand for each session.
#dnd tip: When using a virtual tabletop, speed up prep time by turning off the visual grid and turning off "snap to grid". Thus you can spend less time trying to line up imperfectly-aligned map.
#dnd tip: Describe the world from the eyes, capabilities, and backgrounds of the characters.
#dnd tip: Think of locations is the backgrounds to a play. Give each location an evocative name and three interesting features.
#dnd tip: Looking to add morale to your monsters? The DMG has you covered. Roll a DC 10 Wisdom saving thro when it makes sense for a monster to potentially flee.
#dnd tip: Non-legendary boss monsters feeling action constrained? Give them an extra action they can take on their turn.

#dnd tip: Change the number and type of monsters in published adventures to suit the current pace and feeling at your table. Lots of hard fights? Maybe they only run into one. Having an easy time? Maybe it's a dozen.
#dnd tip: Maps are for more than just combat. Use them for exploration and even roleplaying.
#dnd tip: Use waves of monsters to keep the pressure up in great big battles. Bring out the boss last.
#dnd tip: Subtlety often gets lost in the translation of ideas from DM to players. Sometimes you need to be direct. Describe what their characters notice.

#dnd tip: Pool damage done to an entire horde of monsters instead of individually. Every time they take damage equal to the HP of a monster, remove a monster. Round HP to the nearest 5 or 10 to make life easy. Horde hit with an AOE? Remove those who fail their save.
#dnd tip: Go with the flow of the game.
#dnd tip: Prep published adventures from the path the characters are likely to take.
#dnd tip: Alternate between hard battles, potentially easy battles, roleplay scenes, and exploration.
#dnd tip: Build paths and choices based on different types of gameplay so players can choose the type of game they enjoy.
#dnd tip: Offer suggestions if the players seem to miss obvious solutions.
#dnd tip: Treat the characters like experienced adventurers facing life and death decisions.
#dnd tip: Find the easiest way to bring in a new character and note the heroic spark in their eye to avoid thirty minute of suspicious questioning.
#dnd tip: Give NPCs interesting details to make them easier to remember.
#dnd tip: Write down NPC names as soon as they're exposed to the players. They've become real at that point.
#dnd tip: Let the characters use the environment to get the edge on their foes.
#dnd tip: Characters getting thrown off a cliff? Give them an athletics or acrobatics check to catch themselves and only take a little damage instead of a 20d6 fall.
#dnd tip: For a series of ability checks, think about how the situation works in the world first and what needs to be done. Then assign DCs and ability checks to the in-world situations.
#dnd tip: When revealing vital but hidden information, call for a group ability check and give the highest roller the information they see.
#dnd tip: Call for ability checks and let the players bring forward skills that may be applicable and how they'd use them in the fiction.
#dnd tip: Make quick legendary creatures with three legendary resistances and three legendary actions per round with their most appropriate single attack and a non-provoking move.
#dnd tip: Add interesting environmental details for big boss fights. Improvise how they behave when the characters mess with them.
#dnd tip: Take turns going through downtime scenes. Rely on your abstract secrets and clues to fill in interesting details the characters learn during downtime.
#dnd tip: Don't overdo NPC to NPC discussions. Involve the characters as much as possible.
#dnd tip: Though you may find yourself in the DM chair because no one else would take it, you may find DMing to be an incredibly rewarding experience. Lean into it.
#dnd tip: Focus on the characters. Build the story from them. Keep them in the spotlight.
#dnd tip: Avoid DM PCs and tag-along NPCs. Keep the focus on the characters.
#dnd tip: Experiment with jump-cuts into high action scenes. "A yeti punches you in the face"".
#dnd tip: Run multiple non-legendary bosses simultaneously when characters hit 7th level and above.
#dnd tip: Don't get frustrated with banish. Embrace it in the fiction.
#dnd tip: Expect the whole feeling of the game to change at certain level increases. 5th feels very different than 4th. 7th feels different than 6th.
#dnd tip: Build situations, see how the characters choose to interact with it, adjudicate the world's response.
#dnd tip: Give your notes a quick read-through right before your game to internalize what's important.
#dnd tip: Higher levels is more than harder monsters. The scope and scale of the whole story should change.
#dnd tip: Take a moment to consider the mood and energy level of the table and adjust accordingly.
#dnd tip: Give characters opportunities where time isn't a factor and they can take their time to decide on their approach.
#dnd tip: Give lots of chances to fail forward in conversations with NPCs. It doesn't have to be one check and done.
#dnd tip: Always consider what choices and opportunities for a character's action exist in any given scene. Narrative-only scenes get stale fast.
#dnd tip: Jot down three bullets of interesting features for each fantastic location you intended to run.
#dnd tip: Listen to audiobooks to hear how narrators describe high fantasy.
#dnd tip: Consider how random combat encounters reveal secrets to the characters as they do battle. What can they learn from the fight?
#dnd tip: Is a player rolling terribly in a battle? Call on their character to discover interesting or vital secrets during the fight.
#dnd tip: Mix up easy battles and hard battles; battles against many foes and battles against a few.
#dnd tip: Mix up scenes of roleplaying, exploration, and combat.
#dnd tip: Mix in random treasure and treasure selected to support the characters.
#dnd tip: Make magic items unique with an origin and a condition. Add history and a cool name.
#dnd tip: Include secrets about NPCs, locations, history, gods, villains, and plots.
#dnd tip: Expose secrets through artwork, NPCs, magic items, books, scrolls, dreams, portents, and characters' historical knowledge.
#dnd tip: Scale up the story of your campaign by orders of magnitude as the characters reach 5th, 11th, and 17th level.
#dnd tip: Study the capabilities of the characters both to help you challenge them and let them shine.
#dnd tip: Enjoy connecting larger campaign adventures and sharing those connections with the players even if the characters don't understand the connections.
#dnd tip: Prepare for any single powerful creature to get banished once the characters reach 7th level.
#dnd tip: Three bosses are better than one.
#dnd tip: Use the characters' skill proficiencies and passive ability checks to share information as they explore the world.
#dnd tip: Share the world through the eyes of the characters. What do they see? What do they notice?
#dnd tip: Customize published adventures around the backgrounds and drives of the characters.
#dnd tip: Keep things simple. Sometimes a straight-forward dungeon crawl is just the thing.
#dnd tip: Ensure friendly NPCs show up even in the darkest dungeons.
#dnd tip: Build interesting variant monsters by applying traits from one monster stat block to another.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to jack up that damage dial on monsters above CR 10.
#dnd tip: If you offer a choice, expect players to choose either one. Prepare for them to dive into the wrong answer.
#dnd tip: Customize monster stat blocks on the fly. You know better than anyone how a monster might work at your own table.
#dnd tip: Don't be stingy with magic items.

#dnd tip: Need to roll a d20 but don't have any dice? Use a stopwatch. Look at the tenths and hundredths digits. The hundredths is the single digit. If the tenths is even, that's a 10 + the hundredths. If it's odd it's 0 + the hundredths. A .80 is a 20!
#dnd tip: Dragons make great quest-giving NPCs.
#dnd tip: Identify legendary foes.
#dnd tip: In big challenging fights, give the characters enemies to crowd control.
#dnd tip: Understand the damage output, hit points, and combat capabilities of your specific group. This offers much greater insight than overall challenge ratings.

#dnd tip: Give legendary monsters a physical in-world representation of their legendary resistances such as tattoos that wink out, floating ioun stones that explode, or gemstone teeth that crack. Thanks Level-up A5E!
#dnd tip: Prepare some in-town events for downtime scenes. What might the characters see or learn about while engaging in their downtime?
#dnd tip: Think about how a tough combat challenges the characters instead of just worrying if it's tough.
#dnd tip: Use exotic spells from non-core books and third party publishers as a special type of loot.
#dnd tip: Tie third-party spells to single-use magic items. That way, if its totally broken, you only have to deal with it once.
#dnd tip: End at the beginning of a battle so you know you're going to start strong.
#dnd tip: Initiative begins the minute one creature commits a hostile act against another.
#dnd tip: Use, re-skin, and tweak existing monsters instead of building your own.
#dnd tip: Quick monster stats: AC/DC = 12 + 1/2 CR; HP = 15 * CR; Attack / Proficiencies = 3 + 1/2 CR; Damage = 7 (2d6) per level.
#dnd tip: Mix up opportunities for exploration, role play, and combat even when dungeon delving.
#dnd tip: Pay attention to the skill proficiency selections of the characters so you know what to tug on during the game
#dnd tip: Clarify choices
#dnd tip: Represent legendary resistance in-world. Glowing ioun stones, glyphed teeth, stone obelisks, runed scales, layers of magical protection.
#dnd tip: Identify legendary foes so players know what to expect.
#dnd tip: Understand how the urgency of the story affects the choices of the characters. Turn that urgency dial accordingly.
#dnd tip: Don't worry about having to read up on a room when the character enter it in a dungeon crawl. The flexibility of going anywhere is more important than being perfectly prepared.
#dnd tip: Use single use or permanent magic items as hooks to explore risky or dangerous situations.
#dnd tip: Prompt individual characters on their thoughts about what to do next.
#dnd tip: Players used to playing online often stay silent to avoid talking over one another. Ask individuals for their thoughts and choices.
#dnd tip: Use random encounter tables to show battles that happened before.

#dnd tip: All non-core books are optional. Choose which books and material to include into your campaign instead of allowing everything and having to exclude stuff. Flavor your campaign by the sources allowed.
#dnd tip: Tailor your campaign's theme with thematic third party material. Kobold Press in particular. Their stuff is awesome.
#dnd tip: Scheming NPCs act in their own best interest. Betrayal isn't inevitable.
#dnd tip: Go with something cool or fun even if it breaks some realism.
#dnd tip: In more open-world adventures or cities, think about the three places the characters might go in three different directions.
#dnd tip: "Pause for a minute" to break character and, as players, discuss and resolve inter-character conflicts.
#dnd tip: Let the characters see random encounters wandering by and let them decide if they want to engage them or not.

#dnd tip: Be careful dropping traps and surprise attacks on the character whose player is willing to use them to propel the story forward. Don't regularly punish characters for taking initiative in the story.
#dnd tip: Take breaks every ninety minutes.
#dnd tip: Describe the world through the eyes, backgrounds, and proficiencies of the characters.
#dnd tip: Add monsters designed to eat the characters' favorite save-or-suck spells like Banish, Polymorph, Hypnotic Pattern, or Stunning Strike.
#dnd tip: Beware the too-long monologue. Let the characters jump in and punch the monologuing villain.
#dnd tip: Spells or powers seemingly too good to be true often are. Give them a quick read to see what's being missed.
#dnd tip: Greater challenges most often come from more monsters but so too does the duration of the battle.
#dnd tip: Focus on the prep time and materials that bring the most fun to your game.
#dnd tip: Use rough abstract battle maps with relative distances when players can't visualize pure theater of the mind.
#dnd tip: Ask yourself if all the time spent setting up dynamic lighting actually makes your game better.
#dnd tip: Focus your time and attention on the parts of your campaign you love the most.
#dnd tip: Not digging what you read in a published adventure? Wish it was something else? Do that instead.
#dnd tip: Use published material as sources of inspiration to fuel your own adventures.
#dnd tip: Be prepared for the characters to attempt negotiation with every monster you drop on the table even if a fight is what they're really after.
#dnd tip: Expand or reduce future battles based on the results of the previous. Did they have an easy time? Beef things up. Did they have a rough time? Drop it down.
#dnd tip: Reducing monster hit points is the easiest way to tune down the length of combat. Increasing damage is the easiest way to increase danger.
#dnd tip: Keep descriptions down to three sentences. Make them fantastic, useful, and oriented towards the characters' actions.
#dnd tip: Ask your players what they hope for as you come to the close of your campaign.
#dnd tip: Consider the arcs of each character as you come close to the end of your game.
#dnd tip: Waves of combatants is a great way to challenge powerful parties without dumping everything on them at once.
#dnd tip: Ensure the story evolves in long combat. Give players the opportunity for exploration and roleplaying even as combat rages on.
#dnd tip: Low hit points and high damage make for great minions at high levels.
#dnd tip: Add 2d6 elemental damage to a monster's attack to boost their threat. Flavor their attacks with the type of element. Dripping acidic claws, necrotic blades, blazing axes, etc.
#dnd tip: Describe the world from the characters' point of view.
#dnd tip: A "one year later" montage is a great way to hand a character's arc over to their player at the end of a campaign.
#dnd tip: Challenge high-level and high-power characters with waves of enemies in a single battle.
#dnd tip: Add groups of monsters in big piles the characters can blast or control for fun and profit.
#dnd tip: Tie level progression to specific quests or accomplishments in the story of your game. Articulate them up front. Thanks @mattcolville!
#dnd tip: Leave at least 30 minutes for the end of your campaign after the final battle. Give the players time to breathe and enjoy their victory.
#dnd tip: Build off what the players bring to the story.
#dnd tip: Improvise multi-success or failure progress clocks to mirror complex situations in the world.
#dnd tip: Internalize the mood, theme, and atmosphere of an adventure and campaign as much as the details.
#dnd tip: During your session zero, focus the characters motivations around the theme and drive of the campaign.
#dnd tip: Put yourself in the shoes of the NPCs and act as they would act.
#dnd tip: Use a "pause for a minute" voice queue so you or any player can break character for a moment, address any issues, and ensure the game is on the right track.
#dnd tip: Describe the world from the point of view of the characters.
#dnd tip: Keep track of the skills and languages each character knows to aid you in describing the world without breaking to ask.
#dnd tip: You have what you need. You'll be great.
#dnd tip: Let the players know when it's safe and not safe to split the party.
#dnd tip: Remember, it's just a game. Do what you need to do, in or out of character, to keep the game running smoothly.
#dnd tip: Consider carefully how you treat the theme of the scene, the adventure, and the campaign. Small changes can have big effects.
#dnd tip: From Shawn Merwin's idea of the "unity of effect" - Everything in a scene should (and does!) reinforce the theme and tone of the adventure.
#dnd tip: Check in with your players each session to make sure they're happy with the direction things are going.
#dnd tip: Know which clues are vital and be ready to drop them in in many different places.
#dnd tip: Share too many secrets instead of too few.
#dnd tip: Clarify the theme of your adventure and campaign.
#dnd tip: You're campaign's theme counts for about half of a player's engagement with the game. The other half focuses on their character.
#dnd tip: Make things happen. Let things happen.
#dnd tip: The moment a player's character receives a fun single-use magic item is the most enjoyable moment. If they hoard it, that's fine.
#dnd tip: Describe. Listen. Respond.
#dnd tip: Worry less about overpowered single-use magic items. They may unbalance one battle but that makes a remarkable story.
#dnd tip: Clarify choices.
#dnd tip: First and formost, players want to watch their characters do cool stuff.
#dnd tip: Get the scene to the actions and decisions of the characters as fast as you can.
#dnd tip: Ask your players to describe their characters' new tricks when they level so you know what the players are excited about.
#dnd tip: Mash up your favorite adventures.
#dnd tip: Ask players what their characters think of their current situations and views of the road ahead.
#dnd tip: Roll random encounters ahead of time and see if they spark your interest.
#dnd tip: Tie random encounters to the rest of the story with well-placed secrets and clues.
#dnd tip: Keep an eye on the pacing and feeling of your session and steer it in the right direction.
#dnd tip: Strong starts don't need to be combat. The main theme of the strong start is "something happens".
#dnd tip: Keep some fun encounters on hand and drop the right one in as needed during your game.
#dnd tip: You don't owe anything to your game preparation. If it's working for your game you're doing it right.
#dnd tip: What's the one-word theme of your campaign? Write it down and keep it in front of you while preparing and running your games.
#dnd tip: Keep the characters in front of you at all times. You never know how how you can draw them into the story.
#dnd tip: Stuck for an idea? Write down 10 ideas as fast as you can and see what your brain comes up with.
#dnd tip: Grab the knives the players give you but don't stab too deep or they won't give you another.
#dnd tip: What's cool? What's fun? What's funny? What makes sense for the situation?
#dnd tip: Fun is more important than realism.
#dnd tip: Build dungeons quickly with a map, some one- to three-word room descriptions with fantastic monuments, and a handful of potential encounters (good and bad).
#dnd tip: Note the players' interest in particular NPCs and double down on them.
#dnd tip: Write down NPC names as soon as they're spoken.
#dnd tip: End some games early so you have times to ask for stars and wishes. What did each player enjoy so far? What are they hoping for or looking forward to?
#dnd tip: Relax and focus on the basics.
#dnd tip: Just because a creature has multiattack doesn't mean they have to use it.
#dnd tip: Use NPC personalities that reinforce the themes and feeling of the campaign.
#dnd tip: What's the one thing you learned from the last game you ran?
#dnd tip: Give players the option to declare enemies either killed or "knocked out" even with spells or ranged attacks. Give the players agency over the world to decide if such things happened.
#dnd tip: Write down NPC names as soon as they're spoken.
#dnd tip: Put yourself in the point of view of the characters and NPCs. What does the world look like to *them*?
#dnd tip: Drop friendly or useful NPCs into enemy territory like dungeons or villainous lairs.
#dnd tip: Listen. Adjust.
#dnd tip: Let characters take out enemy combatants with good ideas and ability checks instead of just damage. "I pick up and body-slam that bandit into the lake."
#dnd tip: Use random tables to shake up the status quo.
#dnd tip: Lose yourself in the world and the characters.
#dnd tip: Take note of who's been quiet. Ask them what their character thinks of the current situation.
#dnd tip: Set up an easy and fast system to take notes during the game. Use it.
#dnd tip: Don't overstay the welcome of any one scene or situation. Know when to move things along.
#dnd tip: Show pictures.
#dnd tip: NPC stat blocks are the most reskinnable in the game. Know then and use them.
#dnd tip: Ask players to fill in details of the world around them.
#dnd tip: Glance at a monster's defenses and damage output along with its CR to gauge how it might play out when it hits your table.
#dnd tip: Make a checklist of the things you need to run your game. Check it ten minutes before the game begins.
#dnd tip: Alternate between easy fights and hard fights.
#dnd tip: Keep a list of treasure you can drop in for the right upward beat.
#dnd tip: Be ready for a change in the story's direction when the characters roleplay with important NPCs.
#dnd tip: Keep your toolbox lean and focused on running an awesome game.
#dnd tip: Ride the flow of the story of the game.
#dnd tip: Tokens printed on photo paper and sealed using a 1" epoxy sticker and a 1" circular adhesive magnet are a great alternative to miniatures.
#dnd tip: What's the situation? What's the location? What's the goal? Who are the inhabitants?
#dnd tip: Use handouts to draw players into the game.
#dnd tip: Omit what distracts from the story you share.
#dnd tip: Keep the characters' names in front of you all the time.
#dnd tip: Let the characters get the edge on their villains.
#dnd tip: Replace published NPCs with those who matter to the characters.
#dnd tip: Be liberal awarding partial cover when characters seek it out.
#dnd tip: If your game jumped forward 14 months into the future in the middle of a session, would you be ready to keep running?
#dnd tip: It's really hard to beat the flexibility, portability, and cost of a dry-erase flip mat and some dry-erase markers.
#dnd tip: Choose tools that help you improvise during the session.
#dnd tip: Run with scissors.
#dnd tip: Keep some generic tokens or miniatures on hand for improvised battles.
#dnd tip: Wrap fantastic locations in the lore of gods old and new.
#dnd tip: Offer three options.
#dnd tip: Draw player in through the skills of their characters.
#dnd tip: Address the quiet player.
#dnd tip: Keep a list of the characters in front of you at all times.
#dnd tip: Refine you tools.
#dnd tip: Ask your players what they enjoyed and want more of.
#dnd tip: Make boring monsters fantastic in your story and narrative.
#dnd tip: Clarify when characters get info from unreliable narrators.
#dnd tip: Mix monster stat blocks.
#dnd tip: Use tabletop terrain as scene set pieces, not just for combat.
#dnd tip: Start and end with a bang.
#dnd tip: Reintroduce NPCs the players know and love, even love to hate.
#dnd tip: Show character secrets through dreams and visions.
#dnd tip: Take a walk and think about the drives and backgrounds of the characters in your game.
#dnd tip: Try a small new thing in every session.
#dnd tip: What's the coolest thing in your next session? Double down on that.
#dnd tip: Move quickly to the actions and decisions of the characters.
#dnd tip: Build custom magic items for your characters.
#dnd tip: Focusing on the characters may be the biggest impact you can have in your game.
#dnd tip: Give the characters a headquarters. Let them customize it.
#dnd tip: Watch the time.
#dnd tip: For some encounters, give players the choice to engage in combat, roleplaying, or skip them completely.
#dnd tip: Every scene is an opportunity for the characters to learn something.
#dnd tip: Move mysteries forward one clue at a time. Enough to learn something new but not enough to see the whole picture.
#dnd tip: Reinforce the theme and feeling of your campaign with each NPC, environment, and worldly description.
#dnd tip: Thank your players for taking the time to enjoy a game with you.
#dnd tip: Fill your mind with great books, movies, shows, and games.
#dnd tip: Find the right music to add atmosphere to your game.
#dnd tip: Reflavor animated armor with origins, conditions, and elemental damage.
#dnd tip: Let players respec their characters.
#dnd tip: Tailor magic items to the backgrounds and interests of the characters.
#dnd tip: Quick monster stats: AC / DC = 12 + 1/2 CR; HP = 15 x CR; Attack Bonus / Prof Saves / Prof Skills = 3 + 1/2 CR; damage = 7 x CR
#dnd tip: The heist model is a nearly perfect D&D scenario. Choose a goal, choose a location, add inhabitants (some known, some a surprise), allow for some planning, complicate the situation.
#dnd tip: What's your villain doing right now? What do they want? What steps are they taking to get there?
#dnd tip: Run small experiments.
#dnd tip: Think about what cool magic items fit the characters.
#dnd tip: Peek at the players' character sheets to fuel ways to spotlight their coolest features.
#dnd tip: Mix equal parts humor and sinister.
#dnd tip: What tools help you best share stories of high adventure with your friends?
#dnd tip: Use dirty tricks to help you improvise during the game.
#dnd tip: Start and end with the fiction.
#dnd tip: What stats do you *really* need to run a monster?
#dnd tip: What choices or actions can the characters take in this scene you're building?
#dnd tip: Offer three options to fuel the players' ideas.
#dnd tip: Let time expand or contract to support the pacing of the game.
#dnd tip: What are you most excited about in your next session?
#dnd tip: Focus on the fun parts of your game.
#dnd tip: You don't need new mechanics for every new situation. Let ability checks guide new actions.
#dnd tip: Don't shame players for missing things. Give them opportunities to refresh their understanding.
#dnd tip: Run NPC vs NPC combats in the narrative. Don't bother to roll attacks back and forth.
#dnd tip: Mix up scene types between roleplaying, exploration and combat.
#dnd tip: Avoid more than one red herring in a row.
#dnd tip: Clarify choices in any given scene. Get quickly to "what do you do?".
#dnd tip: Break symmetry.
#dnd tip: Build great dungeons with clear goals, a cool map, fantastic locations, secrets and clues, interesting NPCs, and dangerous foes.
#dnd tip: Drop an interesting location and situation in the middle of travel.
#dnd tip: Keep monsters, secrets and clues, and interesting NPCs abstract from the location so you can drop them in anywhere that fits the story and pacing of your game.
#dnd tip: Tweak monsters to fit their place in the story.
#dnd tip: Build encounters around the location and situation in the world.
#dnd tip: Let arcane boss monsters redirect damage done to them to their nearest hapless minions.
#dnd tip: Give boss monsters multiple concentration spells tied to nearby destructible pillars.
#dnd tip: What groups operate in opposition to the characters' goals?
#dnd tip: Skim-read the next part in your published adventure shortly before you run it.
#dnd tip: Highlight and take notes in your published books. A mass-produced book just became a unique one.
#dnd tip: Take a moment to check in with players to make sure everyone's enjoying what's going on and has an avenue to give you feedback.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to reiterate your safety tools mid-adventure or mid-campaign.
#dnd tip: Let players know if the theme of your campaign is going to shift. Ensure they're still into it.
#dnd tip: Every NPC has a name and a title.
#dnd tip: Give monsters extra attacks or take them away to help balance an imbalanced economy of actions.
#dnd tip: Flavor each room or chamber to reinforce the theme of the adventure or campaign.
#dnd tip: Reward characters who takes risks and move the story forward.
#dnd tip: Give each character a chance to shine both mechanically and in their story each session.
#dnd tip: It's easy to get excited with an NPC you love. Don't overblow your monolog.
#dnd tip: Ensure characters have meaningful choices in each scene you run.
#dnd tip: Ensure roleplaying scenes give characters useful information.
#dnd tip: Who hasn't gotten a magic item recently? Add one they're sure to love.
#dnd tip: Reskin monsters into creatures unique for your setting and adventure.
#dnd tip: Prepare for your big surprise to get blown early. How does your campaign keep moving forward even if the characters know the answer?
#dnd tip: What NPC are you most excited to roleplay next session?
#dnd tip: Reskin monster stat blocks into your own twisted horrors.
#dnd tip: Aim for more episodic sessions when you know players can't make it from session to session.
#dnd tip: Reveal secrets before the players figure them out.
#dnd tip: Plan and prepare scenes you can't wait to run.
#dnd tip: Move the features of dungeon chambers to the rooms you want them to be in as you play.
#dnd tip: Write down one to three interesting features for each chamber in a dungeon.
#dnd tip: It's easy for people to talk over one another when playing online. Interrupt the interrupter and pass it to the original talker, then back to the interrupter.
#dnd tip: Have a session zero conversation about lag, conversational interruptions, and how you'll deal with it for online games.
#dnd tip: During scenes of rest, ask the characters how they feel about the current situation and what it makes them think about from their past.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to give out vorpal swords. Let them run with scissors.
#dnd tip: Give knives, just don't take them. Give your characters campaign-breaking items, alliances, and powers.
#dnd tip: Strip down your NPCs to those your players can remember.
#dnd tip: Instead of sub-systems focus on ability checks, roleplaying, and your facilitation of events.
#dnd tip: Make a checklist of the things you need to run your game. Check it before the game begins.
#dnd tip: Use adhesive book tabs to mark monsters in your monster books and make them easily accessible during your game.
#dnd tip: Few tools are as usable and flexible as the humble index card.
#dnd tip: Use "pause for a minute" as a verbal queue to break character and address situations as players outside of the game.
#dnd tip: Maps or terrain need not just be for combat. Give the players a cool view of the room in which their characters engage in crucial conversations.
#dnd tip: Reveal the world and situation through the backgrounds, skills, and proficiencies of the characters.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to end a game early if the timing is right and the situation works better at the beginning of the next game instead of the end of this one.

#dnd tip: Give players early warning to think about their "one year later" montage at the end of a campaign. Should they survive, where might they see their characters one year after the events of the campaign?
#dnd tip: Important enemies might not die on the final blow. Let them offer one last bit of NPC interaction before they expire.
#dnd tip: Read published adventures. Take the parts you like and reshape them into what you want to run.
#dnd tip: Write down the targets of past foreshadowing so you remember to bring them back into the story later.
#dnd tip: Don't steal the characters' final blow against a big villain by giving it to an NPC or some other external event.
#dnd tip: "Pause for a minute" to make sure the players are all good with the characters finishing off a villain.
#dnd tip: Clarify the choices the characters currently face.
#dnd tip: Add interesting phases to big battles. What new thing happens each round, good or bad?
#dnd tip: Add one or two interesting environmental features to big battle arenas.
#dnd tip: Give characters interesting options, even at the very end of a campaign.
#dnd tip: Don't spend a lot of time with monsters attacking monsters. Go with the narrative and put the spotlight back on the characters.
#dnd tip: Give bosses legendary resistances but clearly delineate them as legendary so players don't waste save or suck spells on them.
#dnd tip: Follow Level Up Advanced 5e's idea and tie legendary resistances to in-world features like glyphs on a sword or ioun stones floating around one's head.
#dnd tip: Tie spells from third party products to scrolls and magic items to gently introduce new features the players haven't seen before.
#dnd tip: Modify and customize published adventures based on the characters the players bring to the table.
#dnd tip: Add in fun NPCs and villains into published adventures and campaigns to make them your own.
#dnd tip: Keep a list of the players and characters in front of you during your prep and during your game.
#dnd tip: Ask players for pictures of their characters so all of you have visuals in mind.
#dnd tip: Think of a published campaign as one arc in a bigger story you're going to put together as the game moves forward.
#dnd tip: Limit character creation source material to steer each campaign in an interesting direction.
#dnd tip: Bring interesting third party material into your games. There's a world of fantastic options for our D&D game.
#dnd tip: Review a checklist of what you need to run a great game.
#dnd tip: Introduce lots of NPCs. Narrow down to the ones the players enjoy the most.
#dnd tip: What are the three most interesting features of the city your characters visit?
#dnd tip: Ask your players to describe the interesting features of their headquarters.
#dnd tip: Introduce NPCs the characters know from their backgrounds.
#dnd tip: Tie NPCs to faces. Show pictures.
#dnd tip: Print NPC face cards four to a page. Cut them out and keep them in front of the players.
#dnd tip: What characteristics make your next NPC unique? What interests your players?
#dnd tip: Adding an extra attack can dramatically and easily boost a monster's threat.
#dnd tip: In each session give each character a chance to shine both mechanically and in the story.
#dnd tip: What's happening in the background while the characters go about their business?
#dnd tip: What forgotten tunnels, sewers, chambers, ruins, and caverns lie beneath your city?
#dnd tip: Embrace the quantum ogre. Let the world shift in interesting ways as the characters choose their path.
#dnd tip: Give boss monsters movement that doesn't provoke opportunity attacks and some extra attacks of their own to make up for the big crosshair on their back.
#dnd tip: Balance a large number of characters with a large number of monsters, but expect the battle to go long.
#dnd tip: Share observations from the point of view of the characters. What do they see, hear, and know?
#dnd tip: Give the characters the opportunity to discover traps. Discovered traps are far more rewarding than sprung traps.
#dnd tip: Add traps that make sense for the location, not just ones that "challenge" the characters. Walking right through a bunch of low-level traps is a fun way to enjoy a higher-level character.

#dnd tip: The MCDM minion rules are an easy way to run dozens of monsters. Give creatures a trait that, when successfully hit with an attack or failing a saving throw, they die. It's a fast way to get lots of monsters on and off the table.
#dnd tip: Give players meaningful choices when exploring a dungeon.
#dnd tip: Address the characters of quiet players.
#dnd tip: What ten secrets and clues might the characters uncover in your next game?
#dnd tip: Focus your game around the plotlines you enjoy the most.
#dnd tip: Embrace third party material. Expand your selection of campaigns, adventures, monsters, and character options.
#dnd tip: What can the characters learn about the activities of the villains behind the scenes?
#dnd tip: Write and email short flash fiction between games to keep players engaged.
#dnd tip: Introduce villains early and often.
#dnd tip: Foreshadow villains with annoying heralds.
#dnd tip: Don't be afraid to let players know when they've crossed a line you don't want crossed.
#dnd tip: Extra attacks dramatically increase a monster's threat.
#dnd tip: Let characters turn prisoners into turncoats, informants, employees, or good citizens who turn over a new leaf.
#dnd tip: Ask players what they look forward to in future sessions.
#dnd tip: Let players know what story events lead to new levels.
#dnd tip: Give the characters a home base they can evolve and upgrade as their campaign continues.
#dnd tip: Give players an easy way to travel back to their home base, even from afar. Shadow-roads, elven gateways, ancient portals, glyphed stones of returning.
#dnd tip: Clarify what sources you allow for character creation and clarify how to keep track of this in tools like D&D Beyond.
#dnd tip: Embrace third party material.
#dnd tip: Be wary of a reliance on digital tools. They don't last the hundreds of years a book does.
#dnd tip: What scene excites you to run in your next game?
#dnd tip: Ask players to describe their new character abilities to you and the other players whenever they level.
#dnd tip: Note what character abilities excite your players. Build encounters to show them off.
#dnd tip: Let fantastic art Inspire NPCs, villains, locations, and whole campaigns.
#dnd tip: Change campaigns with your own fantastic ideas.
#dnd tip: Prep and drive campaigns with the goals and quests of your villains.
#dnd tip: Give mini-bossess double HP and maybe an extra attack to set them apart from the rabble.
#dnd tip: Prep with handouts. Pack them with important names, places, and plots.
#dnd tip: Plan roughly one scene for every 45 minutes of game time.
#dnd tip: Recap previous sessions - either provided by you or your players.
#dnd tip: Think about the beat and pacing you want to end with in your session and how you might get there.
#dnd tip: Break up long travel with interesting encounters and locations along the way
#dnd tip: Spend the time to design your big knock-down drag-out set piece battles.
#dnd tip: Develop your comfort in improvising smaller situational combat encounters.
#dnd tip: Build a library of re-usable encounter maps for improvised battles.
#dnd tip: Build battles that let players show off their cool abilities.
#dnd tip: Ask players what combat abilities they want to use. Give them situations to use them.
#dnd tip: Have players describe the new capabilities of their characters when they level up. Note it in your character notes.
#dnd tip: Give players meaningful choices as often as possible.
#dnd tip: Print out art and hand it out during the game.
#dnd tip: Use third party campaign worlds as a hub for lots of third party content. Build an entirely new flavor of D&D around it.
#dnd tip: End on a cliffhanger and your strong start is built in.
#dnd tip: Ask players what types of magic items they'd like for their characters.
#dnd tip: Write down notes right after a session before you forget them all.
#dnd tip: Fill travel with interesting situations with choices to make and lore to discover.
#dnd tip: Watch carefully for players having a poor time from bad luck. Find ways to give them an upward beat.
